fun

The game that changed game making forever and of top of that created a new genre.
What can I say, this game is fantastic in every aspect.
Epic battle system, epic lore, epic fights, epic character design, epic audio design, epic level design, epic score/music design, epic art direction, epic game direction, epic online experience.
This game will remain always in my heart.
We must protect Hidetaka Miyazaki at all costs.
PLIN PLIN PLON.

PD: Played it on Steam Deck flawlessly.

I played the original Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition years ago and this remaster (so far) is a faithful port.  
Despite its reputation, like many Souls games, it isn't that difficult and can become quite relaxing once you get use the the attack patterns (and learned the location of enemies). 
The bosses are satisfying to beat and the grandiose lore reminds me of Greek Mythology.
Its also one of the first linear games that don't feel linear but is. 
Now onto my review:

Graphics 8/10 - Only complaint is that the player's face always looks weird no matter what.

Game play 9/10 - Can be infuriating at times as the controls get delayed sometimes. (Which also becomes a major issue in DS2). Just beware falling into the trap of farming to progress levels to beat a boss. It doesn't work, you just have to git gud.

Narrative/Lore 8/10 - Like all FromSoft Souls games, you have to dig for the lore. But it is damn compelling. So far my favourite boss lore is that of Artorius.  Overall it is a tragic tale, one I recommend VaatiVidya on YouTube to explain.

Experience 10/10 - Love the feeling when finally defeating difficult bosses. I especially hate Manus - too infuriating. Love the stories of the side cast NPCs and their tragic tales into insanity (RIP best booi and onion knight).

Overall Score 9/10 - A few complaints about the delayed controls and the trend of my character's face looking like a potato. Great game, highly recommend.

Praise the Sun!!
Faithful to the original, play this if you want the true Dark Souls experience. Also very easy to play with friends... compared to the original.

Probably the best game From Software will ever put out (Elden Ring somehow being in the same category). Every aspect of the game has a certain kind of significance to it and every choice it forces you to make has enormous intent within the context of its systems; the game works to familiarize you with them and gives you options and safety nets only to change, limit or take them away completely. At the same time it achieves a balance such that you're always only barely completing your objectives with just the smallest bit of health to spare. It gives you a consistent feeling of satisfaction and fulfillment in the face of the utterly bleak setting.

Very fun game. I can't say the difficulty was too bad on this one, the hardest part was how clunky all these older controls are and a lot of bugs in this game. I had a blast on my first play-through, currently working on NG+ to get all achievements like I did with Elden Ring. However if this is the first Souls game you're wanting to play I highly recommend playing Elden Ring first as I did. This experience wasn't half as good as Elden Ring's, although it was enjoyable. The bosses in this game were pretty strange, if they weren't stupid easy they were ridiculously hard. I gotta say the mods for this game look like a lot of fun so I am excited to try some of them. The areas in this game that are good are just filled to the brim with enemies while the rest of them straight up suck. Also the balancing in this game is AWFUL. I really wish that I could give an in between of thumbs up and thumbs down for this game.

I've played the original Dark Souls to death and loved it. It used to be my favorite game before Elden Ring came out. The remake honestly is very similar. I however have one huge issue with the remake. The way they programmed in the controller joystick makes it very likely overtime to cause your character to constantly go between running and walking when trying to run. From what I understand they made it so it only considers you running if the joystick is fully going in one direction. The issue is all joysticks overtime will struggle to maintain the original maximum directionality and as a result it will bounce between registering your character as running and walking. As this game has very essential platforming it becomes nearly unplayable with controllers that aren't perfect or new. 
Imagine the pain felt as you are walking through an area of the game where you have to avoid giant blades trying to knock you off narrow platforms and you have to pass through four quickly only to suddenly go from running to walking on the last one and your character gets knocked off and dies. 
Now imagine running up extremely narrow rooftops with giant archers who are shooting ballistic arrows at you and if a single one hits you you get knocked off and die. Repeatedly you get close to the end of of this nightmare but time after time you switch from running to walking at crucial times and are launched from the rooftop to your doom below. You've done this many times before but the new difficultly of bad programming of controller joysticks has you bested. You find another one of your less desirable but newer controllers and swiftly get through the area but feel the disappointment in your hands as you realize the reboot of the game you loved is nearly unplayable because of the pure incompetence of the programmers who worked on the joysticks.  May future games avoid this curse and better programmers with more sense work on how to make a functional joystick.

I would give this a solid upvote, except for these reasons:

1. There are little to no accessibility options (This is the big one.)

2. Accidentally hitting an NPC can cut off entire avenues of progress in the game as they'll become hostile and not trade 
    with you anymore. Yes, there is an NPC who you can buy forgiveness from, but if you hit him by accident too, you're SOL. 

3. Much of the game is obtuse just for the sake of it, instead of actually contributing to a better game.

4. The player is inundated with dozens of items, like 30+ kinds of weapons, 30+ kinds of armors, and dozens of spells, but realistically, playing through the campaign without grinding, you'll only ever really experience one fully upgraded weapon/armor build. The amount of weapons and armors begins to feel like bloat, thrown in to add story through item descriptions, instead of actually having the story play out through the game.
This game belongs in a museum.

The definition of a Masterpiece.
I truly do believe that this game perfected difficulty in video games. Sure, Demon's Souls did it first or whatever, but in my opinion, Demon's Souls' difficulty has a lot of added B.S. to it like with the world tendency system, and just how overall experimental the game was.

I do love this remaster, it may be no Demon's Souls Remake, but I really like the better particle effects, 60 fps, and proper resolution. I know a lot of people like to hate on this remaster because it didn't change a lot of things, but you have to remember all of the quality of life things they added and just how much better optimized it is compared to Prepare To Die Edition. Remastered version or not, this game is a masterpiece and my favorite game in the Souls trilogy and genre. 10/10, a certified MASTERPIECE.

'Tis said that long ago peace and tranquility covered the lands. Food and drink flowed freely, man and beast lived in peace, gold and silver abounded â€“ it was the Golden Age of Akalabeth.

Mondain, second born of Wolfgang, a great king of old, wished to gain his brother's inheritance and so he used his great powers for evil, creating deep dungeons guarded by daemons and Balrogs. Now blood flowed freely in Akalabeth, and foul creatures soon came to roam near the surface. Mondain cast such sickness and pestilence upon Akalabeth, that both man and beast lived in constant fear. Thus was the Dark Age of Akalabeth.

There arose from the land a man, pure and just, to battle the Dark Lord. British, Champion of the White Light, did battle with Mondain deep within the labyrinth of dungeons, eventually driving him from Akalabeth forever. British of the White Light was proclaimed Lord British, Protector of Akalabeth. Alas, much damage had been suffered unto the lands. The Revival of Akalabest has begun.

Dark Souls. The pinnacle of fair but challenging game design. There are very few games I've played more than the first installment of this series, and I'm very happy to have experienced this game on PC + MNK prior to a full achievment run on Xbox a year or so ago, and it's provided me with a great new perspective on this game - especially after playing the rest of FromSoftware's lineup of soulslikes.

Without a doubt, this is the best game in the trilogy -  that may be a hot take, but this title has bee able to create a balance of amazing bosses, phenomenal level design/connectivity, storytelling and writing, build options, and overall feeling of fair difficulty. Of course there are some major flaws with this game, the biggest being Demon Ruins, Lost Izalith and their bosses; along with some AI bugginess in certain bossfights, most prominent with Gwyn.

Now when approaching this game on mouse and keyboard, it was a completely different experience, and in some ways, better than controller - ex: item/estus slot switch w/ mouse wheel, dodge w/ spacebar. However, I believe the downsides of a keyboard and mouse make it to where I'd prefer this game and recommend FromSoft's SoulsBorne games with a controller. The biggest issue with this game not using a controller was definitely parry. Having to use two buttons to parry felt extremely un-intuitive and there wasn't really an ideal button to map it to. I actually had to switch to a controller on the NG+ Gwyn fight after tanking the fight for hours and after thirty minutes or so on controller, the fight was over. Highly recommend using a controller for this one.

As for boss quality, this contains the best and most well designed bosses in the series: Knight Artorias, Gwyn, Ornstein and Smough, Manus, and Sif. This game also contains some of the worst in the series: Bed of Chaos, Capra Demon, and Demon Firesage being the best examples. Nonetheless, I believe the good much outweighs the frustrating in this case, helping that the Bed and the Firesage don't exactly bug me as much as it would for most. Every boss (for the most part) is carefully crafted to test certain abilities you have in the game - Gwyn tests your parry skills, Four Kings tests your ability to do rapid damage with a ring slot gone, Manus tests your patience and endurance, the Asylum and Taurus Demon test your ability to use the arena to your advantage, and so on. Each boss is fully unique, with the only exceptions being Stray and Firesage Demons. All are very well representative of their lore and are fun and engaging to fight, while being challenging yet fair (again, for the most part....)

When it comes to map layout, this game is absolutely perfect - with a sea of open world games out there, having more closed and constructed level design akin to more oldschool games works extremely well for this game. Shortcuts are extremely rewarding to explore and finding items, weapons and more in tucked away spots even more so. This game takes the mentality of knowing its layout like the back of your hand and applies it better than any FromSoftware title, considering that many of their games are more or less straight paths relying on bonfire teleports to backtrack.

I'll always be happy to come back to replay this masterpiece every so often. My soul level one playthrough is just itching to start. If you are looking to pick up an extremely high quality RPG - do your best to three-pointer your copy of Assasin's Creed in the trashcan and pick up this title. It may be hard at first but anyone can finish this game.

Dark Souls is a game catered towards a specific kind of player. You have to work for everything yourself. You have to work to know enemies and learn their patterns to defeat them. You have to listen to NSCs to get to know their stories and quests and learn about the world. They don't repeat important information and it's not stored anywhere so you have to be attentive. This is also true for the world. It's very beautifully built in detail and will give you alot of infos if you are willing to pay attention and look for it. All around the game experience is amazing if you are willing to put in the effort.
If you are that player dark souls is one of the best experiences in video gaming you will have. You will have to earn that experience yourself but i promise it will be worth it.
Only caveat one has to mention is that the servers for online play are not available and probabely won't be in the future. 
If you are looking for one of the best and most intense single player gaming experiences you are  in the perfect place.

Dark Souls is a classic with fantastic world design and challenging gameplay. If you can muster the patience to overcome your many enemies, you will find much to enjoy in one of the best games of all time.
Sim.
It still is a great game but after O&S was a genuine insult to my time spent playing

DS1 is a great game and it deserved a much better remaster. This shit is the worst case scenario and doesn't justify existing for a marked up price, let alone after delisting the original. All it has going for it is a portion of the fixes you can find in an unofficial patch and, in some ways, higher fidelity graphics which occasionally look worse than the original. It's an insulting missed opportunity that QLOC didn't fix some of the major bugs or port in any of the control improvements and QOL that From has developed on since DS1, for starters. If you have access to the original, consider how little more you're actually paying for on top of that.
it  was fun
dark souls try not to be a great ass game challenge (impossible)
best
Kill the undead merchant and get a cool katana.

This remaster isn't the ideal remaster, with all the remastering primarily affecting textures and fixing the network issues that plagued the first port. It is essentially exactly the same as it used to be with a tiny bit of polish and now you don't need to install DSfix to play with friends. I honestly hardly noticed much of a difference texture wise while playing through. 

I only really put this as a recommend because this is now the only real way to play the game since Prepare to Die Edition is no longer for sale and can only be accessed through keys sold by third party and if you're new to the series this is absolutely worth getting.

When stepping into this, if you come from DS3 or Elden Ring, remember that this game is going to feel dated because all of the old design is here. Bosses won't be as crazy as they are to watch in action as they are in Elden Ring. This is where they learned and improved from Demon Souls, and so coming back to this title from 2 or more games in the future is a huge leap backwards. You will see where they started in the realm of PC here. 

My advice to anyone brave enough to trek through this classic, learn to parry, be aggressive, and Prepare to Die. 

"It may be tough, and it may make you cry, but between the scenery and the difficulty, it is a beautiful and challenging game. The detail on the buildings, Anor Londo specifically, is to die for (since the things in the place might kill you anyway!).

It is a tough game, for sure, and should not be sat down with while in a mental state that says "I will be good at this, better than anybody else, and I will beat it." You will more than likely end up frustrated in the end." 
- Relevant information from my review of Prepare to Die Edition.

Dark Souls Remastered should have been free to anyone who had Prepare to Die (like with Bioshock Remastered). I resisted buying it even at the original discounted price because I was salty about it. But watching a recent playthrough made me nostalgic, so I figured fuck it. Also, hashtag entitled gamer or whatever.

I still can't find a weapon that I love but I guess Sunlight Blade buffed Falchion will have to do for now.

If you are looking for more souls because you have played Elden Ring and DS3 let me tell you this ain't it. I understand this game was probably great when it initially came out but if you didn't play it back then you will hate it. The combat is a bit rough with attacks going through i frames some attacks not hitting etc. The game feels incredibly sluggish, your roll, your attacks, enemy attacks take 5 hours to complete. But mostly what frustrates is the bosses. They are either incredibly boring and easy because they have 3 different attacks or just unfun bullshit like 2 bosses attacking at different times together so much that you simply can't have enough stamina to dodge all of them without farming first. Oh and the walkbacks are disgusting. Every time you have to walk 1 minute at least and fight roughly 10-12 enemies before you can try the boss again. And usually its made in a a way that you cant run past them either. The game feels also as hard as DS3 and Elden Ring combined but not in a good way that challenges your skill but rather in an unfun "really what is this, why did they do that" way. 

I 100% Elden Ring, played DS3 twice, played sikiro and other soulslikes and loved all of them. But this i regret spending money on, i would rather replay one of the good ones
number 1 game
peak souls: repeaked

---Negatives---

- Old game. Little bit clunky
- Related to the game called Dark Souls 2 


---Positives---

- Incredible game-play that brings the old school of developing game play with intricate level design and simple move sets. 
- Very easy game if you know what you are doing. In your second play through you can decimate your environment. So it is not the problem of everything is being challenging but problem of lacking information.
- Incredible interconnection. I didn't see anything close to DS1.
- Some bosses will remain in your mind forever. 
- Very recognisable and characteristic art direction. You can almost immediately recognise Dark souls among bunch of medieval genre. 
- Variation of skills, spells and weapons. That leads more replay ability.
- Poise
- Too much content if you interested with story. However, it does not force it into you. Players choose to consume it or not by using outside sources. 

---Sum---

An Incredible masterpiece. It is one of the literature worthy games that will have influence over many future games.

[b][u]Liked[/u][/b][list]
[*] The gameplay is probably the best thing to come out of the gaming industry as a whole since its inception.[/list]
[b][u]Disliked[/u][/b][list]
[*] Sometimes items will fall through the map.
[*] Sometimes the body of a dead enemy or broken objects will get stuck on your character.
[*] Sometimes the full questline for an NPC will be hard to follow without a guide.
[*] Sometimes Solaire of Astora's summon sign will be bugged and won't appear before the final boss fight.
[*] The endings are extremely anti-climactic as all you get is a 50 second cutscene.
[*] The story-telling method of reading item descriptions is [u]objectively[/u] bad story-telling for a video game.[/list]

Started with Sekiro, then bloodborne, DS3, Elden Ring, DS2, and finally decided to give the one that started it all a shot since they came out with a remastered version. [h1] A chessboard game with pool precision [/h1]

I feel like most people only like it because they haven't played it in a while. It is painfully slow, ganky and repetitive. On top of all that, the game is actively punishing you for being new (or even average for that matter) - be it enemy placing, where you have to know exactly where to wait or who to kill to not get stuck, or be it navigating the area without getting killed. And it may be easy for someone who already knows their way around the game, but not for any new player.

[b]Enemies[/b] are placed in such a way they block your path and don't let you escape. And it may be fine for a relatively easy areas such as undeadburg, but then goes sens fortress, anor londo, lower londo, the catacombs and so on and you are slowly getting tired of fighting same hordes of generic enemies over and over again. Because...

[b]Combat[/b] is awful. And it's not just game being slow in general - it's also the pacing - many enemies, instead of slowly chipping your health, have one chain attack that does a lot of damage. And here's the question - will you risk having a blow trade, knowing well that if you fail you have to run half of the map again? You'll probably play safe. That makes an already slow game feel even slower. And even if you did choose to engage, prepare for...

[b]Controls[/b]. Artificial difficulty at its finest. As I said, the game requires high precision because each mistake can get you  ganked, oneshot etc. Well, this game has input buffering - but only for certain things aka you can't press heal twice and actually heal twice. But you can roll when you don't want to. Or attack when you don't want to. And with rolls only having 8 directions, you easily roll into your own grave. Again, this is the game where you are supposed to be very precise at your rhythm and movement - placing such restrictions on a player are creating artificial difficulty. Those who already already played it will understand me - [h3] you're not fighting enemies, you're fighting your own controls [/h3]

[b]Locations[/b] are probably the only thing this game does right. I won't be talking about rushed Izalith as I don't have much issues with this area. But sure enough, if there is anything to like about this game, it is its interconnected world with very memorable spots.

[b]Weapons[/b] are okay, upgrade system is not. This stone, that stone, grind this here, grind that there, you need this ember then you need that ember. And I won't even talk about places where you're supposed to "find" those embers. Imo weapon scaling should be your only mean to upgrade weapon and you should be able to upgrade via level-ups

[b]The conclusion[/b]
Sometimes I wish people could stop savoring each and every Michael Zaki's footcrumb and just admit this game blows. This whole "git gud" thing is nothing but "take it in the Ð°ss like a champ". This game's problem is not rushed development or somewhat archaic souls formula - it's artificial difficulty created by bad level design and broken pacing.

This game is a masterpiece, a carefully constructed experience that will probably scar you for the rest of your life.
You'll feel things at times, things we all have felt. You'll be left in awe and wonder, or scared and confused, desperate even. And then you'll feel right at home. All this just by playing through a game.

If you haven't yet played this game, I envy you, because you still do so for the first time.
Witnessing Lordran and its tales, is "like" living through a legend. You'll see with your own eyes, the myths of this world, through a cathartic storytelling experience.

It's not an easy game, but that is part of the appeal, the game itself gives you all the tools to beat it, and definitely doenst hold your hand, giving you complete freedom to fail time and time again. And it's okay.

------------------------------------------------

The remaster:

Besides the controversy caused by the removal of the original, and charging almost full price for a slightly improved version of  the same, we are still talking about a masterpiece, made by a company who doesn't sell you DLCs at release, nor unfinished games filled with microtransactions, and for me the price is more than worth of the value i got out of the game.

The remaster iself is honestly not bad, the difference in user experience is night and day.
The game is now 60 Fps, and keybindings have also been adjusted to be more in line with the newer souls titles.

Definitely got a tad crusty with age, but still the most solid world of the series overall I feel.
Of the souls games, I recommend either Dark Souls 1 or Elden Ring as a starting point with a warning that Elden Ring will spoil newcomers with all the quality of life features that have come over the years. But if you really want to see what got this series into the limelight, as well as the popularization of what people call souls-likes, then do yourself a favor and play this game.

It can be tough at times, especially to a new player, but fret not as the game rewards patient players and those willing to adapt to new strategies to overcome obstacles. The game is full of highly memorable set pieces that are bound to leave a lasting impression; as well as great freedom in what you can choose to do with your adventure. This game is over 10 years old and still has an active online playerbase as well, allowing you to still experience the jolly cooperation as well as dastardly invasions of players at your leisure. Not a fan of online? No problem, the game is entirely doable offline as well.

Blighttown

Enough has been written about it for you to understand the experience - it's actually kind of shocking to someone working backwards how much of Elden Ring's elements are kept entirely the same as those in Dark Souls, a game released a full decade before. That speaks to two things - that Dark Souls plays extremely well for its age, and that despite the stories being disparate, these are all games set in the same universe. At least when viewed analytically. 

That said, there have been some vast improvements to small gameplay elements between then and now out of convenience, and those improvements are sorely missed here. But this was the game that effectively reshaped an entire generation of development across the industry, so I can't really be that critical. The game is almost unfathomably expansive, and part of me wishes I could play it through the lens of someone who enjoyed it at the time, as it's been copied and supplanted so many times now that it's nearly impossible to understand how impressive it would have been.

Importantly, they've fixed the online functionality and I can change my review now that the game performs as advertised. 

Problem is that the online features aren't a boon. DS1 encourages griefing more than any other; my first invasion came the second I stepped into the Undead Burg - less than 5 mins after starting my newest playthrough. A low-level player had rushed to areas with high-tier gear and returned to prey on other low-level characters, forcing me into a tedious tit-for-tat for 10 minutes. This happened again, and again, and again. Sometimes the invaders would drop in when I was in extremely perilous areas, and then fail to find me. So I would stand and waste my time waiting for them because you can't use bonfires while they're in your game, unable to move in case I was attacked by monsters and the invader at the same time. 

Online play in DS1 involves rudimentary co-op, and one-sided PVP that both encourages and benefits exploitative players. I eventually decided to play the game offline, at which point I lost access to the soapstone warnings from other players about traps and treasures. So there's no ideal way to play this game - online and offline suck in different ways. 

That said, unlike other games in the series, DS1 doesn't block any essential progress off behind illusory walls or hard-to-find items. The level design is reasonably enjoyable to navigate, and of all the games in the series this one minimises the chance that you're going to forget where you're supposed to be going, or fail to see a passageway that takes you to the next area. Memories of initial clunkiness melted away as I played, until it just felt right. It's still intimidating and awe-inspiring and weird and inventive, and it's impossible to misunderstand why it's so well-regarded. I'd argue that, despite all its flaws, it's probably the best in a trilogy of flawed masterpieces. It's not conceptually tired like DS3, it's not quite as unnecessarily obtuse like DS2. For an observant and patient player who can check their preconceptions of what an RPG will demand of them at the door and learn the quirks that allow the game to be conquered, DS1 remains a singular experience.

This is by far my favorite game of all time. The mindlessness of playing is almost like crack. Fight, Die, Retry, Continue, Repeat. The enemy, level and boss design of this game is unmatched by nearly anything else I have ever played in my life. This game is great for multiple runs, whether it be for just different builds, or challenge runs. You fall in love with the game very quickly. You learn the game very quickly. You everything very quickly. There is ridiculously deep lore and story for you to dig into, HOWEVER, ITS OPTIONAL!!! This is my favorite part of Dark Souls. I don't have to like a story. I can enjoy a game for it's great gameplay and not have to have things be super complicated. But I can find out who the knight's of Gwyn are, so on and so on. Dark Souls Remastered, released in 2018, serves as a loving tribute to the iconic original game that cemented FromSoftware's reputation for creating challenging and atmospheric action RPGs. As a player who ventured into Lordran in the past, the remastered edition not only rekindles the flame of nostalgia but also breathes new life into the classic title for both veterans and newcomers alike.

Visually, the remastered edition brings Lordran into the modern era with upgraded textures, improved lighting, and a stable frame rate. The result is a world that retains its haunting beauty while benefiting from the technical advancements of contemporary gaming platforms. The enhancements, while not groundbreaking, contribute to a more polished and immersive experience.

The core of Dark Souls lies in its intricate level design and interconnected world, and the remastered edition faithfully preserves this hallmark. The atmospheric locales, from the towering spires of Anor Londo to the oppressive depths of Blighttown, are as captivating as ever. The ability to explore seamlessly without load screens enhances the sense of a cohesive and foreboding world.

Dark Souls Remastered introduces quality-of-life improvements that refine the overall experience. The increased multiplayer capacity, allowing up to six players to engage in jolly cooperation or brutal invasions, adds a new layer of unpredictability to the online component. Additionally, the bonfire warping system, initially introduced in Dark Souls II, is available from the start, streamlining travel across the expansive world.

The heart of Dark Souls is its demanding combat, and the remastered edition retains the punishing yet satisfying gameplay that fans cherish. The controls feel responsive, and the weight of each swing and dodge is conveyed with precision. The subtle tweaks to animations and hitboxes, while not altering the core mechanics, contribute to a smoother and more consistent combat experience.

The memorable boss encounters, a cornerstone of the Dark Souls experience, are just as impactful in the remastered edition. Facing off against iconic foes like Ornstein and Smough or grappling with the enigmatic Manus remains a thrilling test of skill and perseverance. The orchestral score, hauntingly beautiful in its melancholy, complements these battles and enhances the overall atmosphere.

While Dark Souls Remastered successfully modernizes the classic, it does little to address some of the original game's minor flaws. The camera can still be a source of frustration in tight spaces, and a few areas suffer from frame rate dips, although these issues are less pronounced than in the original release.

In conclusion, Dark Souls Remastered is a faithful and well-executed return to the challenging realms of Lordran. Whether you're a seasoned undead or a newcomer seeking to experience a gaming classic, the remastered edition offers a refined and enhanced journey through one of the most influential titles in the action RPG genre. It stands as a testament to the enduring legacy of Dark Souls and its continued relevance among gaming enthusiasts.

Very classic and genre-defining game. Dark Souls and Soulslike in general have the perfect combat system: Press RB to attack, press B to dodge or hold LB for shield and pay attention to telegraphed attacks. Nothing more and nothing less. It's simple, nothing too fancy and has a nice push and pull concept.

Boss encounters are challenging but fair! It revolves around learning their behaviour / attack patterns and countering them. 

The world is good designed during the first half of the game, almost bearing resemblance to a Metroidvania with many memorable encounters. No immediate checkpoint before a boss is not good though. It's a time waste having to run past enemies, everytime you fail a boss. This is NOT a challenge, no matter what "git gud soulsfanboys" are saying.

Sadly, the game suffers heavily if you reach the 2nd half of the game. The later areas become completely tied off from the interconnected areas and are lacking in the quality department. The distance between checkpoint and boss is also very unnecessarily long and it becomes frustrating when you have to run for 5 minutes (!) just to have a chance to learn a boss.

Lock-on can feel clunky, if you played modern Soulslikes. You can't sprint and you can only dodge in four directions. It's recommended to play without lock-on.

Forced PvP is unnecessary, very beginner unfriendly and should be completely optional, just like in Elden Ring.

Despite some flaws, it's still a good game. I have like 10 playthroughs on console and it was always fun (the first half atleast).

Sound Design 1/10

Its not dark souls 2 sadly, i would love the option to de-spawn enemies after killing them so many times and join a covenant if i want them turned back on.

I would recommend this game to other players, but i would first warn them of the potential pain and agony that this game brings. This game is amazing at times, and, if we're honest, terrible at others. Areas such as blighttown, Sen's Fortress and Lost Izalith are truly painful to play through, especially the first time. However, some areas are amazing. Most of them are, in fact. In all honesty, this game takes a significant step-down after you defeat Ornstein and Smough, essentially marking the half way point of the game. You must also be ready to deal with the clunky and dated feel of the game, especially if coming from more modern souls/soulslikes. For example, being immobile while healing or only having 4 dodge directions while locked on can really drag the game down, and take some getting used to, as it did for me as I played this after Elden Ring and Lies of P. In short, this game is great, but it is definitely an acquired taste.

I could go on and on but my mainpoint is this:
Most of the time I am not actually fighting the enemies or bosses but just the game (or its stupid mechanics) itself. 
To be honest most enemies/bosses dont put up a big fight anyway (and im saying this with the self-awareness of being not the best souls-player). Normally I get the biggest adrenaline-rush fighting bosses in souls-games but in this game it just feels like a slowass fight between old people. Wich is something that drags throughout the whole game. I know its an old game but still, this is supposed to be a 'remastered version' so why does everything feel so painfully slow, janky and well...not remastered at all?
I played through ds2 and ds3 and had a lot of fun doing so but this game is just trash. 
I will propably still finish it but definitely not blind (wich if you read my little adventure up there you know is something i wouldnt recommend anyone doing, wich is a shame tbh because I think thats how youre normally supposed to play these games and also how I had so much fun exploring/discovering things in ds2/3). 
Also this game is just way too expensive. Again, this game is not really 'remastered' so its essentially a more than 10 year old game that they still charge you 20 bucks (at least during the 2 times its on sale each year) for. Please just pay 10 bucks extra and get ds3 wich is actually the best souls-game. Thanks.

Don't be scared about the claims of this game being hard, you have many options in form of in-game mechanics to make the game easier.
The level design and area variety is a 10/10, although this game has some rough areas in the late part of the game where there was no budget.
The combat system is great, feels good most of the time, but you can see some flaws due to the game being a bit old, those issues get fixed immediately with the next entries in the series (its mostly about a meh lock on enemies system and some weird hitboxes, but nothing that annoying), but in any case the bosses and enemies are perfectly designed for the character to fight, feeling satisfactory..

Still Not Hollow: A Reverent Return to the Fires of Lordran

Introduction:
Dark Souls Remastered, developed by FromSoftware and published by Bandai Namco Entertainment, brings the beloved classic action RPG back to life with updated visuals, improved performance, and all the punishing difficulty that fans have come to love and fear. As players once again traverse the treacherous land of Lordran, they'll find themselves drawn into a world of dark fantasy, challenging gameplay, and unforgettable encounters. In this review, we'll delve into the enhancements and nostalgia that Dark Souls Remastered offers to both veterans and newcomers alike.

Enhanced Visuals and Performance:
One of the most noticeable improvements in Dark Souls Remastered is its enhanced visuals and performance. The game boasts updated textures, improved lighting effects, and a higher resolution, breathing new life into the haunting landscapes and intricate environments of Lordran. Whether exploring the twisted corridors of the Undead Burg or gazing out over the sprawling vistas of Anor Londo, players will find themselves immersed in a world that is as beautiful as it is dangerous. Additionally, the game runs more smoothly than ever before, with improved frame rates and reduced load times, ensuring a seamless and immersive experience from start to finish.

Faithful Recreation of Classic Gameplay:
Dark Souls Remastered stays true to the challenging and rewarding gameplay that made the original game a cult classic. Players will once again face off against hordes of deadly enemies, navigate treacherous traps and pitfalls, and battle larger-than-life bosses in epic showdowns. The game's signature combat system, which emphasizes timing, precision, and strategy, remains as punishing and exhilarating as ever, rewarding patience and skillful play with each hard-won victory. Whether mastering the intricacies of parrying and riposting or carefully managing stamina and equipment load, players will find themselves drawn into a gameplay experience that is as rewarding as it is unforgiving.

Multiplayer Enhancements and Quality of Life Improvements:
Dark Souls Remastered introduces several multiplayer enhancements and quality of life improvements that enhance the overall experience for players. The game features dedicated servers for online play, reducing lag and connectivity issues and providing a more stable and enjoyable multiplayer experience. Additionally, the game introduces password matchmaking, allowing players to easily connect with friends for cooperative or competitive play. Other quality of life improvements, such as the ability to use multiple items at once and the option to switch covenants at bonfires, streamline the gameplay experience and make it more convenient for players to focus on the action.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, Dark Souls Remastered is a reverent return to the fires of Lordran, offering both veterans and newcomers alike the chance to experience the classic action RPG in all its glory. With enhanced visuals, improved performance, and faithful recreation of the original gameplay experience, the game captures the essence of what made Dark Souls a beloved classic while introducing welcome enhancements and quality of life improvements. Whether facing off against fearsome foes solo or teaming up with friends for cooperative play, Dark Souls Remastered offers a challenging and rewarding journey through a world of dark fantasy and untold mysteries.

In this underground cult classic hit, we first are introduced to the phrase, "It's time to put out the candles, because this soul is getting dark." Little did we know John Darksouls was going to be saying that in our ears every 45 minutes for the next 5 years, but we didn't know how much it was going to ROCK. Now let's get into it. Dark Souls is a game from 2018, but it looks like a game from 2011, and takes cues from games like Lords of the Fallen (2014) and nioh (2017). When I boot up Dark Souls, and choose the difficulty settings, I usually choose easy. I like to think of Dark Souls as being like my dad, it can technically get hard. The entire time I played with John Darksoul I didn't play outside. So I got really pale, and my bones were brittle. I went to the doctor and she said "This is the first case of rickets I've ever seen." Anyway, if you want to know how Jon Darksouls got his darksoul you should start here.

Dark Souls is surprisingly ahead of its time owing to its stellar and interconnected level design. Exploration always feels rewarding and enriching. Combat is simple but tightly designed. It does show its age in certain aspects like graphics. Some areas are also questionably constructed (looking at you Anor Londo archers and Sen's Fortress rafters). And if you come in here expecting the bosses of Elden Ring and other newer titles then you'll likely be disappointed. Dark Souls is more deliberate, almost playing like a turn-based game trading blows with bosses. If you can get past a few slight janks here and there, then you're sure to find yourself enjoying this title.

I highly recommend playing Dark Souls Remastered to others for its unparalleled gaming experience that seamlessly blends challenging gameplay with a rich and atmospheric world. The game's unforgiving difficulty fosters a sense of accomplishment as players conquer formidable foes and intricate level designs. The meticulous attention to detail in the remastered version enhances the already stunning visuals, bringing Lordran to life in a way that captivates players from start to finish. The interconnected world encourages exploration and rewards curiosity, uncovering hidden lore and secrets that add depth to the narrative. The game's unique multiplayer features, including cooperative and competitive elements, contribute to its longevity, fostering a strong sense of community among players. Dark Souls Remastered stands as a testament to the timeless appeal of demanding yet rewarding gameplay, making it a must-play for those seeking an immersive and unforgettable gaming adventure.

I've eagerly been waiting for this to go on sale so I could see if this series would be something I'd enjoy playing. It really felt like my kind of thing, so I was probably going to buy the whole series if this game went well. Well... I spent a half hour messing around in the character creator, started the game and used up all of my starting flasks while getting used to the controls, got to the first boss, died, tried again, then the game disconnected from the servers ten seconds into the second fight and I asked Steam for a refund. Soured the whole experience.

I understand there's multiplayer parts to the game and everything, but I'm one that likes to play these games by myself. I'm not putting up with getting ripped out of my solo game because FromSoftware/Bandai Namco's servers are garbage. Went from wanting to buy the whole series to none. I guess I'll continue to play vicariously through streamers if I can't be sure I can even play a [u]solo[/u] game without getting booted for network issues.

This is the most accessible way to play Dark Souls on PC.
Compared to Prepare to Die Edition with Dsfix (mod), this behaves more like a PC game should.
The support for 60fps and the changes to multiplayer especially make this a far better experience.

Anti-cheat was the main point of contention in my original review, but since time has passed and the communities for this game and Dark Souls 3 have matured, it's become clear to me that it wasn't actually that big of a deal and that I no longer feel the same way about this game.
It is unclear if dropping cheated items and getting other players banned is still an issue, but this does not seem to be a common occurrence, and there are mods and utilities to get around the risk.

It is a bit unfortunate that some effects and textures were updated for the worse in the remaster, but that can thankfully be solved using mods.
Purely visual mods seem to be *somewhat* safe online, and it is now possible to approximate Prepare to Die Edition's appearance using them (though keep in mind that many non-visual mods are probably not safe online, and using any mods online is not recommended and done at your own risk).

As for the price, $40 would have been a rather steep asking price if this game didn't frequently go on sale. Don't buy this for full price, it's often 50% off and $20 is a more reasonable price.

In summary, this version is worth it and I'm glad to be wrong about it.


Original negative review:

The anti-cheat was unacceptable in Dark Souls 3 and it is unacceptable now. ]

gut

Thia franchise needs no introduction, I'm sure of it.

I'm here just to be one of the millions of alienated Miyazaki fanboys that tells you to play this game no matter what.

If "old" games bother you, don't worry. Play some Elden Ring, Sekiro, Dark Souls 3 or whatever game fits your last gen gaming computer needs. You'll eventually develop a lust for this specific feeling that only Miyazaki knows how to make us feel.

This one right here though is definitely the goat, DS1 incorporates everything that makes a "souls-like" a souls-like (even though I hate the terminology).

It's kind of overpriced depending upon where you live but it's never wasted money.

The lands of Lordran waits for you!

I cannot recommend any game more highly than this one. In my opinion, it remains the supreme gateway to Dark Souls and the Soulsborne series, possibly with the exception of Elden Ring. Maybe it will even give you a new mindset for achieving goals irl :)

Dark Souls 1 is the second game in the Souls Series, the first one being Demon Souls. This game and this remaster is worth your time and your money in 2024 and beyond. The game is good in 2023(when i played it twice) and it was probably great in 2011 when it first came out, there are some negatives tho and you need to be aware of them.

 First of all... 'Dark Souls' games come with a condition and that is 'Do you like a big challenge and a big reward?'. If you don't like a challenge let me tell you that the reward/satisfaction from clearing a level and beating a boss is the kind of experience that you will remember probably forever. These souls games give you those epic, unforgettable moments that is why they are worth it.

 Also please be aware that there is an easy mode for this game, its called summoning. You can summon npc help for bosses and even for level clears but for the real Dark Souls experience you should only summon if its your first run, the second run you should try to solo. Try to solo as much as you can even in the first run, when you see unfair parts or bosses go ahead and summon. Rewrote my review after my second FULLY SOLO run and 200+ hours of gameplay time.

[b]Positives:[/b]

- Great combat, deep combat
- Combos and energy management
- Satisfying kills on regular monsters
- Super satisfying/epic kills on bosses
- 200+ hours of content if you plan two runs(with summons/help for beginners + without summons for a better/deeper experience)
- Memorable levels
- Extremely memorable bosses, best in gaming
- Memorable boss fights especially if you SOLO them, strongly recommend
- Multiple classes available: paladin, barbarian, mage, rogue etc, are all viable
- Good selection of weapons and spells
- Weapons look realistic and are cool to use
- Easy mode option with summoning(better experience SOLO tho)
- Best levels/most memorable levels in gaming: Undead Burg + Cathedral, Anor Londo + Archives
- Good story if you dig for it or check youtube. Very cool lore characters in Dark Souls 1 like Gwyn and Artorias
- Best level inter-connectivity, example: FireLink Shrine connected to Cathedral -> can be seen in first 6 hours of the game
- Cool and memorable songs and themes, especially FireLink Shrine theme
- Great expansion(Artorias of the Abyss) with great bosses that are better than Dark Souls 2 bosses and are close to the bosses in Dark Souls 3.
- Graphics are almost decent in all levels, more in the next section

[b]Negatives:[/b]

- Graphics are decent in almost all the levels that are outside/above ground. The underground levels sadly in 2023 they look outdated, like the insides of a dumpster and these underground levels are very annoying the first time going in
- Some horrible underground levels that are hated by the whole souls community: Depths (a lot of kaka on the walls + rats) + Blight town (permanent poison + toxic enemies make it a nightmare), Lost Izalith (permanent lava) + Tomb of the Giants (no light, monsters that can stun lock and kill you)
- 'Narrow paths' BOSS - a lot of levels have a narrow path where you need to fight dragons, knights or ghosts and a wrong step means you fall to your death. The level beats you, the extremely narrow path beats you. This was removed in Dark Souls 3 but its still alive and well in Dark Souls 1
- 'Invisible paths' BOSS - Crystal caves, you need to reach a boss in a cave of narrow paths that are invisible, the invisible paths will kill you a lot.
- Some levels feel unfinished from an idea and monster placement + boss design perspective -> Lost Izalith, end game


 [b]Despite all it's flaws stated above the positives outweigh the negatives by a lot. This game is a MUST play for any RPG fan(DS3 too) and especially this is a MUST play for a newer 'Souls' player(play with summons the first time when you get stuck, the game can get unfair sometimes)[/b]

if somehow i could log my hours from playing this game on my xbox 360 over a decade ago, i would have several thousands of more hours in this game, and yet it would still not be the soulslike i have spent the most time in to my knowledge. 
of all the dark souls trilogy, this is the most tame and most easy in my opinion. yes, it can be daunting at first, but i find that parrying in this game is the easiest, the magic in this game is the most powerful, and the amount of weapons that can just shatter enemies to bits and pieces is rather high. i think this is the only dark souls game that the player could one shot every boss in the original version because of the ability to stack damage so much and enemies not having that much health. 
speaking of the original game, that game had so many glitches that could be exploited with such glitches enabling one shot runs. one of my favorite series of videos that a youtuber did was a series where they one shot bosses, and they utilized the frame perfect weapon moveset swap glitch to deal crazy damage to bosses. additionally, back in the day, players could gain a bunch of souls easily because of the confirmation box duplication glitch with boss souls. 
returning to the modern day of this version of the game, there are still problematic glitches in the game like stored rolls messing up landings and toggle escapes along with chain backstabs can stil ruin pvp. 
however, some glitches i find to be welcome improvements in making the game even more homely, like the new version of the duplication glitch. the new duplication glitch that works off of using stacks of items and overriding the amount of an item you have with another stack of an item is rather reminiscent of the old old duplication glitch that used an infinite item to use an item over and over again, tick by tick, in that the amount of souls the player gets is rather high and quick. 
rambling about glitches aside, i think that this game is always going to be great. the only issue i have is the lack of mods for this particular game as well as the second, which i hope each will have more in the future.

[h1] A Resurrected Classic[/h1]

[h3] Introduction: [/h3]
Dark Souls Remastered â€“ because who doesn't want to die repeatedly in high definition? Get ready to laugh, cry, and hurl your controller across the room as this remastered edition brings back all the joyous frustration of the original, now with better graphics for you to admire while your character gets obliterated.

[h3] Gameplay [/h3]
The gameplay is as challenging as ever â€“  Remember that time you thought you were getting the hang of it? Yeah, forget about that. They've rearranged enemies just to mess with you. You'll find yourself in uncharted territory, questioning your life choices.  Dark Souls Remastered retains the challenging and rewarding gameplay that has become a hallmark of the series. Combat remains as precise and methodical as ever, demanding mastery of each encounter. The interconnected world design seamlessly invites exploration, and the subtle changes in enemy placement keep even veterans on their toes.

[h3] Sounds and Atmoshpere [/h3]
The haunting melodies and atmospheric sounds remain untouched, providing the perfect background music for your existential crisis. It's like a horror movie, but you're the star, and the monsters are your self-esteem crumbling.  There is only a few places in the game that have background track, each one makes the atmosphere of the game interesting.  The remastered edition maintains the immersive audio experience, further enhancing the game's ability to draw players into its dark and foreboding universe.

[h3] Story [/h3]
The story of the game is vague.  It is made that way with intention making players fill in the gaps and create their own story in a way.  
In the twisted tapestry of Dark Souls Remastered's narrative, players are thrust into the enigmatic land of Lordran, a world steeped in mystery and despair. The story unfolds like an ancient tome, with fragments of lore scattered throughout the decaying landscapes and cryptic characters. As an Undead, cursed to roam this desolate realm, players navigate the interconnected realms, encountering grotesque creatures and formidable bosses. The narrative is a cryptic dance between light and dark, and each discovery adds a layer to the overarching mystery of the fading flame. Unraveling the lore is akin to deciphering an intricate riddle, with moments of profound revelation punctuating the relentless struggle for survival. Dark Souls Remastered invites players to delve deep into a narrative abyss, where the line between hero and villain blurs, and the weight of destiny rests heavily on the player's shoulders.

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
Dark Souls Remastered â€“ the game that turns you into a comedian as you laugh in the face of your impending doom. With improved everything, it's the definitive way to rediscover the masochist in you. Just remember, in Lordran, you either die a hero or live long enough to see yourself die a thousand times.

Overall: B
Dark Souls has undeniably changed the video game landscape around it. If you enjoy games, its cultural importance alone makes it worthy of recommendation. Now having played it myself, I see two games. At its best, it offers satisfying combat and exploration which dances the line of tension and relief; at its worst, it is esoteric and tedious. 
	
Stamina-focused and methodical combat is FromSoftwareâ€™s most lasting legacy for good reason. It provides clear, immediate feedback on when the player has over-extended. The combat is not mechanically very deep but gains great depth in its situations which all need slightly different approaches. The flaws of a first game do emerge especially in areas where the game loves to put enemies in tight corridors or on cliffs. Weapons clanking off the walls might be realistic but that makes it all the more frustrating when I cannot simply swing my weapon differently in those areas. 
	
The game also does a poor job explaining core features like how magic works or the importance of equip loads. There are large segments of the game where navigating becomes a chore. While it has a lot of potential that later games undoubtedly build on, the first Dark Souls remains flawed.

Old age should burn and rave at close of day;
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Though wise men at their end know dark is right,
Because their words had forked no lightning they
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Good men, the last wave by, crying how bright
Their frail deeds might have danced in a green bay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

Wild men who caught and sang the sun in flight,
And learn, too late, they grieved it on its way,
Do not go gentle into that good night.

Grave men, near death, who see with blinding sight
Blind eyes could blaze like meteors and be gay,
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

And you, my father, there on the sad height,
Curse, bless, me now with your fierce tears, I pray.
Do not go gentle into that good night.
Rage, rage against the dying of the light.

[h1] Embracing the Abyss in Dark Souls  [/h1]

What can I say about THE game, Dark Souls? This game isn't just a journey; it's an addiction, a unique experience that has repeatedly drawn me back into its hauntingly beautiful and treacherous world.

Sure, it's not without its quirks - there are some glitches here and there. But honestly, that's fine by me. These minor imperfections hardly detract from the overall brilliance of the game. In fact, in a way, they add to its charm, reminding players that perfection isn't the goal - perseverance is.

Dark Souls is more than just a game; it's a test of will, a trial by fire (and occasionally by some pretty terrifying dragons). It will humble you, make you stumble, and push you to your limits. But therein lies its beauty. It teaches resilience, strategy, and patience. Every defeat is a lesson, every victory a triumph worth celebrating.

I've journeyed through Lordran on multiple platforms - from the PS3 to the PS4, and now on Steam. Each playthrough brings new challenges, discoveries, and a deeper appreciation for its intricate design and storytelling. Chasing achievements on Steam has given me a fresh perspective and new goals to strive for.

In conclusion, what can I say? I am addicted to this masterpiece. Dark Souls isn't just a game to me; it's a testament to the art of gaming, a reminder of how engaging and immersive a video game can be. If you're ready to embrace its challenge, Dark Souls will offer you an unforgettable adventure that stays with you long after you've put down the controller.

After finishing the game here are my thoughts

It feels inherently simpler than it's successor(s) which is nice, but there's still a lot of room for experimentation 
The atmosphere is very good, each level feels very unique 
The Metroidvania style level design is probably the best part 
on the other hand late game bosses are a drop in quality, aside from [spoiler] gwyn lord of cinder and the dlc artorias [/spoiler]
Some aspects of the game could be more thoroughly explained or woven into the tutorial of the game instead of being behind dialogue that must be exhausted from npcs  

Overall 8/10 would smash my desk again

clunky but not terrible
Dark Souls stands as a testament to the marriage of brutal difficulty and masterful game design, creating an unparalleled experience that has left an indelible mark on the world of gaming.

This game as a whole has taught me that, with enough effort, anything is possible.  This game has made me feel all kinds of emotions while playing.

The entire dark souls trilogy is incredibly well written and the worldbuilding is incredible.  From Software is a company that I would poor my entire life savings into. This is a company that LOVES the games they create and it is very obvious.

The world in Dark Souls 1 is entirely interconnected (up until Anor Londo) and, even though this is a third person game, makes you feel so immersed into the game.  There were times during boss fights where I actually jumped and made grunts of pain from being hit or jumping/dodging away from an enemies attack.

This game has taught me valuable lessons that another person simply couldn't ever teach me and allows me to escape reality for a few hours.

If you're looking to get into this game, do it.  Just go in knowing you're going to fail and lose, just like in real life, this game does not hold your hand and forces you to think for yourself and navigate a world without a tutorial (or atleast, without a given tutorial level) and the way the game starts in the Northern Undead Asylum is done perfectly: albeit, a little frustrating for new players of souls-like games.

10/10 - my addiction, my cure

lol ugh

I do not understand how people can call this game a masterpiece, not when after reaching Anor Londo the game take a serious dive both in quality and enjoyment, I would recommend DS2, 3 or Bloodborne over this steaming pile of dog shit any day.

after what is arguably one of the most iconic boss fights in gaming this game seemingly goes from a 9/10 to 3/10 in the blink of an eye, it's almost shocking how people will say that you shouldn't bother with DS2 because it has cheap gotcha kills and bad level design only to suggest you should play DS1, in my experience DS1 is endlessly more clunky and frustrating and I spent near enough 50 hours in 2 and only ran into to like two or three instances in which the way the game was designed actually frustrated, whereas with this game, every single level leading up to one of the big 4 at the end of the game was either actively trying to piss you off while padding out run time, or, had a boss that made you want to pitch your controller at a wall.

I cannot recommend this game to anyone, the clunky controls combined with the below average late game overshadowed & ultimately ruined all the fun I did have prior to finishing up Anor Londo and I cannot for the life of me understand how it is people are willing to overlook how bad the last third of this game is, but, will endlessly rag on DS2 for stuff like "bad hitboxes and annoying enemies" as if DS1 doesn't have the exact same issue's.

generally I can push through quite a bit of bs and beat a game before coming to any concrete conclusions about it but not this one, I understand that in 2011 this would have been THE rpg to play and that there wasn't anything else like it but, guess what, it isn't 2011 anymore and I genuinely believe this game needs serious critical reevaluation or at least hold it to the same standards and criticisms as other games not just in the series but in the genre.
between a remaster that really hasn't remastered anything of note, frame drops on modern hardware when there is no good reason for there to be any and an end game that'll leave you wanting to pull your hair out, I'd say this game needs a remake more than upgrading some textures and ignoring all the bugs/exploits that as I understand it have been in the game since its launch...

if you do play it, god forbid you criticise the end game on the subreddit, and don't you dare compare it to either of the 2 other games in the series, I had the displeasure of saying the other games' worlds kept me engaged through the rougher parts of them and the amount of backhanded "advice" and talking down to I'd received was both hilarious & frustrating.

I so desperately wanted to understand why it is people talk so highly about Dark Souls 1 and just as I was beginning to I found myself being repelled by the game, rather than coming away from the game loving it I've just been disappointed time and time again honestly.
out of all the videos and written reviews I've seen they all gloss over lost izalith, tomb of giants and the dukes archive as if they don't exist and most of these reviewers have absolutely ragged on other games for design choices that pale in comparison to what goes on in these areas but proudly hold DS1 up as a masterpiece even though there is enough here that is wrong, at least in my mind, that it doesn't deserve that level of praise, it is good, some parts of it is great but this game is so deeply flawed from my experience.

I may actually finish the game some time in the future and if I do and my opinion changes I'll update the review but as of right now, it gets a negative rating, I really wish had a third rating option (like so many other people have said before) because somewhere between a positive and negative review is where this game lands for me.

Just 100%'d the game, and it was really good! The first half of the game is simply spectacular. The level design was near impeccable and most of the bosses felt fun and fair! Certain moments feel truly incredible 

The second half of the game has, some problems. If you've done any of your research, most people would probably agree. Since I'm writing this without spoilers, I can't give specific examples, but here are some of the problems:

-Worsened Level Design
People believe this could be due to pressure from Bandai, but all of the levels feel so much worse than the first half. Along with less shortcuts and or longer boss runs (the latter not necessarily being a bad thing), the designs are much more basic. For example, the second area most players experience has so many buildings, nooks and crannies to explore, whereas the later areas have very straight walkways, which either lead to the way forward or a chest. One of the areas had quite interesting level design, but it's gimmick/s made it easy to hate.

-Underwhelming/Aggravating bosses
The bosses in the first half aren't nearly as grand as some of the later entries in the series. However, they felt about right considering their place in the world. The second half of the game requires you to fight some, lore-wise, much stronger bosses, but there are a lot of problems. There are certain bosses I actually like in the second half of the game, but one of them could be considered the worst boss of the series, heavily relying on RNG. The rest feel underwhelming, but can also be extremely punishing, to a point I would also consider to be unfair.

There are some things I like about the second half. The build variety really opens up around this part of the game, including the boss weapons. Also, I really like the concepts for the areas, They're all very different from each other and the rest of the game.

The DLC, which can only be accessed during the second half and is often played at the end of a player's journey, is very good. The level design was an improvement from the second half, but I still preferred the original sections. The bosses however, are great! Each of them were enjoyable, fair and provided a good challenge. The clunky-ness of Dark Souls 1 definitely affected how cool these bosses are compared to the newer games, but nonetheless they were very fun. Also, since it's included in this version of the game, you might as well play it!

I'd 100% recommend playing this game, though. Even with a mid tier second half, Dark Souls 1 is definitely up there in my favourite games of all time! The remaster is slightly expensive, so I'd probably wait for a discount, but if you have the money, go for it!

Awesome game, really worth trying. I loved the experience of going in blind, but if you don't have the chance to do that, it doesn't really matter its awesome anyway!

This game made me cry and also scream in joy best gaming experience I have ever had so far.

As someone who played elden ring: this game is more challenging in some aspects, like a lack or early game fast travel, and the change in style of attacking an enemy, but these changes give you patience and an appreciation for the effort put into the games. If you hate running backwards and forwards then maybe this isn't your game but trust me you'll get used to it. Some of the bosses are pretty easy actually and I beat first or second try, but some (capra demon, basilisk, dogs) can be really annoying sometimes. Idk maybe I just have a skill issue. I don't usually write blocks of text like this so sorry ig but for the 3 people who are still thinking about buying ds and could be bothered to read, hope this helps!

[h1][b]Dark Souls: Remastered[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 8/10 - Great[/b]

[b]Dark souls: Remastered[/b] is a [b]Great[/b] game with an amazing atmosphere, a stellar soundtrack and absolutely masterful world design. The way the game world is interconnected is incredibly refreshing and often surprising. Many locations are stunning and offer great visuals. On top of that the combat is, beside a bit of jank, really fun and great. Most bosses are decent but a few are simply amazing and there are only a few bad ones, most of which are in a single area of the game.

Overall an incredible experience with a super satisfying gameplay loop and world. All of this is tied together by some of the most interesting lore in all of gaming.

Elden Ring was my first souls game and after falling in love with it I decided to go and play every single souls I could get my PC hands on starting with Dark Souls and my god; I understand what people are on about now when they say FromSoft is a master at what they do. Even now, soooo many years after release and remaster this game is amazing. Obviously not as perfect graphically or mechanically but it is still a fantastic game and I loved playing every second of it. Currently halfway through my second run and working on getting Plat for the game. Definitely one I recommend if you enjoy souls and have not played this series. Fun characters, interesting builds, unique bosses/mobs and a well thought out DLC at end game. Looking forward to playing the next one in the series!

Perhaps one of the most overrated games of all time. While the game is probably objectively great, playing it is an absolute bore and people act like it's greater than it really is. The game's design is questionable at best, mid story, meh visuals for their time and lore that feels like it's trying too hard to be deep and cool and it comes off as edgy and not interesting in the slightest. Because yeah having to read 20,000 scrolls and read through the lines of one speck of dirt is totally great storytelling. If you want good environmental storytelling, check out Metroid, that's a series that's really good with it. Dark Souls however is nowhere near that. So I suppose like I said, this game objectively may be good, but it's nowhere near conversation for the best game ever and anyone who says it is has to be either high on copium or has spent so much time wasting their life on this game that they want to justify their playtime by claiming it's a masterpiece. I'd avoid this one unless you really like boring medieval fantasy games and also love getting your balls crushed over and over.

The world design of this game is like nothing I've ever experienced. I played DS3 before this and the fact that I couldn't warp to other bonfires made me not wanna play for a while because it was annoying. However, after a few hours of playing I started to appreciate it. The excitement of finding the safety of bonfires and cool ass shortcuts is so much more relieving than any other souls game I've played. I never thought I'd enjoy this game so much but yea this world is so so so so fun to explore, like seriously, I love the way they designed the world. Also, this series as a whole is a masterpiece. I think this is the most fun in gaming I've ever had in my life. Praise the sun!

Would recommend, dont expect amazing graphics or amazing gameplay, it is after all a remaster of a decade old game, i played this game to see where Elden Ring got its inspiration, and if you're interested then definitely do so. I love the interconnected world and all the different areas to explore, the bosses arent incredibly hard, in fact, i would go as far as to say that this is one of the easiest soulsgames ive played. I love the boss and enemy variety, while i do love ER's huge open world, most bosses are really just copy pasted.  This isnt a critique of elden ring though. While there is one infamous boss that appears 3 times with a different color palette, there arent any other bosses like that. theres also 3 bosses that appear as regular enemies later in the game(but that area has already been criticized enough). Every boss except for those i mentioned are very unique, while for a certain boss, that isnt a good thing, usually it is. But enough about the bosses. The enemy variety is so good, theres always something new to see in areas, you dont just fight the same enemies with different clothing or weapon. In my book, if you master making a game that has enemy variety, fun gameplay, good bosses and an interesting world to explore that doesnt tell you EXACTLY where to go at all times and lets you get lost in its world, then its definitely worth it
everything souls.

A pretty good (yet janky) game in it's own right. Though, I'll go against the brunt of the community surrounding this game and insist that it would benefit heavily from difficulty options. The worldbuilding, characters, boss fights, and hidden lore all around are incredibly well crafted and mysterious, but that can all be sometimes marred by the combination of difficulty and how janky the game can be at times. Many, many deaths I experienced in the game seemed to me to be less of skill issues and more because the game janked me into my death.

Fortunately that didn't stop me from enjoying the time I did put into the game (so far) and enjoy wandering around the world of Lordran and discovering it's mysteries. The game would only be more popular if it was more accessible and it's community didn't attempt to gatekeep every game made by FromSoft as if nobody could ever actually enjoy themselves or feel accomplished beating a game if it's easier.

For those who don't know, this game won 'Ultimate Game Of All Time' in 2021 by the Golden Joystick Awards, which is basically the gaming oscar, and I think it was pretty deserved.
This game has several problems. Although the remastered edition updates the graphics and brings a lot of QOL improvements, this game still feels a little 2011 at its core, with its controllers and enemy AI being a little clunky, but it still is amazing. It has a lot of bad and cheap stuff like Capra Demon and Bed of Chaos, but overall, it's an excellent game, that went against the standards and managed to succeed exactly because of that.
Overall, the experience I had on this game across PS3, Switch and on PC was one my best gaming experiences ever, and I'll never forget the amazing feeling of getting the platinum trophy on this game(or the 100% achievement on steam)

The other Dark Souls games are so much better with maintaining consistency in terms of level and boss design, so just play those instead. It really isn't worth the constant unfair/cheap deaths you experience in this game.

Firstly no the game isn't that difficult and if you do come across something you can't do you can always summon other players for help since despite what others may say there's nothing wrong in doing doing so. The first half of the game is spectacular with great areas and bosses while the second half of the game is a complete mess that got rushed, leaving the areas and bosses boring or infuriating with probably 4 bosses at most i'd consider good. The "Artorias of the Abyss" DLC comes with the remaster and its really good with some of the games best and hardest bosses. So overall despite the awful second half i'd say the game is at least worth trying out to experience Dark Souls. I fully believe Dark Souls will go down in history with greats like "Ocarina of Time" and "Chrono Trigger" and honestly i'd say Dark Souls has changed my life.

It feels really dated coming from Elden Ring. It sounds stupid, of course, it is an old game. But it felt very clunky and unenjoyable. In particular, this game is not suited to playing once a week for an hour or two because of the lack of a map. As much as people praise the level design, its way too easy to feel as though you don't have any idea what your next objective should be when you take breaks or your play sessions are not that long. 

Your money is likely better spent on a newer FromSoft game, such as Elden Ring (phenomenal - easily my goty for 2022) or Sekiro (playing through right now and is pretty baller so far).

Note - I have closer to 12 hours played on this game, Steam didn't track them while I was offline on plane flights.

It's slower, it's clunky, and it's darker, but the same mechanics apply in Elden Ring as in this game.

The Prepare to Die Edition is said to be superior, but since it isn't available anymore, DSR is your best bet.

I really love this game. I think I can really put thought into words after playing it's sequel Dark Souls 3 and compare them. I think Dark Souls 1 is such a magical experience like you the world is and feels magical which I don't think Dark Souls 3 can replicate. After playing Dark Souls 3 (which was a great game) I feel like I a much greater feeling for this game, I almost feel nostalgic for it despite only first playing it 7 months ago. I think Dark Souls 3 is a better game but in Dark Souls 1 the bosses feel more unique and the world just has a magical feeling to it which Dark Souls 3 lacks (Ik that's on purpose). In summary I feel at home when I play Dark Souls 1, like it's a game I can play and just get lost in for a little bit. Truly a great game.

Oh boy what an crazy adventure. I played Dark Souls so much back in the day on ps3 and was happy to pick up the remastered version here on PC. It runs smoothly and plays pretty well. If you're a souls fan then the remastered version delivers exactly what you'd expect. Dark Souls but again, this time remastered with a fresh coat of polish. 

For those who haven't played Dark Souls, I employ anyone who is a fan of any kind of action adventure rpgs, or any of the other Souls games, to pick up Dark Souls Remastered. Buts it's super difficult, right??? Nah, the souls games difficulty has honestly been meme'd far into outer space. Yes the game is more difficult then most action adventure rpgs but it's not nearly as impossible as some like to play it off as. So don't let that scare you away. The game can just demand a bit of actual learning and ingenuity. There are so many different ways to tackle problems, enemies and bosses in this game. Various weapons that deal different types of damage, sorceries, pyromancies, miracles, etc. If one thing doesn't work then try another. All in all I highly recommend Dark Souls Remastered. Whether you're a Souls veteran and you've somehow skipped this one or a newcomer to the series, the game offers a challenging and rewarding experience. It really does feel amazing to finally get that last hit in on a boss that may have been giving you trouble. Remember to never give up and just keep trying. You got infinite lives anyways.

P.S. My only gripe with the first Dark Souls in general is still the Bed of Chaos. That boss just isn't fun to fight at all. It's not a difficult fight, it's just very very annoying. A single blemish on what otherwise has become one of my favorite games.
