This game was amazing. Elden Ring was my introduction to Souls-like games, and I liked that so much that I decided to come back and try Dark Souls. Despite being a much older game, it was still a great, polished game. The world design is iconic. The way it is so big but so beautifully compact and interconnected is a work of art. It starts off being so overwhelming, and then as you get familiar with the layout you can traverse the map so quickly. The exploration is extremely satisfying. The combat feels good. It was a bit tough going from the jumping of Elden Ring back to the more 2-dimensional combat, but it still feels good - challenging but fair.

Having only played through it once, build variety is hard to assess. I know that tanky melee builds work well, and that sorcery builds can be very strong as well. It doesn't seem like dexterity, status effects, archery, and some of those other builds are quite as viable as they are in elden ring, but maybe i just need to get more familiar with them.

One other down side is the inflexibility. There isn't any way to respec your character, so you're a bit locked in by your early game build choices. That's even true when you go into New Game +. It would be cool to be able to respec and play the game differently on subsequent plays without starting from scratch, but this is a minor complaint.

All told, this game is an iconic classic, and I would highly recommend to anyone. It's not as hard as people make it out to be. If you level up and use good weapons, you can get through much of the game without excessive or unreasonable challenge.

The game has not aged well. If Elden Ring was your first From Software game and you want to see 'where it all began', I would recommend playing it. But only then. 

This is my first ever review, but since everyone seems to criticize the remastered version for being an overpriced patch and I just wanted to know if the game is a good choice for newcomers, I wanted to share my toughts on the game as someone who has no nostalgia connected to it. 

I have never played a Dark Souls game before (Elden Ring was my introduction) and never thought I ever will (too hard, too frustrating), but since Elden Ring is my favourite gaming experience since The Witcher 3 and Red Dead Redemption 2, I thought I finally had to give it a try (discount...). And although Elden Ring pulled my in right from the start, Dark Souls 1 never really reached me. The mechanics, erratic questlines, weird npcs and the interconnected world - it is all there, but (for me) Elden Ring is just the way superior experience. In every aspect.

Even though I - of course - did not expect it to be as good as ER, I still was disappointed. I don't really know why I never really enjoyed the game, but one reason is that there is almost never any music, which in ER greatly enhanced the atmosphere for me. In Dark Souls 1 the only things you hear are your own too loud footsteps and the monsters/fight sounds. That can be immersive in tight dark corridors - but it never was for me. The parts I liked the most were the very first area (dark clouds, a fallen castle, thunder rumbling in the background: excellent), and the very last area (mostly because of the visuals). Here the game really shines.

Speaking of visuals: usually, I do not care much about graphics, especially if it is a game from 2011, but I have to say, except from the lighting in some areas: this game does not look good, especially the late game areas reminded me of Gothic 1, a (great) game from 2001, that was already graphically outdated when it was released. In DS1 many areas are pretty big, but also feel pretty empty. I don't want to spoil anything, but often they are just bland: too huge (but of course smaller than in ER) to really fill them, so you have some items and some enemies here and there and that's it. I never was fully intrigued by this world and was never motivated to think about the story of this decaying land as I was in Elden Ring, where every part of the world seems to breathe story and atmosphere. The same thing is said about Dark Souls 1, but at least I did not have this impression.

My biggest concern before playing was the difficulty. After playing Elden Ring (and Sekiro) the game is pretty manageable. The bosses almost move in slow-mo compared to the two and should not give you too much trouble, if you have played ER or Sekiro. But even here, the game could not convince me. While ER felt like a fair and rewarding challenge, the gameplay in DS1 often just annoyed me due to just annoying design choices. In one notorious area for example 1 hit (arrow) of a certain enemy type is enough to change your status into toxic - at the beginning of the area. Have fun to explore and fight! The said enemies don't respawn and you can use an item against it (if you know about it), but it is still a cheap way to artificially increase a difficulty that is not challenging but often simply annoying. Another example: you can get a curse that halves your HP, even after you died - good luck finding a cure. Not to speak of one of the most annoying boss fights in video game history. Many will say that this is the typical Dark Souls experience and it certainly is. But ER never annoyed me this way, while still being an actual challenge (learn movesets) and providing a breathing and mysterious world.
 
Just a noob perspective. I only finished it once and I do not know if I will ever play it again. So why still the thumbs up? Because I absolutely love Elden Ring and can acknowledge its promising beginning in DS1.

This is one of a few games that I come back to every now and then. If you're a fan of the series, you know that there's plenty of games in this vein that might scratch the itch better. They play faster or more agressively. They executed different design ideas, or have an interesting setting. This game popularized the subgenre started by it's predecessor, Demon's Souls, which remains a Sony exclusive to this day. Dark Souls fleshes out more of the ideas set forth in the previous game and gives you a well-crafted, seamless world where you can traverse beautiful castle landscapes, to dark, dreary catacombs, to oceans of lava and fire, and everything in between.

People say it's hard, and it's not. The game gives you more than enough tools to complete it. The fun is in sticking to it and seeing how far you progress.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

This was my very first Souls title that I've ever experienced. And boy howdy, do I have a lot to say about it.

I come from the land of easy-to-play baby games that don't challenge you very much if at all. I had zero interest in playing anything even remotely difficult, so when this one was suggested to me, as a streamer, I could not have been less excited about it. But after a little convincing, I decided to take up the mantle.

After advancing past the "first" boss and second boss with some 50+ deaths, I had had maybe no less than two or three emotional breakdowns. Dark Souls has touched me in a way no other game has - in that it not only challenged me, but it completely obliterated my fragile, inflated ego. It magnified my skill issues and forced me to swallow the cold, bitter truth - I needed to get good. Not just at the game, but being able to accept that I sucked SO HARD at something. I contemplated throwing my controller down and giving up a handful of times, but something just kept on pulling me back. I didn't want to admit defeat.

After keeping at it and figuring out some of the basic game mechanics, such as dodge rolling and blocking, etc, I slowly started to not only not mind the endless amounts of deaths I would be punished with, but I was actually *enjoying* it. I wanted to explore every nook and cranny, find every secret, learn about the enemies, the lore, the NPC's. The world is beautiful, the characters are memorable, and the combat, while difficult, is so satisfying when you do get the hang of it.

While Dark Souls has given me many rage-inducing screams of frustration and agony, it has also given me many shouts of victory and laughing fits over the stupid ways I've died or watched enemies fall off cliffs. But above all else, it has given me the gift of humility, something no other game has. It taught me to be patient, observant, and persevere.

A game I once wanted to stay as far away from me as possible now sits in my library as one of my most favorite titles of all time. And I look forward to playing the other games in the series as well! Thank you for helping me grow, FromSoftware. Not just as a gamer, but as a person, too.

If you've already played Elden Ring, DS3 or Sekiro, it will take you some time getting used to the controls and much slower pace of this game; but once accustomed, the difficulty will be like a joke in comparison.

The jump button is by default the same button as sprinting, and I found out literally while typing this review that I can rebind it. So that's a me problem, so here's just a PSA for anyone else thinking it's annoying to accidentally jump face first into an axe when you're trying to dodge it.

While locked onto enemies you only have 4 dimensional rolling; meaning no diagonal dodges. This will cause you to accidentally roll directly into the enemies if your joystick was slightly angled more up than left/right. This also makes fighting enemies on a bridge specifically awkward, as you can't slightly roll left or right by going diagonally forward or backwards.
You're also unable to sprint while locked on. I don't think I need to tell you why this is frustrating for somebody that is used to more fast paced souls-likes, so you better get comfortable switching between locking on and unlocking from enemies depending on the situation. I'd honestly recommend not locking on bosses at all until the exact moment you're about to attack.

Enemies have pretty weak tracking, so by simply side strafing or running behind them, will cause them to miss the majority of attacks. Unfortunately, you have the same issue. Gonna charge up a strong attack with an ultra greatsword? Better hope they don't move one frame to the side.

A couple of bosses has sadly wasted potential and a few copy-pastes here and there. One late game area in particular feels very rushed. Controls are a bit janky with frustratingly slow animations, (but this game was made before even vine, so not the same ADHD tiktok attention span brain rot back then, so gets a slight pass on this one.)
Bosses are too easy imo, leaving me pretty underwhelmed after first trying most of them. I had way more difficulties with the titanite demon in the catacombs hallway than any of the bosses in the entire game combined.

So why am I recommending it? Because I love DS3. To be fair, most of my complaints are from having played the later games that are objectively more hardcore and fast paced, so I'm trying to see this game for what it was when it first came out.

There's a lot of visually stunning areas in this game, interesting NPC's and a fascinatingly interconnected world. For a game without fast travel for the most part, I really thought I'd be missing it way more. But it just works really well. Every time you find a shortcut you'll be amazed by how it connects and loops around the game world.
Sure, it can be annoying sometimes having to backtrack a lot if you want to go back and check something, and sometimes it would discourage me from going back up to pick up an item I missed, but it's not a major issue overall. I personally love running around and getting familiar with the areas. (except that one town)

DS3 is one of my favorite games ever, and I love discovering interesting connections with this game. So if anything, playing this game has enhanced my love and appreciation of DS3 even more. And that fact alone makes this game worth playing, even in 2024.

Ok... it's not easy to talk about DS. My first souls-like. It absorbed my soul. In a single word: Legendary.
Yes

Legend.

I played it for the epic combat but fell in love with the lore and world-building as well.

The lore is difficult to piece together because you are basically an archaeologist studying a nearly dead world thousands of years after events have taken place. 

Also you can't really get it all in one play-thru. Things are much more tragic than they seem on the surface.

Fun game controls are a little bit rough but hey its an older game and it laid the groundwork out for the future souls titles. bosses while decently easy are fun and creative (besides bed of chaos) overall fun experience and would recommend.

Yes I've not played the whole game as you can see by my hour count, but I just cannot continue, I'm getting so annoyed playing this, because enemies are all a pain in the ass and just not enough interesting to make me willing to defeat them, and bosses are just so easy that there is no reward in defeating them. Overall, the game is boring and clunky in it's gameplay. YES it is gorgeous artistically, but if gameplay sucks, I think I'll just watch a youtube walkthrough of it skipping the boring parts, saving hours of my life that can be dedicated to other games.
And to those who say "yeah it's an old game of course the commands and mechanics are worse than all the games that came after this" I'm sorry but games like the original Ratchet and Clank trilogy are 10 years older than this, and still far better in every aspect gameplay-wise. I cannot just forgive this game because it's old.

Edit: just watched the entire game on youtube, I have to say there are some great moments, and this game is artistically a masterpiece. Too bad I was unlucky and my experience was just terrible. If you have to play this, play it with a guide, it will tell you where to go since the game is non linear, it will speed things up and make this game not the burden that I experienced it to be.

This is the Remastered edition of the First instalment of the Dark Souls franchise

This game's audio and visuals contribute to a great presentation of a dark, horrific and gloomy atmosphere.  Combine that with incredible, seamless level design and you're in for quite the immersive dark fantasy 3rd person action experience. 

It's not an open world fantasy like Skyrim, you're just fighting all the time, enduring the sinister challenges that await you with nothing but your grit, a few healing items here and there, an arsenal of weapons for you to choose from.

I only swung greatswords and polearms around but the weight of their attacks are nice. Enemies do a lot of damage including random non-boss monsters so getting your head around this is pretty much the only hurdle to overcome. Once you're over it and like the gameplay enough, you're in for a treat.

There's also replayability in the form of new game plus or for speedrunning if you wish to get into that sort of thing.

I know no one reads these, but with my personal playthough, I'd say it's a game worth playing, but play it with the knowledge that it's not perfect. I only really liked about 5 out of the 20 or so bosses. I think the DLC bit is absolutely incredible and only really has one boss that's less than great, but the rest of the game just feels weird. I wouldn't say it feels unfinished towards the end, but bosses like Bed of Chaos and Gravelord Nito just don't feel right to me. There's always one small mistake with most bosses, like weird hitboxes, enemies in the boss room, and overall if this is your first souls game, I'd suggest starting with Dark Souls III or Elden Ring. This game just feels clunky and janky a lot, and a lot of basic things could be fixed with things like mods, but overall I think it's worthwhile to play. It's both a good and a bad game in my opinion.

I finally jumped on the Dark Souls, and man, have I been missing out! You know how everyone talks about how insanely hard it is? Well, they weren't lying, but it's so much more than that.

I'm at level 40, tackling Sen's Fortress, and I can't believe how awesome this game is. The difficulty is real, but it's not just about dying over and over. It's about the thrill of making progress, the surprises around every corner, and the sweet taste of victory when you finally beat a tough part.

The level design is like nothing I've ever seen. Everything connects seamlessly, and there are secrets everywhere. No map? At first, I was like, "What the heck?" But now, it's one of the coolest things. Getting lost is part of the fun, and finding a bonfire feels like discovering a hidden treasure.

I get why people rave about Dark Souls now. The world is crazy interconnected, and it all just clicks. Different enemies keep you on your toes, forcing you to mix up your strategies.

Anyway, stop what you're doing and play this game. Seriously. It's a wild ride, and I'm kicking myself for not playing it sooner. It's easily one of the best games ever.

I've just finished this game and I would like to tell people my thoughts about it.

Dark souls I is unique, it offers an experience I have rarely seen elsewhere. I absolutely recommend to NOT watch playthrough as a big part of the experience comes from discovery. It doesn't have incredible graphics but certainly doesn't need to. If you're searching a game with good interconnected level-design with a very addictive fighting system and unique mechanics you are looking for the good game. I would recommend playing through this game at least twice be cause you WILL miss a lot on your first playthrough.

If it is the difficulty stopping you then don't fear. This game is hard, you will lose sanity sometimes (this game is one of the few to make me lose my mental, even if I'm usually very calm) but the key is perseverance. The game sometimes feels unfare and just here to annoy you, but actually looking back I liked the difficulty. It would not be the same game if it was not so hard. Sure you find new armors to wear, weapons to wield and level up, but in reality you only really forge your experience, knowledge and skills. Everything seems hard until you memorize, react, dodge, attack at the right moment against this one boss that was once an incredible wall. Learn from yourself (not guide as they kind of ruin the experience).

If this comment happens to convice you to buy the game then have a good time with it, and, most importantly, pray you don't go Hollow !

EDIT: This game is an actual masterpiece. As in a work of art through and through! There's no denying how artistically rich this game is and how much it brought to VG as an art form. You can't say you know how to do a video game analysis without doing this one.

To clarify, i will always be appreciative of the dark souls trilogy: it has inspired a genre and led others to polish and refine this style of game further and further to spearhead the genre into an absolutely breathtaking range of games... However, as this was one of the first, its experimentation and introduction of relatively innovative mechanics came with so many issues to compliment the extraordinary, ultimately resulting in an experience that is diluted by tedium in a range i would arguably describe as 20% exceptional, 80% monotonous  

Inherently when experimenting with the first of anything (car, bike, software, hardware) there are very obvious flaws that are highlighted and buffered out in later iterations, understandably though this is the first iteration and is riddled with said problems, the primary issues all result in horrific compromises in pacing, progression and mapflow, making the game feel odd.

The main problems are ultimately due to the ambitious pursuit to make the game heavily based on exploration and self discovery: you aren't taught fundamental mechanics or aims, where to go, what to do, why you're doing it: this is both from a narrative and game-play point of view and this makes first playthrough unpleasant without any external information... the main kicker to this problem is the game is very specifically paced: it expects you to know where to go, what to do, why you're doing it and this is one of the most substantial factors to why this game is horrifically paced... you'll find yourself asking "how was i supposed to know to kill this guy" or "why did i have to do this in that order" "am i the right level for this" as you accidentally stumble into one of the most lategame regions at the start: you'd think this is the "joy" to exploring a harsh world but from a progression standpoint the game STOPS you from playing it if you dont do it exactly how they expect. "you didnt speak to this background character inbetween this fight and this fight, youve ruined the arch" without any indication, "you cant progress until you do this incredibly odd, complicated thing or travel to an incredibly odd location in the background:" later iterations of this formula such as elden ring polish this idea, allowing these exploration things to be entirely optional without compromising your game or pacing, and it also explains what you need to do and why: this game doesn't hold your hand and expects you to follow their exact instructions without any instructions: its vague and poorly executed. If you dont play with an external, third party guide your experience will suck: but in an exploration, adventure game: the very LAST thing you want is a guide... you want to work stuff out for yourself but it feels too essential to not have one due to the unclear pacing of this game

The next issue is repetition: the game-play really can get monotonous and not in a conventional souls-like perspective... fans often quote something in the sense of "the game wants you to learn and study a route/fight to perfection in order to obtain victory" and this can be a fun feature if you are actively being taught from trial and error. But this game has alot of dull segments of backtracking, not learning anything new each experience just suffering the same walk or sequence over and over, this is partially due to relatively poor bonfire placement / map design issues, resulting in large backtracks, but also just some segments really overstaying their welcome 

The engine also feels reminiscent of something like bethesda: where all their games feel kinda clunky, floaty and unresponsive but supposedly people like this feel... idk this is a subjective thing for me but it just feels so rough i cant be the only one.

I'm absolutely sure this game could be some fun to people that have devoted their gaming experiences exclusively to theses titles: with the knowledge of these mechanics it could be great. but not the first playthrough... I barely want to touch a second: the game floods me with an overwhelming feeling of boredom for the most part but the pull to play again and again is due to that other 20%

The world-building, the cinematic experience, music, atmosphere is all exceptional... actually some of the best in any game ive played and these few highlights can make we want to slog through the other 80% : highlights being the sif fight and in dark souls 3 the dancer of boreal valley. it carries the experience and ALMOST makes me want to thumbs up this game... but i honestly cant bring myself to it: the game brings me pain from a "its so unfun to play." i dabble with sometimes excruciatingly difficult games (much harder ones than many souls like) so i dont think its a "skill issue." but more just a complete sense of  disinterest with the generic base mechanics that the added frustration in pacing, progression and exploration make it overall: a game i dont enjoy

my brain likes to remember the positive highlights of a game so i will potentially be drawn back to these games for that 20%... On a huge positive note: games such as remnant, hollow knight, darksiders and many others have been birthed thanks to the existence to these early games: ones that in my subjective opinion have refined these issues with monotony and incoherent progression almost entirely out of them

If anyone tells you this game is good, they're gaslighting you. It's really not.

It's a boring, tedious grind of farming souls, learning moves/enemies and thinking what the author had in mind as there's no explanations anywhere. And while I get that some games are like that, there's no reward. My biggest issue with this game is that it simply wastes time - you make a mistake and die twice in a row? Time waste. Lots of running and every single time you need to get through enemies once again.

The world design is great, but I'd love a story with it, not just crappy fragments here and there. As for "remastered" - textures look like they were "upgraded" by an intern in a closet somewhere for a whooping minute as they simply look shit. Crysis was released 5 years before this and had much better graphics.

I played this as everyone said it's amazing, but I feel highly disappointed. I feel this is a good game for a console player, who never played a good PC game. It's lacking in every area - graphics, story, gameplay and most of all - fun.

Hard but a good hard

The game is difficult!  It once seemed daunting after all these years, now felt like a welcome challenge to get back into. This world brought a waves of nostalgia, reminding me of the countless hours I spent in the "Prepare to Die edition" when I originally played this game on the PS3. The improved graphics and performance, along with the new enemy placements, make a new feel to this game, its more engaging without the old expectations of the former games predictability, making it feel fresh even after all these years. The Dark Souls' design and the satisfaction of victory from overcoming its challenging bosses all started here. This game is so memorable nobody will ever forget "YOU DIED" making it one of my favorites of all time.

You Died (remastered)

I initially played this at the start of 2021 "through means other than Steam," but after seeing this game finally go on sale and after 2 years later of playing other souls games, I decided to buy this and revisit it.

Although sometimes quite jank in feel and gameplay, the first installment of the Dark Souls series holds up in other regards, such as atmosphere, its use of music, voice acting, exploration and overall worldbuilding. 

Most of the story is either shown visually, implied or simply written in the description of an item you pick up. Like the world, the game asks you to seek things out off of your own curiosity, should you have any.

The pacing of player combat is quite slow, but hardly will you ever feel outpaced by enemies, even when using a colossal weapon. 

It's difficult, but fair and encouraging, as well as rewarding, to learn.

Dark Souls to me is not a masterpiece however - some bosses are either buggy or downright tedious, but thankfully I can only really think of two great offenders of this throughout the whole game (Bed of Chaos, Ceaseless Discharge).

I can't speak for PvP, as I have no interest in it in this game nor do I intend on trying it.

If you're willing to get over the somewhat-dated graphics and elementary combat, but interested in the world this game offers, give this a go.
Praise the Sun!

UPDATE 2024-01-04: changed to dislike. Mainly due to the above reason "where to go". I am fed up with constantly Alt-Tabbing to find out where I need to go. The game simply doesn't have a plot. Instead I am supposed to figure out how to find the DLC on my own? That's nonsense. Fuck FromSoft.

10/10 game. I firmly will recommend this game to anyone who is even somewhat interested in trying out this genre. Hell, even people who aren't into it should try this game. Beating it kind of changes your perspective on gaming as a whole.

It was understandable that they were prioritising Elden Ring at first, but it's gone on long enough. Give multiplayer back.

Dark and soulful

In 2011, I walked into a Gamestop in Monterey, CA with my ex-wife and the store employee asked what I was looking for. I expressed that I was tired with how easy most video games had become. She nodded, understanding my plight and asked what games were my favorite. I was eclectic and had a wide range so she assumed I was a hardcore gamer, but what I did not divulge was that I was a dabbler, a poser, a hack who only played other games when World of Warcraft would briefly lose its luster. She walked over to the wall and picked up a game I hadn't heard of before - "Demons Souls". She talked about how difficult it was how the story was a puzzle, every enemy was a boss fight, and the sense of accomplishment I would have after beating a boss. Excitedly, I paid and hurried home to try out this amazing sounding game. I progressed doggedly through the tutorial, got to the nexus, and progressed onto Boletaria where I immediately hated everything about the game. Disappointed, I turned off the PS3 and never returned to Demons Souls, my passion for WoW reignited.

Several years later, some of my coworkers were talking one afternoon, about a new game sweeping the gamer landscape.
"What game are you guys talking about?", I asked.
"Dude, it's called 'Dark Souls'. It's fucking awesome, hard as shit though", they replied.
"Nice, is it on Steam?"
"Yup, it sucks though. It's way better on PS3."
Damn, I thought, I just got rid of mine. I wasn't deterred though, thinking I was a real gamer. I knew with persistence I could overcome jank and bugs. Hell, one of my all time favorite games at this point was Morrowind. As soon as I could, I purchased it, "Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition". That sounded metal, it had to be good. After a brief wait for the download, I was good to go and quickly booted it up. If I could somehow find a way to express the confusion and frustration at trying to figure out the keyboard and mouse controls, what the menus meant, what anything was, I would be a far better storyteller. But all I can say was after ten-ish mintues, I was done. Uninstalled and never to return.

Fast forward 10 years. Life had changed drastically for me. I was several years divorced, I had a few promotions at work, got to do some awesome projects that really tested my professional capabilities, made some mistakes, got fired and was trying to pick up pieces. I had met someone new and special, we moved in together and I was getting my life back on track. One of my newest hobbies was investing random moments into video game lore. Legend of Zelda, Warcraft, Diablo, Metal Gear Solid, Final Fantasy, etc., all the universes of all of my favorite games I had begun taking headlong dives into to divine the game series with the best and most rich stories. This, of course, was primarily accomplished through essay-format videos on YouTube. One day, a video suggestion for the "Dark Souls Remasterd" popped up.
'Ugh', I thought, 'that game sucked'.
But curiosity got the better of me and the sweet soothing voice of Vaatividya began to ooze out of my headphones. The story of Lord Gwyn punctuated with snippets of Dylan Thomas' "Do Not Go Gentle Into That Good Night" immediately had me enraptured. I was sucked in at the depth and complexity of the lore. Every one of Vaati's videos had me enthralled and the crushing feelings of loneliness, death, and desperation were drawn out elegantly. I watched all of them, every single one, multiple times. After several weeks of gushing over the videos, I finally bought the Remaster. And unlike all the other attempts at FromSoftware games, I couldn't stop playing this time.

I love this game. Praise the Sun.

A decent modernisation of the Prepare To Die edition. If you don't know much about dark souls, then get it - but be prepared to die a lot. Unlike many games, skill can exploit the game's potential non-linearity, giving plenty of replayability.
I've got through Prepare To Die a fair few times. This edition (no summons):
* Sorcery/dagger
* Ascension mod - warrior
* Daughters of ash mod
* Ascension mod - sorceror/pyro/light armor
* Dagger only - NG/NG+/NG++
* No death run
* St Jude's Mod
* Fog gate randomizer + item randomizer
* Cestus run
* SL1 no pyro/no magic/no RTSR/melee only
* Short bow only, dex/vit increases only, no items other than estus

MODS WILL GET YOUR ACCOUNT SUSPENDED. So play offline!

A wonderful experience for any gamer, despite the difficulty being famous it wasn't all that brutal. though that maybe obscured since i come from having played bloodborne and demon souls and elden ring, even having played those other three installments before getting into this game, it was still a wonderful experience and was a joy to explore. go into this game with as little information you can, i know that can be hard after its been out for so long but try your best, i did so knowing i would eventually play this game so i went in knowing a couple boss names and location names. I actually felt like i knew a lot about the game but about 3-4 hours into the game i was shocked at how much was here and how wonderful the experience was. 


as for how it holds up against the other souls games.... not fantastic, it left me feeling like demon souls, just not really intrested in playing again right away, compared to bloodborne where i wanted to play more immediately and still play that game very frequently. I do plan on doing a second play through in a couple years but as it is right now there wasnt a lot in the game that left me wanting to do it again, there were maybe 4 bosses, 2 of them being in the dlc portion of the game, that i feel a desire to fight again and the rest id rather not fight them ever again. which is unfortunate however still a good game and would highly reccomend!

p.s. I dont think Bed of Chaos is really that bad, sure hes annoying and confusing but once you know whats going on you kinda just get through it, i thought it would be a big stumbling block in progression purely out of jank, but it was fine hes not even one that im worried about having to face off with again

it really good

This is my 2nd souls game after Elden Ring, and it was pretty enjoyable. Although in my opinion it doesn't come close to Elden Ring, its still a really good game. I liked its simplicity with the only exception being the weapon upgrade system which I found to be unnecessarily complex. The atmosphere of the game is unmatched, just in the character creation screen the music makes you feel like you are about to embark on a mysterious adventure. Even though theres very little music at all, every area in the game feels completely distinct and unique. And like Souls games are, the gameplay is perfect, its been said before and I dont need to explain how they nailed it.

My only issue with the game is that although most of the game is great, the only reason this doesn't get a 100 is because of how annoying and padded out the last third of the game is. *SPOILERS UNTIL NEXT PARAGRAPH* Right after Anor Londo, every boss afterward up until seathe and gwen are all gimmicky and annoying as shit, Nito, Firesage Demon, Bed of Chaos, the entire Duke's Archives level. I used so many walkthrough videos at this part its ridiculous. If they had just cut everything between meeting Gwynevere and fighting Gwyn, it would've been a perfect game.

 I know its not just me because I've heard multiple other people say the same thing. Overall I wouldn't call this game a masterpiece but its definitely a really good game.

The Dark Souls franchise is characterized by creating difficult and challenging games. DS Remastered has several missions, some are optional and others depend on your decisions. It has two endings of the player's choice and a dlc called Artorias of the Abyss which is highly recommended and worth it.
If I had to tell you what I liked and what I didn't, I would start by telling you what I didn't like. At first, you can't teleport between bonfires (which is essential to not waste time going back and forth, especially when the distances are long) but later as you progress in the story you can teleport yourself from one place to another. The good thing is its story, its dark narrative where the world is on the brink of extinction and the characters suffer different tragedies.
Graphically it looks amazing, especially when you get to Anor Londo. Personally, I had a pretty bad time in the Fortress of Sen and Crystal Cave, where you don't know what to do and it's full of traps.
The game has a message of perseverance and improvement, since it invites us to learn from our mistakes and not give up in the face of adversity, thus being a life lesson, I would say, in my opinion, the most valuable.

What I liked:

Interactive level design offers a level of complexity rarely seen in modern gaming. Every shortcut, hidden path, and interconnected area contributes to a cohesive and immersive experience. Exploring Lordran is a puzzle in itself and is quite rewarding.

Now, for what I don't like: The PS3-era jank; the game is quite dated in many areas, feeling clunky and slow, especially since I am coming from playing BB, DS3, and Elden Ring, it feels jarring. Secondly, the bonfire placements; there were many instances where I had to go through long and arduous paths to get to where I want to be. Lastly, the bosses can be a mixed bag; some made my jaw drop, while others almost made me quit the gameâ€”I am looking at you, Bed of Chaos.

All in all, I don't recommend this entry in the series, even though it's the one that gave the series much-deserved attention; it certainly didn't age well.

"Dark Souls" is an iconic action role-playing game that has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry since its release in 2011. Developed by FromSoftware, it's a game renowned for its challenging gameplay, atmospheric world-building, intricate level design, and profound storytelling. Here's a comprehensive review detailing why "Dark Souls" remains a must-play for gamers seeking a uniquely immersive experience.

[h1] Unforgiving Challenge:  [/h1]
"Dark Souls" is notorious for its punishing difficulty. It doesn't hold your hand; instead, it teaches through trial and error. Players face relentless enemies and formidable bosses that demand patience, strategy, and precision in combat. Every encounter is a lesson, forcing players to learn enemy patterns and master combat mechanics to progress. The sense of accomplishment upon overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds is unparalleled.

[h1] Intricate World Design: [/h1]
The game's world, Lordran, is a masterpiece of level design. It's interconnected, sprawling, and intricately woven, offering a sense of exploration and discovery. From the decaying ruins of Undead Burg to the hauntingly beautiful Anor Londo, each area is distinct, with its own lore and challenges. The level design encourages exploration, hiding secrets, shortcuts, and hidden paths that reward observant and daring players.

[h1] Atmospheric & Immersive: [/h1]
"Dark Souls" excels in creating a hauntingly atmospheric world. The dimly lit, desolate landscapes are complemented by a melancholic soundtrack that perfectly encapsulates the game's dark and foreboding ambiance. Environmental storytelling adds depth, with cryptic item descriptions, abandoned structures, and NPC dialogues subtly revealing the game's lore and history.

[h1]  Deep Lore & Storytelling: [/h1]
The game's narrative isnâ€™t spoon-fed to players. Instead, it's cryptic, requiring keen attention to item descriptions, NPC interactions, and environmental cues to piece together the lore. The fragmented storytelling allows for interpretation and speculation, fostering a community of fans dedicated to unraveling the game's mysteries and hidden meanings.

[h1]  Rewarding Character Progression: [/h1]
Character progression in "Dark Souls" is intricate, offering diverse playstyles through various classes, weapons, and magic. The leveling system allows customization, letting players tailor their characters to suit their preferred playstyle. Balancing stats, choosing equipment, and mastering different weapon types add depth to the gameplay, providing a sense of accomplishment as your character grows stronger.

[h1]  Multiplayer Innovation: [/h1]
The multiplayer aspect of "Dark Souls" is innovative and unique. Players can leave messages for others, warning of dangers or offering guidance. Co-op and PvP elements add unpredictability, allowing for both cooperative play and intense, challenging encounters with other players invading your world. The online component adds an extra layer of depth to an already rich gaming experience.

[h1]  Lasting Impact & Influence: [/h1]
"Dark Souls" has left an enduring legacy in the gaming world. Its influence can be seen in the resurgence of challenging games that prioritize player skill and perseverance. It has spawned a dedicated fanbase, inspiring discussions, fan theories, and even academic analyses due to its depth of design and storytelling.

In conclusion, "Dark Souls" stands as a timeless masterpiece that demands dedication but rewards players with an unparalleled sense of accomplishment. Its challenging gameplay, intricate world-building, profound storytelling, and lasting impact make it an essential experience for any gamer seeking a uniquely immersive and rewarding journey into a dark and mysterious world.

i tried dark souls when it first came out. hated it. thought it was stupid that anyone would take pride in beating a game that's designed to be overly frustrating and unfairly difficult.

then i went and lived my life, forgot about it, then picked up this dipshit remaster on sale because the original version i bought has had the online removed and ran like shit. i was a different person by then. i'd been through some shit. i loved it. i saw it in a new light and became obsessed with it and living in its world and i found a lot of value in its message, which i viewed to be a love letter to life itself: by showing such desolation, melancholy and sadness, it was highlighting the beauty that we take for granted by contrast.

by this point i've finished every game in the series, and the other similar games: bloodborne, sekiro, elden ring, etc.

the marketing around "oooo it's so hard" and "oooo you're gonna die so much" is honestly not in the spirit of the game. the game wants you to win. it wants you to never give up. this is an experience that people without confidence in themselves need to fight against so they can learn something about what they truly are and the potential within. don't you dare go hollow!

Dark Souls, developed by FromSoftware and directed by Hidetaka Miyazaki, stands as a monumental achievement in the realm of video games. Launched in 2011, this action role-playing game has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry, redefining player expectations and setting new standards for challenging gameplay. At the heart of Dark Souls' success lies its unique and groundbreaking gameplay, a distinctive blend of difficulty, interconnected world design, intricate combat mechanics, and environmental storytelling.

Unforgiving Difficulty

One of the defining features of Dark Souls is its unrelenting difficulty. Unlike many contemporary games that prioritize accessibility, Dark Souls thrusts players into a world where death is not only inevitable but a crucial aspect of the learning process. This punishing difficulty curve serves as a stark departure from conventional gaming norms, demanding players to adapt, strategize, and persevere.

The lack of hand-holding is intentional, forcing players to explore and learn from their mistakes. Each death becomes a lesson, encouraging a methodical and patient approach. The game's tagline, "Prepare to Die," serves as both a warning and a promise, setting the tone for an experience that rewards resilience and mastery.

Interconnected World Design

Dark Souls' world design is a masterclass in environmental storytelling and interconnected level design. Unlike linear game structures, Dark Souls features a sprawling open world with interconnected regions that seamlessly flow into each other. The interconnectedness of the world allows for a sense of discovery and exploration rarely seen in other games.

Players often find themselves opening shortcuts or unlocking hidden pathways that lead back to previously explored areas. This design choice not only enhances the sense of a cohesive and living world but also reinforces the feeling of accomplishment as players unveil the intricate connections between different regions.

Combat Mechanics and Player Agency

At the core of Dark Souls' unique gameplay is its deep and intricate combat system. Combat in Dark Souls is deliberate and methodical, requiring players to learn the timing and patterns of enemies. The absence of a traditional difficulty setting forces players to confront challenges head-on, emphasizing skill development over character progression.

Weapon variety, character customization, and the importance of player skill contribute to a dynamic combat experience. The stamina system adds an additional layer of complexity, requiring players to manage their actions carefully. The lack of a pause button during gameplay further intensifies the sense of vulnerability, enhancing the overall immersion and tension.

Environmental Storytelling

Dark Souls eschews traditional narrative methods, opting for a subtle and cryptic approach to storytelling. The game's lore is deeply embedded in its environment, with item descriptions, environmental details, and cryptic NPC dialogues providing fragments of a larger narrative. Players are encouraged to piece together the story through observation and exploration, fostering a sense of engagement and intellectual investment.

This game was really fun and a lot easier than expected! I would definitely recommend trying it out (but be sure to use a controller)! This game can be incredibly unforgiving at times but don't give up, you can do it :)

There is good build variety, interesting and sometimes beautiful areas, fun (most of the time) combat, and cool boss fights! If you really really REALLY can't find where to go do not hesitate to use a guide but otherwise I recommend playing this game completely spoiler-free. There are a couple spoiler-free guides on the internet so definitely look for those if you want, but the general consensus is if you keep dying super easily you probably shouldn't be there.

P.S. There are definitely a couple "bullshit" parts (THOSE archers, skeleton dogs, etc.) but there is often a simple solution you just aren't seeing. Don't be afraid to try new tactics!

(It gets a few points for being the genre-defining game and also being the first souls game that I played, hard to be objective talking about something so endearing)
Didn't think I would love this game when I first looked at its visuals, but here I am. DSR is the game that finally could appease my craving for a challenge and did it in a really stylish and cool way. While the first few bosses are made to be a stumbling rock in your way, it becomes much easier to fight them with each consecutive try, since the learning curve is insanely well made in this game. And if you want an additional challenge - you can also look into its DLC. And the lore is also quiet good, despite many people saying otherwise.

Nevertheless, you cannot ignore how unfinished later parts of the game look. The big four combined are easier than Ornstein and Smough encounter, level design is going downhill after you're done with O&S too, which breaks my heart. Hopefully, one day we'll get a Dark Souls Remastered 2 so that we could finally enjoy our adventure to the fullest.

This game will add length and girth to your manhood even if you arent a man. Praise the sun. 10/10

This game is far from "Best game ever made!" that some people keeps claiming... 8/10 at best of days, sure, but most of the days it's only a 7/10 game.
There are glitches, bugs and dumb designs.

It's a piece of work that drives once sanity to the breaking-point, and then stomp you on the neck while you are down. Heck almost all From Software games are like this! And DS1 is far from the best of them.

And I've lost count over how many times I've wished for the developers to step on LEGO's or stump their toes into table-legs. And for the love of it, I don't understand why I even keep play it as it keeps hurting me!
And if you don't believe me, try playing with an whip-only run!... Oh... oh shit... that's why it hurts so much!


Anyway, with all that said... 10/10 times I would suffer through this game again, for some reason, cause at the end of the day... I'm having fun with the pain here... WHAT DOES IT EVEN SAY ABOUT ME!!!?

So if you like to suffer too... I'd give it my recommendation.
If you don't... I'd still give it my recommendation, but with the advice that you have to out-level every zone.

After 50 hours of trying to like Dark Souls Remastered after playing the original, Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition, I still can't like it.
PTDE is unique, it's, in my opinion, the only true original Dark Souls experience, and only it can truly communicate the "origin of Dark Souls", what makes Dark Souls what it is today.
- "Why?" - Because DSR graphics are not even close to the original ones, the atmosphere is not the same and even playing with mods that change them didn't make it close to what PTDE's graphics were. Install a patch like DSFix to PTDE and there you have a game that makes Remastered almost pointless to exist. PTDE can run at 60 fps in high resolution with custom HUD, the only downside to playing it over Remastered is not having online features... Which may not be of much value to many people anyway.

It's not bad, but there is no reason to play it when you can play DS3, Elden Ring, or even just Dark Souls: PTDE...

Dark Souls Remastered: A Timeless Masterpiece

Dark Souls Remastered is a faithful remaster of the critically acclaimed action RPG that redefined the genre. It features the same challenging gameplay, intricate world design, and memorable characters that made the original so beloved. The remaster also includes a number of enhancements, such as improved graphics, framerate, and online connectivity.

Graphics and Presentation

Dark Souls Remastered boasts a visual overhaul that brings the game's grim and atmospheric world to life in stunning detail. The textures have been re-worked, the lighting has been enhanced, and the environments have been meticulously recreated. The result is a game that looks more beautiful than ever before.

The remaster also features a higher framerate, which makes the gameplay feel more fluid and responsive. This is particularly noticeable in boss battles and other intense encounters.

Gameplay

Dark Souls Remastered retains the same punishing combat mechanics that made the original so unforgiving. Players will need to learn to dodge, parry, and block effectively in order to survive the game's many challenging encounters.

The world design is still as intricate and rewarding to explore as ever. Secrets are hidden around every corner, and the interconnected levels encourage exploration and experimentation.

Enemies and Bosses

The game's enemies and bosses are as memorable and challenging as ever. From the humble hollows to the fearsome knights and dragons, there is always a new challenge waiting around the corner. The bosses in particular are some of the most memorable in gaming history, and they will test your skills to the limit.

Online

Dark Souls Remastered also features a robust online component that allows players to summon allies to help them through the game, or invade other worlds to cause mischief. The online play is as chaotic and unpredictable as ever, and it adds a whole new layer of depth to the game.

Overall

Dark Souls Remastered is a must-play for any fan of the genre. It is an excellent reimagining of a classic game that remains as challenging and rewarding as ever.

Pros:

Stunning visuals
Improved framerate
Faithful remaster of the original game
Intricate world design
Memorable enemies and bosses
Robust online component
Cons:

Nothing new for returning players
Recommendation:

Buy it.

[b]tl;dr[/b] - Don't make this your first Souls game. Start with Elden Ring and then come back here once you know what you're doing.

Don't get me wrong: I enjoyed myself. This is a fun game that will certainly offer an experience you won't soon regret or forget. There's many interesting locations to explore, with a connected world that remains one of the best ever designed, and truly feels alive as you explore further and further, and which brings all kinds of dark fantasy to life for you to enjoy.

That said, this game hasn't aged too well. The combat is clunky and at times unresponsive, and the difficulty of the game usually comes from being swarmed by a large group of enemies rather than any interesting combat mechanic.

Boss fights are surprisingly easy and just not very interesting. They're all too slow and pose very little threat compared to the swarm of enemies you've been fighting in the open world. The only three difficult boss fights include a coin toss in a tiny arena against some demon dude and two dogs, a not-so-fair 2v1, and a fight where the most used strategy is literally to save and quit. There's [i]ONE[/i] really good boss fight, and it's a DLC fight.

Most of your time in the game will be spent running back to wherever you got killed, running pass everything and avoiding interacting with the game. You'll spend way more time just running back to your corpse or a boss arena than exploring or actually fighting anything, and it gets grating.

I couldn't tell you what the plot is about. Almost all important plot points are way too cryptic to understand at a glance, which is a shame because the stories this land has to tell are actually really interesting... too bad the game doesn't really want to tell you about them. A game shouldn't have to rely on fan content for you to make basic sense of its story.

[b]Don't make this your first Souls game[/b] and only play it once you've got some experience with future (better) games and only if you're curious to see where Dark Souls started. If your friend wants you to play this game blind, chances are they wanna see you suffer and have fun at your expense.

In all, if you've never played a Souls game, I'll always recommend starting with Elden Ring. This game is terribly clunky, but charming in a strange unique way. There's nothing quite like OG Dark Souls, and the more I play it, the more I enjoy it. But it's [i]definitely[/i] an acquired taste.

I had high hopes for Dark Souls Remastered, expecting an updated and more inclusive experience. Unfortunately, my excitement quickly turned to disappointment as I delved into the game. The lack of diversity and inclusion is glaring and detracts from the overall enjoyment.

The game seems stuck in the past, featuring a predominantly homogeneous cast that feels out of touch with the diverse gaming community of today. The character customization options are limited, and the representation of different races and genders is sorely lacking. It's disheartening to see such a renowned title fail to embrace the rich tapestry of backgrounds and identities that make up the gaming world.

In an era where inclusivity is rightfully prioritized in the gaming industry, Dark Souls Remastered feels like a missed opportunity. The narrative could have been enriched by diverse perspectives, and the overall gaming experience could have been more relatable for a broader audience. It's disheartening to see a remastered version of a classic not take the chance to address these issues and bring the game into a more inclusive future.

Just like with Dark Souls III, it starts out fun, but then fails in the end due to 3 reasons. First, why is there no minimap? After going around in circles 5 or 6 times, the frustration level is just too high. Unlike with the later Dark Souls games, one cannot travel to a different bonfire, requiring long walks relying on memory. The second problem is it is not clear what to do next. I hate games that rely on the internet community and their walkthroughs to learn what to do next. 

Third, one cannot save. but rather on their few bonfires to save. The difficulty level rises fairly quickly so that by the middle to late game, it is really difficult. Not so much the combat, but rather stupid things like suddenly sinking to one's death waking across a pond (with no recovery of saved souls) or trying to time swinging blades just right while crossing a narrow ridge high up. Dying means losing all saved souls and respawning at a point far before the point when one died. Furthermore, all enemies respawn, too. That means another hard slog just to get back to regain your lost souls when you were killed before.

This is not an open world game, it is quite lateral. Nonetheless, they still are able to make the frustration level too high for me to continue. The ambiance is great as is the environement. The story is weak. I quit sometime past when the frustration level outweighed the enjoyment. 4/10

The classic, with all of its original, uncompromising glory (that also includes the typical FromSoftware disastrous design decisions that thankfully have gotten better after every new game of theirs). Still solid after all these years.

What I found most interesting is the level design, and how they nailed that this early in their Souls entries, so much so in fact that I think it almost rivals Bloodborne's, and is certainly better than all their other Souls games in that aspect, for me.

Will update the review after I play the DLC that I missed because, in classic FromSoftware fashion, you needed to be told beforehand about its existence and how to access it, as otherwise you'll just finish the game and get locked out of the DLC until replaying 70% of the game again, but harder this time.

Luckily, I have an older save just before finishing the game backed up. In your face, Miyazaki.

I'm glad that this was my 1st souls-like game ever. I've been watching my friends streaming BloodBorne on their PS5 (I'm a PC gamer). The atmosphere of it got my attention, then I've done my research on best souls-like games on PC and landed onto this game. 

It was tense and different than any genre I've played before. 
You as a player will notice your huge progression alongside the game. 
The little minions that were slapping you on your face at the beginning of the game will be nothing more than insects to you afterall (I recommend going with the Zweihander str/dex build). 

Moreover, the most mind-blowing thing in this game is how the whole world and areas are connected into each other. The design is genius!

I highly recommend this game for anyone that wants to do himself a favor. It's one of the best (if not the best) game I've ever played so far! I didn't expect playing a single game for more than 15 hours but here I'm, with a total of 50 hours in my 1st run (I will do my NG+ run after some time, I just want to taste it again after forgetting how great it taste).

Dark Souls is a game about perseverance. Everything about it--the gameplay, the levels, the lore, and the NPCs--serve to drive home this theme. It's not difficult for its own sake or to give people bragging rights or whatnot; instead, the whole point is Not Giving Up. 

The old Japanese saying, "Nana korobi ya oki"--fall down seven times, get up eight--is at the very heart of every design decision. NPCs go "hollow" when they give up trying in the face of adversity and setbacks (and so do players, in a way: they quit the game feeling empty rather than fulfilled). The "prophecy" of the Chosen Undead? It's not about you unless you make it about you. We are told that several undead have come from the asylum already; but the Chosen One is simply the one who doesn't give up. Is it you? That's not up to destiny. It's up to your perseverance. 

You weren't chosen by heritage or fate or oracles. YOU CHOOSE YOURSELF.

(Don't give up skeleton)

Things that are good:

- The first half is genuinely good designed, including environmental storytelling, intuative 
  leads towards the intended path and interlooping map design.
- Any of the many builds available can work if you know what you are doing.
- Primary gameplay loop is actual fun while still being challenging, a very new and innovative 
  concept for AAA games these days...
- Story is one of the best in gaming history. Prepare thyself for many hours of hunting down 
  every bit of lore.

Things that p*ss me off and will trigger you too:

- Why the f*ck is the dodge direction bound to the camera lock? When unlocked you can
  dodge in any direction you input but when you lock on you can only dodge in 4 directions.
- Why THE F*CK is the lock-on distance different in every area? Not much of a problem if you 
  have a melee build 'cause you can play unlocked but if you play a mage of some kind you 
  basically HAVE to play locked-on and in specific areas like the Duke's Archives you can't 
  lock shit even if its only a metre or two in front of you.
- Yeah, a game from 2011 has kinda shitty hitboxes sometimes. Not as bad it sounds 
  though...
- The second half just falls flat and dips its sh*tty little nose in some sh*tty little Izalith lava 
  before dropping in a sh*tty little hole in the sh*tty little Tomb of Giants.
- After you gain the ability to warp from bonfire to bonfire you will be asking yourself why tf 
  you can warp ONLY to specific bonfires for wich there is no good reason. Backtracking will 
  become a chore since the level design aint as good as it was in the first half 
- Speaking of wich, in the later half most boss arenas are outright hostile to you, be it through 
  too little space, the arena being filled with enemies IN ADDITION to the boss, unavoidable 
  drop damage or the game suddenly becoming a platformer with no dedicated jump button. 
  F*ck Nito and the Centipede Demon and f*ck the Bed Of Chaos in particular.
- The game mechanics outside of basic controls are not explained to you. Like, not at all. I 
  strongly suggest watching/reading a guide after you arrive in Firelink Shrine 'cause the game 
  is about as eager to explain it all to you as the government is to stop printing f*cking money.

All in all:

Dark Souls is a master-class in world development and atmospheric presentation. The game explores non-linearity in a very "everything is connected" way and is made quite approachable.
 
While it must be acknowledged that there is a bit of the patented difficulty curve at play, Dark Souls is only as difficult as you want it to be. No, there isn't a difficulty slider. Don't like dying? Play a sorcerer (Magic is OP strong). 

While Dark Souls graphics are getting a little aged, the oppressive ambiance and creative setting demand exploration. 

Dark Souls Remastered fixes many issues with the original title and preserves what was so amazing about the original. To this day, I still feel the emotional stirring in my chest when the final boss theme plays. Don't listen to the naysayers and the quitters... Try it. Yes, it is challenging... but the beauty is worth the cost.

ULTIMATE GAME OF ALL TIME

A lot of shit has happened in my life that somehow this game, this one singular game has been with me since the start. I was always interested in playing this game, but was intimated by its infamous difficulty, and upon my first hours of the game, regrettably I gave up. But then I picked it up again, and later raged quit at Sen's Fortress. But then I picked it up again, and made it to Anor Londo, then the game really stuck with me. It barely dawned on me on how big of a masterpiece this game truly is. No other game has made me feel as satisfied when overcoming the obstacles I once thought impossible, and the lore, by god, THE LORE. The world, its characters, its locations, its meaning, I was obsessed, no, I'm still obsessed. 

This game became personal because of the escapism it offered to me when I was in a low point in my life, and playing a game notorious for its difficulty is probably not the best coping mechanism, but it worked its magic on me. I ONE-HUNDRED PERCENT recommend this game to the world, but I also understand that this game might not be for everyone, and that's okay, keep trying to find games that bring happiness and fulfillment for you, as for me, Dark Souls makes me feel great, and I'm happy/grateful for being alive to experience this game.

Dark Souls 1 is a masterpiece everyone should play through til an ending. The satisfaction for progression is the key. I've played this game SO many times to exhaustion: PS3, Steam (Prepare to Die Edition "PTD") and now the Remastered.

What I would say is that the Remastered version is hardly 'remastered'. A modest discount was provided for fellow PTD owners on steam (for a few years before they rescinded that, while removing PTD entirely).
If anything, I question whether there is a slight issue with input latency (PS4 controller) on this version, or whether things might've just felt slightly more responsive 10+ years ago?
In addition, it was a prolonged length of time before network connectivity was restored to this game (which is honestly essential for jolly cooperation and invading: core mechanics to the game) so obviously not exactly on the radar.

Dark Souls 1: Yes, recommended. But don't think you're getting the experience as it was back in the day, it's a hollow shell of itself, sad to say. It's probably more of a solo experience if you play this game nowadays (which is also certainly fun and a good challenge, but nothing like how it was).
There is a much lower amount of players nowadays and with that comes fewer helpful/funny/disparaging messages around the world; fewer player ghosts to make you jump or laugh at when you see them; fewer invasions at inopportune moments who will try to cost you your souls/humanity; any hope of organised pvp battles is pretty slim; fewer people to help you, and fewer people for you to help!

Would also recommend Elden Ring regardless of how you feel about DS as that took everything that worked from the last decade and expanded upon it in all the right ways :)

EDIT:
For me, a) a good (i.e. entertaining and rewarding) gameplay and b) respecting players' time are the most important things for a (functional and stable) software, made for entertainment (a.k.a. a video game). For me, the aesthetics are secondary (maybe even tertiary), the stories are also secondary (maybe even tertiary). That is why I'd say that Onimusha, albeit an older game, is a similar game (gameplay-wise), but a better one. If you play it in 2023, you will feel entertained and you will feel that your time is being respected. When it comes to Dark Souls, the two most important checkmarks for me are missing. Before you decide that you know better and that you want to insult me or make a snarky/meaningless comment, please, keep in mind that I've put myself through Escape From Tarkov for a little more than 3000 hours. Did you play Dark Souls for more than 1000 hours? I very much doubt that.

EDIT 2:

Do Not Buy: If you really really want this game, I recommend you play this on console, as Steam Support will leave you high and dry. 

The game on PC is absolutely broken: You'll be plenty of distance away from the environment such as walls or landscape but when you go to strike, you'll get your attack blocked by the terrain in some moments. Hallway combat is a nightmare, your best bet is just to lure the enemy back to an area thats clear, but even then you'll still get caught on invisible obstructions. Once and a while you'll be walking on a path or stairs and just fall through it, and it won't leave your "souls" where you died. This game is unplayable, many bugs and glitches, Steam won't help you, they'll just tell you to go contact the game developer, so with that said, Steam will just take your money and run.

Coming from Dark Souls 3, I found this game easier and more enjoyable to play. It still has it's difficulties for sure, but leaning how to parry enemies and the slower attack animations; make this easier to learn combat techniques. There's actual help from NPC's in this game, whether it's sunbro firing lightning spears into bosses; or Big Hat Logan telling you Seath's secret as to how to defeat him. Plus if you find certain bosses to be too difficult; there's a video for how to "cheese" them, making the fight rather trivial. So yeah if you wanted to play a souls game and play around with the variety of builds you can do, pick it up and git gud.

Beautifully crafted masterpiece everyone should experience. The combat while slow and deliberate is a ton of fun to get the hang of and master. The NPC's are fun and interesting, all while being a part of one of the best worlds ever created in video game history. The interconnection between each section of the map is so ahead of it's time and is rarely attempted even in modern day titles. Truly one of the greatest games ever. Do yourself a favor and give it a chance if you haven't already.

Elden Ring was my first souls-like, and I absolutely loved it, so I decided to give the entire Dark Soul series a try.

This game felt very familiar, yet also somewhat different as well. Enjoyed it very much.
Although I have to mention, it's quite clunky and you can definitely feel that it's quite old at this point, especially when it comes to the camera and targeting at times (and don't even get me started on the camera issues for that big fiery demon boss, ugh).

But regardless, it's a fantastic experience, although do beware, definitely not for the faint of heart or those with a lack of patience.

Genuinely just wish it was longer. Expected all bosses (base game + DLC) to take around 30 hours, but after killing [spoiler]Kalameet[/spoiler] (my last DLC boss) and [spoiler]Seath (my last lord soul)[/spoiler], I realized the game was already coming to an end. [spoiler]Gwyn being an absolute cakewalk also made the very end somewhat anti-climatic [/spoiler]. Despite the relatively short length of the game, the content that is there is fantastic, and the game world is easily a contender for the best or second best of the Souls series. The combat felt much slower and deliberate than DS3 or Elden Ring (not nearly as slow as DS2 luckily) which took some getting used to, but this is not at all a bad thing, and getting into a flow state during a tough battle was a common occurrence for me.

Dark Souls is my favorite game series. While I can't be unbiased I can tell you the main thing that impressed me with Dark Souls. While previously playing Demon Souls, you have a world broken up by 5 Monoliths and for me, that took away from the immersion of the game. So I was happy when Dark Souls had A continuous world, where you could walk to all of the content minus the gargoyle and raven taxis, but the layout of the world and how the paths could intertwine and shortcut were a masterclass on design.

It's hard to put into words how I feel about this game. Sometimes it ticks me off and sometimes I feel an intense sense of euphoria playing it (quite literally, if you've played you know what I mean). It is simply put a flawed masterpiece. I'm writing this review after playing this game after Elden Ring (my first souls game) and I find the amount of polish and content in this game considering its age staggering. It is very easy to see why this game is so revered and considered to be one of the greatest of all time. The sandbox is perfect, the world-building is great (I would even argue better than Elden Ring), the mood is pervasive and the gameplay addictive. While not very easy for new players, those that stick with it will be pleasantly rewarded with some of the best experiences video gaming has to offer. Dark Souls is truly an experience that ages like fine wine, the more the player learns about its lore and complex game systems the more fun they will have. I really like the games message about not giving up or going "hollow" in the face of overwhelming odds and I find it to be very applicable to life, which like dark souls isn't always easy but is always worth playing. Man I am so thankful to Elden Ring for making this genre accessible to me because these are some of the best games of all time. The game still looks great, runs great, has excellent music and the included DLC is awesome (it had my favorite boss fights in the game to be honest) thanks to the remaster. While I have a few minor criticisms (like how sometimes it is impossible for a new player to progress without occasionally looking things up) they can somewhat easily be overlooked because the rest of the game is stellar. When finished I was left asking myself, not will I play it again but rather, when will I play it again. I am really excited for ds2 and 3 and will be moving on to those right after this one. A single playthrough of this one took me 45 hours and if the other two have this much content to offer I will be very impressed. I would easily recommend this game to anyone looking to get into the souls-borne games (as it has still aged remarkably well). If you can get it on sale go for it bc honestly its worth full price, a true 9/10 for me. If this is your first souls game, I like everyone else urge you to stick with it because once you climb that mountain there is no going back.

What can I say that others haven't said better? Dark Souls has solid combat, story, music, and level design. If you're looking for Souls-like, play the game that defined the genre. So far, it looks like the remaster has been just that and nothing more. This is a good thing. I've seen remasters of old games severely overstep, such as the Silent Hill HD collection introducing bugs that didn't exist, and the graphical atrocity that was GTA San Andreas Remastered. The devs fixed a few issues that the first Dark Souls had. For instance, the game would sometimes register a fall to your death when you only fell like 10 feet, but since you hit the bottom of the map, "You Died." The remaster fixed that problem. More astute observers probably noticed some issues and I'll leave them to nitpick over it. I personally enjoy this remaster a lot.
