i have never played a soulsborne before, and i was very scared to start one. these games have a reputation for evil, man, and if im telling the truth, i get very angry when video games beat me up consistently. when i was a kid i used to scream and break stuff bc i got so mad. i well and truly had milk all over my lips. so to deal with dark souls, i streamed the entire playthrough to my friends through a discord server, some of which are veterans of this and other soulsbornes. it helped a lot. it did a lot for me that i wasnt going through it alone, but rather, much like Death Stranding, i realised that Dark Souls is a social strand game. it was lonelyâ€¦ but it helped me having people there to guide me, support me, hype me up, console man, and even ridicule me. losing 40000 souls bc i fell off a cliff or died in a stupid way helped me see the humour. it was very rarely a frustrating experience, even during things like bed of chaos and kalameet bc it always just ended up being funny. and dark souls IS funny. to get back to undead asylum u have to do bizarre stuff with absolutely no explanation for why. u just sort of do it. the mere fact that Frampt exists is great, and everything about catarina is delightful too. i laughed so much during dark souls and that really helped me get into the groove of things. its just funny to swing ur sword and slightly slip off an edge. its funny to get to blighttown and get toxicated instantly. its funny when manus of the abyss wombo-combos u. those silver archers in anor londo? they are hilarious! once i realised this game was a big joke i was super into it. the obscure nature of its writing and storytelling do make it a bit harder for me to access, and i dont think id have picked up on much at all if it wasnt for my buddies answering my questions as i went. i still didnt really understand or pick up on a lot of it, but that doesnt mean i dont think its cool. for me, this might be a story thats more fun to read about on the wiki or watch a summary of on YT... like hollow knight.

all of that aside dark souls is a game that is known first and foremost for its gameplay. i dont play action games really, FF16 being my first one only a few months ago, so i was going in as a big baby. i know i wanted to be big and strong. i sort of regret starting as a knight bc it meant i had this great armour to begin with, although i was fat rolling up until bell gargoyles. i think if i had started as wretch i couldve more organically built up my character and there wouldve been something in the player expression of that, bc my character didnt feel like mine until i got to the depths, and i put on the sack. but that, then, was when it all started coming together. i dont remember why i put the sack on as my headgear, but i found it very charming. and aside from a brief stint of using the helm of the wise to fight the gaping dragon, i wore the sack for the rest of the game. upgraded it to +10 quality where it was only MARGINALLY worse than random headgear found elsewhere. suddenly play expression meant that DARK SACK BONUM PULLUM was a real character and i became invested. that, and finding the two weapons id play the whole game with, made me realise i was in my playthrough. i used the halberd and zweihander for the whole thing, finding their different styles useful in different contexts. for sif, i used the halberd, but for nito, i used the zweihander. that and the 3d metroidvania thing the game has going on was super cool. every time i unlocked a shortcut that took me from one place to another i did the biggest sexiest moan that i could. there is something so unbelievably satisfying about linking up all these areas. it helps u feel like uve conquered them in a very real way. and that in ofitself helps u tackle the game in kind of whatever order u want! it felt good knowing that i did sif earlier than all of my friends bc once i found him i decided to stick with him! the only boss i ran from to come back to was the stray demon in the undead asylum, and thats bc he sucks! BUT enough nattering... the gameplay of darksouls is more than exploring or player expression. its combat baby! fighting in this game is good. its simple on one hand, light attack and heavy attack, but theres so much variety. every weapon has flavour and personality, looking cool and distinct and also feeling powerful and weighty. finding the right weapon feels incredible. landing hits with the zweihander is addictive. flattening fools, even big fuckers like silver knights, or staggering artorias, is so rewarding. u commit to a heavy attack at the cost of precious stamina instead of rolling is a tiny calculation of risk, reward, and probability u are running in ur head every few seconds in those hard as nails boss fights. and bosses are hard, theyre relentless and feel unfair and like there's no way u can learn them... and yet u do! kalameet was probably the hardest boss in the game for me. he took me just under an hour to beat but at the start i seriously felt there was no way i was ever going to beat him. and yet the way u learn to read him, learn which way to dodge, when to sprint instead, where ur punish windows are. beating these games rewards u with a feeling of satisfaction so pure that the in-game reward for it can be totally lacking (and often sometimes is) and its FINE bc the reward u wanted was knowing that u won. very few other games can give u that feeling. O&S gave me that the most. i got them on my third try, but genuinely don't feel like i've ever been that engaged with a bossfight other than extreme trials in FF14. genuinely bonkers how wired in u feel when ur going toe-to-toe with a tough motherfucker. cant recommend that shit enough.

im feeling extremely high on DS1 having just finished it but it would be remiss of me not to mention that it does have a lot of stinker stuff in it too. the latter half of the game isnt bad but does pale in comparison to the first. basically once u've finished anor londo the game is just slightly not as good and its noticable. the areas are slightly less interesting, some enemy placements are silly and the bosses are just not as fun either. there are some real bad fucking moments though. tomb of the giants is bad. cool idea for an area, ancient crypt filled with skeletons of long dead giants... and yet it ends up being impossibly dark with annoying enemies and jank platforming. crystal cave isnt as bad but is definitely not good. invisible paths are gimmicky. uninteresting nor innovative way to keep environment design fresh. as for bosses, seathe and moonlight butterfly are not good but man, nothing is as bad as bed of chaos. its nuts just how bad that thing is. it's not even a puzzle boss; it has two huge glowing weakspots that need to be destroyed. the problem is not working out how to destroy them, but rather that he kills u instantly 100 times in a row and there was never anything u could do about it at any point. it doesnt engage u with the way u've played the game at all. ur build or stats or understanding of combat or movement dont come into that fight. so why is it in an action game?

things i wanna gush about before i go: O&S, wow, genuinely so cool. doing mario 64 in the painted world was awesome and one optional boss was genuinely super cool. the DLC bosses were all engaging and fun in their own way. lautrec's side quest is really great (although the idea that freeing him is a choice is kind of dumb. if ur choices are "engage with a mechanic or dont" then the most interesting one is always the former). i love that he kills the firekeeper, despite the fact he can help u beforehand as a summon! then u have a fun bossfight with him if u want to get vengeance and bring firelink shrine back to life! thats genuinely so cool. id also never heard gwyn's music before, so even though he was pretty easy, especially after coming off the DLC bosses, he felt like a fun and fitting final boss. good stuff.

I actually love this game. Dark Souls I is a staple of the Dark Souls series and for good reason, as no other game is like this one. What separates this game from the others in the series is the deep interconnected world, which is why there is no way to warp to other bonfires, and find new routes that lead back to the Firelink Shrine. The story of this game is really cool because it basically starts you off after the events of an apocalypse and you just need to rekindle the flame to continue the cycle, or alternatively you can end it. I really like the lore of this game too as there are multiple characters that you can learn about, some can lie, some will attack you, and they all fit in great in context with the story. One of my favorites being my man Solaire. Now the issues with this game are that the controls are pretty wonky, and the bosses definitely do not hold up in comparison to future games if we are being honest here. There is charm in slowly beating a slow moving boss, and yes they are certainly more balanced except for that one stupid guy at the end of the DLC. But I honestly cannot say that I like these bosses as much as future entry bosses. also screw you gargolyles lol. Also, I forgot to say but the music in this game is iconic, most notably being Firelink Shrine and Gwyn's theme. Another issue is that sometimes it's like almost impossible to figure out where to go next, like it is extremely hard. And sometimes the bonfires are not close at all, which leads to a lot of frustration when lost, but if you can look past all this, this is a game that I definitely cherish, and wish there were more interconnected games like Dark Souls 1.

Elden Ring was my first Soulsbourne, so i'm coming at this from that perspective. After falling in love and putting almost 600 hours into that game (Elden Ring), I thought that id like to go back to the beginning. It was a clash of familiarity and a new (re)learning curve to say the least. It was also a very interesting and rewarding experience, and I want to share my opinion to all the other Elden Ringers that are curious.

The game is for sure more challenging, there is less room for errors, less things in the game are clearly explained to the player, and there are less checkpoints in areas which means a lot of walking, don't forget all of the stuff that was definitely put there to troll the player. All of this stuff just means that exploring, taking your time to figure things out and making these mistakes are all part of the experience of the game.

The biggest thing for me was how different the movement was between the two games. No jump on demand, longer recovery animations and only dodging in cardinal directions, but yet again this is just part of the learning curve of the game and a lot of the game is designed around these things.

Overall, I don't really have strong emotions one way or the other for this entry personally, though this might change as I Journey through the other Souls games. I still do recommend this one to my Elden Ring peeps if you're interested.

I played this after DS3, and I can appreciate the slower and more methodical combat over the faster-paced roll-heavy gameplay of 3. If you pay attention to your surroundings and take things slow, there are only really a few areas that should give you a lot of trouble the first time. People always praise the level design and connectedness of DS1 so you don't need me to tell you that, but it is a neat feature. The first half of the game is great in this regard, but the later levels feel incomplete or there seem to be missing enemies, items, things to discover etc. I don't mind the fast travel you get at a certain point since getting around would be an unnecessary pain without it. The world is also not as dark and drowned out as 3 which is something I quite liked, especially in regards to the armor sets. Most of the bosses are similar in the sense that they have telegraphed attacks which you either have to roll through or run away and whiff punish, or simply go behind them and stab them. They are fun and simple, but 2 of the DLC bosses as well as the final boss of the game are more in line with the fast-paced bosses of DS3. I enjoyed the fights, but I thought they felt a bit disjointed compared to the other bosses. Anyway tons of replay value and cool gameplay and design that rewards you for learning the level.

[h1]The smart philosophy behind creation of Lost Izalith is:[/h1]

- The [b]Demonic Statue[/b] represents [b]stagnation[/b], because nothing will ever change in Lost Izalith!

- The [b]Basilisk[/b] represents [b]curse[/b], because it is a curse to become a demon!
(And Basilisks turn people to stone and Demonic Statue are made of stone. A very smart choice.)

- The [b]Fire Dogs[/b] represents the corruption of good things, because the Witch of Izalith had good intentions!

- The [b]Boss Arena[/b] represents [b]true love[/b], because people feel filled with the true love of Wicth always standing there waiting for you!

- A message will pop into your head when you listen to the small and subtle Bed of Chaos ost ([u][i]The real Dark Souls stars here.[/i][/u])

- And The Bed of Chaos is bad. All it does throwing you down a hole :S

By the way
Now it's time to get serious. Very memorable.

It's a great game, definitely a classic, but the second half of the game kinda lacks the feeling of adventure the first half has (apparently the game's development was rushed or something).

Pros:
+ The interconnected maps design is definitely best experienced blind, I feel there's no other experience quite like it. Making it a little bit further every time you die, finding new bonfires, new shortcuts...
+ Motoi Sakuraba went insane on that soundtrack.
+ The story doesn't get all up in your face, it's up to you if you want to delve into the lore or just kill stuff straight away, no expositions.
+ You seldom see other NPCs but they all manage to be memorable anyway. A lot of them are strangely motivational, too.
+ Just the amount of things you could do in every playthrough is insane, really.

Cons:
- The controls might feel clunky at first, God help you if you're going to do some platforming (you know which boss it is, without cheesing).
- The last half of the main campaign might feel like a slog with how the last few areas feel so low-effort, you don't get that adventuring feel. Some of them also resort to cheap gimmicks, like the entire map being dark as hell. Just areas you'd rather never go back to, really.
- Over time it might feel like it doesn't matter what armor you're wearing, especially if you're melee, because no matter how much defense you got, if you start fat rolling, it's just not worth it. I just went naked for a good chunk of the game because your character is faster and you get the good iframes.

One of the best games i ever played. The game that really kicked off the genre and wow what a game it is! Just recently played this for my second time after some years and it got even better this time around. The pure gameplay experience like the combat is a joy to get better at, and the lore is very enthralling. The world design in its inter-connectivity is ingenious and every enemy placement, level design and enemy design is just very carefully crafted. Even the most random appearing aspects of the game have a lore explanation as to why it is like it is. 

 Are there some negative aspects? Sure, the awful boss run-backs can sometimes feel like a waste of time, especially after getting used to stake of marikas in Elden Ring. It could be argued therefor that the bosses in this game aren't as hard as other Souls-borne games, but there are some real tough cookies in this game, so don't be fooled. 

I'm a fan of hard but fair games, and this game perfectly balances this. 
It is fun, captivating and even  infuriating at times, which makes it exactly the perfect game to start with, in the souls-genre. 

Keep up your courage and patience undead one, because you are going to need it!

While the game doesn't seem much different from the original, the QoL updates are much appreciated. And while I among many other gamers would've loved to see a ground-up remake with new assets, it's surprising how stunning the original game looks while running on Dark Souls 3's lighting engine and bumped up to 4K.

I remember I never beat the original release on the Xbox 360 when the community was still "getting good", so returning to this game in new form is definitely refreshing. After playing all the other Souls games now, it feels like I actually know what I'm doing. If you are a newer player who just beat Elden Ring I'm not sure if I'd recommend this one or Dark Souls 3 as an intro to the series for you. Really, the games can be played in any order, as kinda like the Zelda series they're all connected but very loosely.

This is the best game to have ever graced this earth... only in the first half. Its so beautifully interconnected, with so much love and passion poured into the game that i can damn near feel it through the screen, the second half-ish of the game has a MASSIVE quality drop and it felt like they just wanted to finish up with the game ASAP with re-skinned bosses, and terrible level design and inter-connectivity and almost feels like a chore. First half alone: 10/10, perfect. Second half alone: 6.5/10, playable once, never again. Total score: 9/10 (yes, the math doesnt add up, but it deserves it)

 overall, the game is amazing and completely changed my standards for video games in general.

DSR is basically PTDE with DSFix and Wulf's DSCM with an inflated price of 40 euros. If you already own PTDE, don't ever buy this. Else, buy this, is a good game.

+ More consistent FPStown and Seath boss fight
+ New features regarding summoning (ex. can lock summon sign to friends only)
++ Can still skip sens and the rest
++ Quantity using
+++ Memeroll was a nice addition to the game (did exist in PTDE but was much harder to perform)
+++++ being able to handle items in stacks, no need to spam same buttons 80 times to donate 80 Souvenir of Reprisals. Same goes for consuming souls.

- Vamos Bonfire (NoobTarp.exe)
-- Easier to manage covenants
--- Cannot poopwalk(?)
--- Invader can use estus flask, which doesn't encourage >proper< invader/combat etiquette (no estus allowed for either combatant)
--- Significant increase in # of cheaters in PvP
- Most >boring< bugs are still in place
---- Graphics are in some places improved, some places made garbage. Armour doesn't shine anymore. Ornstein looks better.

Game-wise i still give this game a solid 10/10, probably best game i've ever played.
Remastered-wise i rank this 2/10, didn't really >improve< anything about the game

[EDIT 4/7-22] As of updating this review, the online servers for Dark Souls (R, II, III) have been offline in excess of 160 days, proving either the developer's incompetence in resolving the issue, their neglect for the Dark Souls community (their customers) or both. Keep this in mind and think twice B4 buying a BAMCO game.

Dark Souls is a classic that affects conversations surrounding live action game play and level design to this day. That said; it has an incredibly obscure story, clunky mechanical operation, difficulty is only as bad as it's perceived and has more glitches and skips than I could explain in five minutes. Conclusion: This game is not and has never been difficult and in many ways is objectively just bad. In fact, the right way to say this is that it's bad in all of the right ways. I generally think that most game enthusiasts will eventually want to play this game because of it's impact on the current gaming landscape. The funny thing about the genre that popped up surrounding Dark souls is that the souls likes all tried to do verbatim copies of the original Dark Souls while not realizing that the original objectively sucked. They would input the mechanics, which were horrible, into the combat systems of their games and then wouldn't understand when their game didn't fare as well as the original. Real conclusion: It sucks but I suggest that you play it for yourself anyway.

Video review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-6NhPLEtZu4

DARK SOULS 1 is an addicting surreal experience which will stay with you long after you finish your first playthrough. After you play this game you will find yourself questioning the point in playing any other genre of game or franchise because they will seem beneath you and this amazing gem.

You are Undead. A forgotten remnant stuck in eternal purgatory. Your destiny is to slay the four Lords and usurp the throne from Gwyn, Lord of Cinder. Then you may choose whether to try and save the world from it's doomed fate or curse it and continue the endless cycle (This is my short interpretation  of the plot but a hall mark of this series is to be as intentionally confusing and ambiguous as possible so take it with a grain of salt).

DARK SOULS 1 is obviously one of the greatest games ever made. It has a seriously hardcore player base which continue to play it non stop to this day. This is one of those games that will make all other games look terrible in comparison because of how uniquely fun and addicting it is. There is a high amount of quality for a game releasing in the year it did so I would definitely say it's more than ahead of it's time and more than holds up today.

The combat is flawless and the only example of a game which exceeds it is it's own later sequels. The bosses in this game are some of the most legendary encounters in gaming history and you will feel extremely satisfied when you overcome them. While this game is regarded as very difficult, I would argue it's not frustrating or unfair and it's very nice to see a game designed in a way that only has one single difficulty setting so everyone gets to play the intended best balanced version of the game. The RPG elements are also very strong here with simple but useful leveling and upgrade systems and a huge amount of equipment to customize your fashion with.

DARK SOULS 1 truly is the greatest of all time, but it did eventually lose it's title to FromSoftware's future games like DARK SOULS III & Elden Ring. Despite that it holds up today and is one of the most memorable and fantastic gaming experiences one can ever have.

I beat Prepare to Die edition when it came out and I finally got around to playing this version. I don't have any hyper specific memories of Prepare to Die about how it looked or using DSFix, so I have no qualms about Remastered. It looks and plays fine. Also, it's way easier than we remember. The average Mordhau pugger takes exponentially more skill to beat than anything this game has to offer now. I beat every boss in one try except for Artorias which took two tries and Kalameet which took four, using +15 Longsword, +5 Crest shield, +10 Elite Knight armor set. Good game, good version, very populated PvP invasion scene. But the PvP is extremely laggy even when you have perfect net. It's basically impossible to take it competitively or even half seriously. You'll hit trade and desync for days while enemies teleport behind you for instant backstab from 6 million miles away. So, play Mordhau for PvP, play this game for PvE. Good times to be had.

Beat the game around 45 hours, (It shows 100ish since I would leave it idle to read berserk). I've 100 percent Elden Ring and Sekiro, I wanted to finally try out the Dark Soul franchise and it was AMAZING. It was hard to play it at the start since the control was so slow and tight, but once you understand it, it becomes second nature. My play through was weird  as I did the "harder" parts at the start as I did not watch any vids on the game. All I can say this game is straight up amazing its not perfect, I hated the dark areas but other than that my whole experience was fantastic. The boss designs are BEAUTIFUL, out of all souls games this game had immaculate designs. The difficulty of the bosses are kinda weird, most if not all have a kind of twist on it and thats probably why I love the boss fights in this game. Overall please get this game and try it, for me it is a 9/10 only ruined it for me was the dark area, I can handle poison, lava etc but not being able to see shit really ruined it for me. But other than that it is an amazing time. I cant wait to 100 percent this game too.

I thought joining the hype around Dark Souls series would be enjoyable. I was wrong. This game was not meant for PC. The character animation when fighting is so clunky that it's just awful if compared to current gaming era. You can't really hit the target correctly even though your character is already facing in the right direction. The graphic quality is also very outdated. The developers might have made it in HD quality, but the 3D quality was still from a decade ago. If you're a player with RTX 3xxx or above, you would be disappointed in the "remastered" graphic quality. Hence the thumbs down.

Still really fun after all this time. If you're used to more recent Souls/souls'likes this game should be pretty easy. The only area I don't like is Lost Izalith. It's a cool area from a lore perspective, but has a lot of copy/paste enemies and the bed of chaos.

I'm hesitant on a thumbs up on this one, especially since I came to this after completing DS2 and DS3 (Sekiro, and Elden Ring as well.) While a lot of reviewers say it doesn't have any jank to it, it does. Combat is the weakest out of any installment (haven't completed demons souls yet) and it takes a bit of getting used to if you've played any of the other installments in the series. A lot of people praise the world and levels as well in this game. They are very interconnected, which alleviates some of my complaints, but without fast travel of bonfires, some of the levels get tedious pretty fast if you happen to die. It's been interesting to see how this series has evolved since this game, but I would still say you are better of with Dark Souls 3 or Elden Ring at this point than dipping your toes into this one, unless you want to complete all of the Souls games, or really enjoy the lore. PvP in this installment is miserable, and like other reviewers have stated, its very backstab centric. Recommended if you love this universe, but be wary that the mechanics have not aged as well as the other installments.

A genre defining game, but not the best of the series unlike the die hard fans believe. Later sections of the game overstay their welcome by spamming the same enemies in massive, empty rooms that serve no purpose except to add padding to the game because they blew past the budget developing the first.

"Mmm...mmm... Mm! Oh-hoh! Ahh, where did you come from? Splendid news, I tell you. First, I hear a great roar. And, voila! The path is open. Just goes to show. Good things come to those who wait! Hah hah hah hah!"

- Siegmeyer of Catarina

===================================================================

My first ever Soulsborne Game! At first, I was thinking that "Dark Souls is hard" is such an overused phrase, but I realize now that this Game can really be punishing whenever it gets a chance to. The "hard" part is that you actually have to think before you do anything but at the same time you almost don't have a chance to think at all, especially when you're faced with Boss Battles. There are things that will make your life more difficult in this game, like accidentally hitting NPCs will make them hostile towards you (NPCs are really helpful in this game) and facing enemies in narrow spaces feels like hell because your character's attacks bounce off of walls.. BUT, I enjoyed the game so much! The feeling of finally defeating that one annoying enemy after several attempts can be really rewarding and actually makes me want to explore more of what's ahead after.

As for the LORE, it is just MAGNIFICENT! I can't get enough of the Lore this game has to offer and the Game doesn't just give it to you only by text but also by the world-building (Game Level and NPC Position) within the Game. The reason why something happened is always intriguing from the beginning 'till the end. I can't wait until I finally get the chance to play Dark Souls II. Oh yeah, a little bit about the Game Mechanic and Character Build, the Battle is "easy to learn, hard to master" kinda mechanic but there's no one OP weapon or Armor Set, so try to use whatever you fancy. My suggestion is always try to balance between melee and range attacks. In my case, I used Pyromancy/Uchigatana/Arrow Combination and this is really helpful to defeat many kinds of enemies.

===================================================================

It's one of the greatest games of all time. A masterpiece in terms of design. Nothing about this game is unimpressive, there had to have been some sort of genius to be able to put such a special game together.  My favorite game of all time is Dark Souls.

It's not perfect. Lost Izalith is there more in concept than anything else because it's so unfinished relative to the rest of the game.  Some boss fights have aged. It may also be true that the game is unnecessarily hard to figure out. These and other complaints are true.

Dark Souls is also, in my opinion, the most coherent game ever. All aspects of this game are made to flow into each other: themes, gameplay, lore, multiplayer, world design, character design,  the very notion of death in video games is explored in a fascinating way. 

I'm sure that I and many others will be coming back to this game indefinetly.

This is a tough call...it's Dark Souls so of course I recommend it, but you should know this is an *incredibly* low effort remaster. Prepare To Die Edition with DSFix is much better looking than this, but they delisted that so this is your only way to play this game on PC. Also, because of the delisting, the online player base has migrated to this version so it's sorta forcing you to double-dip.

Basically, all they did was up the resolution, framerate, and change some lighting and effects (with questionable results). With PTDE, you can get the same resolution and framerate, while preserving the original art direction. There are fewer players online, though, so that's why I double-dipped. It's really sad this happened to one of the most critically well-received action RPG's of the decade, and the studio who farted this out really let down the fans and From Software.

All that said, you CAN mod this and make it look like it should have out of the gates. Go over to Nexus Mods and download the DSR 2020 texture pack and you won't be disappointed. There are other mods that can further modify the looks but that texture pack was all I found necessary to give it a remastered appearance. It's just sad that's necessary on a $40 remaster (you can pick it up on sale for half that once a year, or something absurdly rare like that).

Dark Souls Remastered sure is just Dark Souls Prepare to Die Edition with DSfix like people say but the thing is DSfix cannot optimize your game the way Dark Souls Remaster optimized it, never in my life have I seen Blightown with 60 fps until Remaster. So that is a plus towards the remaster. Another pros towards Remaster have to be the switch from P2P to Dedicated Servers, the online works so much better than before, I remember back in  DSPTDE I'd have to download a mod just so i can play with my mate. There are so many changes in this game that I absolutely love and for me it's just better functioning Dark Souls, the price is unfair even though we DSPTDE owners got it half price but hey it brings me back to what I said earlier, it's different Developing Team who was working on this game so no wonder why we didn't get it for free, they need to make money somehow since they've put some effort into it I guess.

I've been playing Dark Souls since 2012, I did hundreds of runs and it never gets old. 

In my opinion, the most well-balanced game in the series in terms of difficulty, length and replayability. You're really free to do whatever run you want, without the need of using exploits, or duping items. For experienced players, a complete run will last 4 to 10 hours, depending on how challenging you want it to be (DLC included) so you won't be grinding for 16-24 hours like the other games in the series. 

It also is the best approach to the series because of those reasons, so new players will find an unforgiving but fair game, that is quite easy to learn but hard to master. An average run for a beginner would last 40-60 hours, depending on how much they want to explore/how fast they learn.

For me, the main selling point of Dark Souls 1 is the gameplay. Namely the crisp animations and very accurate enemy hitboxes. Along with this, all enemies and bosses are governed by learnable (and after a while, predictable) attack patterns. Once mastered, the consistency of the enemies' movements allows the player to overcome them with mastery. The game is really not a test of mechanical skill, but of patience and willingness to take the time to learn the different enemies. 

Due to the consistency of the enemies, dying is mainly the result of the player's lack of knowledge of certain enemy types. The mechanism of learning in this game is failure. After each death, a new valuable lesson is learned - and this for me is the core of Dark Souls. 

The visuals of Dark Souls 1 are a bit dated at this point but they hold up decently well. The atmosphere of the game is great and this is thanks to the visuals being accompanied by excellent overall sound design that matches the dark fantasy environment of the game. "Less is more" seems to be the approach with the music that is often absent or very subtle until you approach a specific area, or discover a boss. Then it ramps up, giving a sense of urgency (or dreaminess), only to subside again upon death, or upon defeating the boss.

The variety of weapons and upgrade options help keep the game fresh. These also enable a variety of approaches to combat, and thus allow for diverse player expression. I opted for a quality Claymore build which is the weapon I used for the majority of my playtime, but someone else may use 5-6 different weapons with different enchantments tailored for different areas, and both approaches work. 

Sadly, the design of the latter portions of the game falls short. Namely Lost Izalith and New Londo Ruins. The drop in quality in these areas in stark compared to the first half of the game. This portion of the game was rushed and I would argue that the game would've been better without these areas. I found myself going through them mainly because I've 'gotten this far and there's no point in stopping now'. Some of the worst boss runbacks are present in these areas.

Speaking of runbacks, this is in my opinion a needless gameplay mechanics. Good example of these are the Bed of Chaos, The Four Kings and Gwyn runbacks. Instead of being able to retry a boss immediately after dying, the player is subjected to running back to the boss for minutes at a time, passing by groups of enemies in the process. If the rest of the game wasn't as good as it is, this would have eventually made me quit the game. I don't understand the point of there checkpoints being so far away from the bosses. Sometimes I wondered how much of my gameplay was spent in running back to the boss rooms over and over again. This mechanic only serves to waste the player's time and increase frustration.

Worth mentioning is that the online community is still active and I found myself being summoned for boss fights around a dozen times during my two playthroughs. I found the multiplayer aspect of the game enjoyable, and the community friendly. I even encountered a player-made PvP hub in the DLC area where members of different covenants would duke it out while others players patiently observed and waited to duel the winner.

All in all, highly recommend the game if you haven't tried it. Its a different breed of game and I wish I had given it a try when it first released, rather than a decade later. With that said, 40â‚¬ is a bit steep, so best to get it on sale.

Dark Souls is a great action RPG that's a wonderful experience for anyone to have a shot at.
I've played Elden Ring previously, wanting to try out the original souls games after some mates recommended them.
I found this to be an entirely different experience than I had imagined. 

MOVEMENT / MECHANICS

The movement is a lot slower than Elden Ring, and I'm not just talking about the player in this regard. Most of the enemies and bosses are slower too. This can make it easier to dodge some attacks because you can see them coming. But sometimes it can be more difficult to predict since most of the attack animations start out slow but then swipe/swing more quickly which makes it really interesting to learn the timing and frustrating at the start. Also some of the bosses have outright ridiculous attacks. I'm looking at you Bed of Chaos. You have a... well, half jump that you can perform by either running and quickly letting go of sprint and pressing it again, or you can press I think the left analog stick. 

LEVEL / WORLD DESIGN

The Level/World design of this game is actually insane. I loved the progression through all the unique and fascinating areas and the fact that no area is the same. You start out in an asylum for the undead, progressing through the beautifully connected world with various swamps (of course), lava caves (Lost Izalith), tunnels that drop deep into the earth (Tomb of the Giants), trap-filled dungeons such as Sen's Fortress, A massive castle (Anor Londo) and Dark green forests (Darkroot Garden). These are just a few of the locations featured in this game. The level design is harder in Dark Souls compared to Elden Ring because it's more difficult to run past enemies (since you don't have a horse) and the environment is generally more dangerous. I personally found this quite interesting and made me think differently about certain situations. 

BOSSES

I will say that the boss design in this game isn't amazing in terms of programming, a decent proportion of the bosses don't live up to the name in my opinion but they're still awesome to fight nonetheless. There are definitely really cool bosses in this game, allowing the player to still enjoy learning the moveset even though they're getting blasted most of the time. A few examples of this would be, Artorias Of The Abyss. (Easily the best boss of the game), Great Grey Wolf Siff and Gwyn Lord of Cinder. I even enjoyed fighting OnS, finding it a way more enjoyable 2v1 than bloody Godskin Duo. 

Disclaimer: I have not fought Kalameet, Gwyndolin and Pricsilla as of this review so I can't comment on those fights. 

BUILD VARIETY

One of the aspects that makes these games so well regarded is the huge amount of build variety, and Ds1 is no exception to this fact. I did a strength build for my first playthrough but I've seen so many different builds utilising other interesting attacks and play-styles. I will say on the other hand, It does fall a bit short compared to other souls games but I will say it was one of the first games to add decent build variety, along w/ Demon Souls.  

CONCLUSION

Dark Souls perfectly captures that gritty dark atmosphere of the nihilistic fantasy world you drag yourself through to achieve something great, and this is exactly how I felt while playing this game. I highly recommend this game to anyone that wants a great challenging experience, it's 100% worth the money.

And can I just say, when the credits rolled after beating Gywn, hearing the nameless song for the first time was something I will never forget.

[b]Dark Souls: Remastered[/b], is based on the original Dark Souls/Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition, which are no longer available on the Steam store. Something of note for this personal review: I have played the original, as well as gotten 100% completion on all Souls games released on Steam so far, and some other random â€œsouls-likeâ€ games. Just want to get that out of the way so you are aware I am experienced on my overall views with this particular series, as I may make some comparisons with Remastered vs. PTDE/1 original, so I will be adding a layer of comparison for those looking for a [b][u]gorgeous view[/u][/b], or [b][u]amazing chest ahead[/u][/b]. 


[u][b]Another note:[/b][/u] Since my review is just too long for Valveâ€™s fairly weak character limits (in far more desperate need of a minimum cap, rather than a max, IMO), I'll be moving it to another link provided, should you wish to read the full review. Now, for pros and cons, I will be both adding overall pros, or specifically mentioning it differing from the original if it fits that particular case as to why itâ€™s a pro or con. Everything I've added to comments will be moved in a few minutes, so you can get the full, organized list [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/AbyssalAscent/discussions/1/2573194016121244332/]here[/url]

Special thanks as well to [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32110520-Simetria-League/]Simetria League[/url] for their support as well for their assistance enhancing my overall Steam experience!


[h1]Pros[/h1]

Updated framerate, and no longer glitches for me on ladders. I didnâ€™t fall through a single one at 60fps. Also native 4k, I believe.

You can now switch covenants at bonfires, so that makes things much easier than than DS1 was. Also no sin penalty for betraying a formerly joined covenant, as far as breaking a rule for leaving via the bonfire selection option. Only when itâ€™s part of the normal game design mechanics did betrayal cause negative ramifications. I donâ€™t think any cared otherwise when I tried to rejoin either, but I cannot recall for certain if this is true in all cases.

It was quite active last time I tried it. Dark Souls stays pretty active, since itâ€™s a real cult classic masterpiece series. Itâ€™s big, confusing, time-consuming, quite addictive, and fun!

Items updated from original in how you can buy, arrange, and select stuff. Made inventory management easier for me.

The game itself is very challenging. One of the few game series where enemies and bosses will teach you as you play. You realize how you messed up, what to do better in most cases, and itâ€™s like a learning experience as you go along. Most games seem unbalanced, but this really does a nice job in teaching you how to evade, take advantage of weak points, timing spots for pot-shotting, and possibly parrying if possible, if youâ€™re really into that. It was a tiny bit easier for me to parry in this version too, I believe. I didnâ€™t focus on my parries, since for me itâ€™s mostly useful in PvP only, which I am not a fan of really. Most enemies are easy enough to eliminate without the need to parry, and waiting for parry opportunities would just make the game longer and more drawn out, so itâ€™s not very useful in most cases in PvE aside from a couple of bosses in the whole series.

Much better in PvP, even though it bores the heck out of me, due to its slowness and story/focus-breaking potential from an immersion standpoint. I got PvP backstabbed a lot in the original one when the enemies appeared to be in front of me, many times on the other side of the room, at least five or ten meters away from me, then would â€œteleportâ€ into an automatic backstab animation, because of the horrendous lag, and a lot of users took advantage of that. On this one the â€œghost backstabsâ€ were much rarer, so fights felt more balanced than on the first, which was literally a trainwreck of awful.

Nothing I considered great from the original game was removed, so I enjoyed it just as much as the first one! Happy they didnâ€™t overdo it, but itâ€™s not really that â€œremasteredâ€ either, looking at it from that perspective.

Most of the bosses that are â€œcheese-ableâ€ from the original are still as easy to kill in the same manner. I could still allow poo to kill a few of them, poison arrow others without being noticed, use fire through doors, and things like that. I wonâ€™t go into spoilers, but there is plenty of info online about how to cheese a bunch of these if you really want to know. I recommend facing them in NG/NG+ and then maybe resorting to it if theyâ€™re too hard after a whole lot of tries, some leveling up, and maybe tweaking of gear setups, or if you already beat them a few times normally, and you would rather breeze through the remainder to get all the achievements.

I enjoyed some â€œsequence-breakingâ€ in this game, since Iâ€™d done things fairly traditionally the first go on Souls 1. On this one, for instance, I rang the Blighttown bell well before the Cathedral one. I beat most bosses in differing orders, and did other random fun things I never thought to do in the first game, since I kind of remembered the gist of how things went.

The combat is very intuitive, the environments, music, and the main ingredients to make a great game are all here, and they are beautifully done. This game is just amazing to play. The bosses and enemies have lots of variations on how to approach combat, ways to beat them, and strengths and weaknesses (such as using bows, magic, close combat melee, stealth, parries, elemental weaknesses or immunities, and so on).


[h1]Cons[/h1]

One of the least remastered games that labeled itself â€œRemasteredâ€ that I have ever played. Almost nothing changed. Aside from mentioned points above. Looks like the same game to me, and felt about the same. Just a bit easier.

Itâ€™s only around $5 USD if you owned Dark Souls 1 original/PTDE on Steam. It should honestly be free(!!), since there isnâ€™t really a lot of new stuff going on. Kinda rude to make you pay for something you basically already have. There is hardly anything notable beyond what I already expressed. Itâ€™s nice if you finished the first one and want to replay it, and get 100% of the achievements again, however. Some of us are just masochistic.

Can still use some tactics to cheese and also to level up easily if you want to waste a bit of time on doing so at certain parts of the game. Iâ€™m surprised they didnâ€™t remove a few of these, or make it tougher to do.

You can get stuck at Vamosâ€™s bonfire, and itâ€™s hard as heck to get out of there if you are a bit under-geared. Skeleton wheels are just evil! Titanite demons and skelly wheels are the worst things in the game, probably.

Not enough room for the rest of the cons I have to list.

Praise the sun!

Dark Souls (later: "DS"), a game with deserved 10/10 rating.
Background: Why DS is a 10/10 game? It simply created new genre in video-game industry. Nowadays, it's very rare to accomplish that.
Gameplay: It's often said that DS is a VERY HARD game for players that are either psychopaths or Einsteins. It's not true. YES, this game will punish you for wrong actions and mistakes, but it gives you true satisfaction and dopamine shot every time you roll over an attack or finally defeat that one boss that gave you trembles and tantrums. Most important thing is that you can in very simple way make that game easy, pick a bandit with master key and access locations from other side, two hand axe and one-shot early enemies. 

World: Great thing about this masterpiece is fact of non-linear world with lot's of metroidvania elements. Later in game you realise, that you can travel to other locations using shortcuts and that most of them are connected to other areas. Another great aspect of created world is that you can see endgame locations from the starting one and vice versa, whole world is connected and it's beautiful.

Lore: You can simply skip all dialogues and know nothing about nothing to enjoy this game. It has in my opinion one of the best method of story telling: Short descriptions of items and dialogues which you need to interpret. Stories of some bosses and final decision is very deep on philosophical level, if you played the game and it was fun, you can simply watch YT videos and other stuff about lore for enlightening, you will be like: "ooh so he is that guy" and "so that's why that happened" or "damn that's sad".

Conclusion: Game is great, i think it's one of those titles every man should play. Finally, little bit of my word to you, if you think this review is good, and want to give me some feedback, it would be very nice of you to give this review some badges, it's purely your decision and I don't want to be too pushy. 

Have a great day and keep playin' :3

Dark Souls: The Brutal Battle Royale Experience That Puts Fortnite to Shame
Dark Souls, the unsung hero of the Battle Royale genre, stands head and shoulders above the rest, making Fortnite look like child's play in comparison. From the treacherous landscapes to the heart-pounding combat, Dark Souls is the true heavyweight in the competitive gaming arena.

Firstly, let's talk graphics. Dark Souls boasts a dark and gritty aesthetic that puts Fortnite's vibrant colors to shame. The hauntingly beautiful environments, the meticulously designed characters, and the grotesque monsters lurking around every corner make Fortnite's cartoonish graphics seem like a mere child's doodle.

Gameplay in Dark Souls is an exercise in precision, strategy, and relentless determination â€“ qualities sorely lacking in the more forgiving realms of Fortnite. Each encounter in Dark Souls is a high-stakes battle, and victory is a hard-earned reward that Fortnite's respawn mechanic can only dream of replicating.

The soundtrack of Dark Souls is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of typical gaming music. The haunting melodies and ominous tones perfectly complement the oppressive atmosphere, creating an experience that goes beyond the lighthearted tunes of Fortnite. Dark Souls' soundtrack doesn't just set the mood; it becomes an integral part of the soul-crushing journey.

In-game purchases? Dark Souls doesn't need flashy skins or emotes to keep players engaged. The reward is in the struggle, the triumph over seemingly insurmountable odds. In Fortnite, you may spend V-Bucks on superficial items, but in Dark Souls, your victories are the only currency that truly matters.

In conclusion, Dark Souls is the Battle Royale experience for those who seek a true test of skill, bravery, and perseverance. Fortnite may have the mass appeal, but Dark Souls is the unsung hero that delivers an unparalleled, unforgiving challenge. Prepare to die, Fortnite â€“ Dark Souls has arrived, and it's here to show you what real gaming is all about.

Its a masterpiece, Not many games can drive me to explore as usually I go from point A to point B as quickly as possible. This game forces you to explore to find interesting gear and punishes you for not preparing to conquer areas ahead. However, while doing that exploring never feels like a chore. You never feel like "god just let me go through already" the enemy placements will at first, force you to stop and look ahead and make you think about how to challenge them. The game also doesn't hand you any wins, there are no participation trophies here, everything you collect in this game you earned. whether it be 10 souls from killing a rat or it is a boss weapon that you forged from beating the boss that took you 50 tries to beat.

The enemy design is very simple at times with wyverns, rats, skeletons etc. but at other times it is also very intriguing and some of the most abstract designs in video games with bosses and other major enemies. This is a plus as when you see a very unique design in the game it serves as a warning, and it also drives your curiosity to find out how it fights but more importantly, how you can beat it.

This game also makes you feel like an adult, it tells you the controls and nothing else. Everything you need to figure out on your own. You need to explore and find things that tell you where to go, whether they be NPCs or the description on items. The only thing limiting you in this game is your drive to explore and learn more about the world.

Let me paint a picture for you:
You've attempted this fight 30 times each time falling short. You make your way back to the boss arena, you've mastered the area before it maximizing your health entering the boss fight. The music kicks in, a beautiful orchestra accompanied by a choir of operatic chants. The stage is set, you know all of the bosses moves, you know exactly how the fight is going to go, you planned your strategy ahead of time, you use your buffing item that you learned the boss is weak to by reading the texts in the game and inferring with the knowledge you've accumulated over countless battles. The only thing to do now, is execute your plan to perfection. You start out strong dodging his moves and weaving in some counter attacks but you get a little greedy and get punished for it. your down, but not out. you fall back to recover but the boss doesn't let up. he keeps pushing you and you find yourself crumbling under the pressure, your plan is faltering. You pull off some miracle dodges and the boss finally calms down enough for you to stabilize. you get your bearings back, the buffs wore off but you still have plenty of life You start taking it slower, only going for 2 hits when you feel you can go for 3. slowly the boss is whittled down. The health bar is so low now. only a couple more hits and its over. you push your advantage you dodge aggresively. you swing, swing, swi- the boss counter attacks, waiting for the moment you got greedy and he hits you hard. your down to your last legs. both of you 1 combo away from death. the blood is pumping, the fear of having to do this again, the adrenaline of being so close to victory everything is telling you different things you cant get a thought into your head without contradicting it. "play safe, run in, dodge and counter, bait an attack" all of your options are in your head, the bosses hasnt done anything as if hes waiting for you to crumble under your own fear so he can finish you off. Then as the music swells, he charges in. the move you've seen countless times before, the move you've sworn to never die to again comes. you know exactly how to dodge it, where to optimally position your self after it to guarantee a counter hit. You feel it in your soul. you dodge, counter. its not enough your one hit away, the boss charges up his next attack, its coming, you have no time to decide what to do "dodge or hit ? dodge or hit ? dodge or hit ? dodge or hit ?" in under a second this one question bounces in your mind countless times you give in to your instincts and right as the bosses weapon is going to hit you, you swing your weapon and strike him down. You've conquered not only the boss but your doubts as well, you overcame it. the relief kicks in its finally over, the battle is won, but more still awaits.

[h1] I recommend Dark Souls Remastered [/h1]

[b]Review by Unam[/b]

Ah, good old Dark Souls. 

I'm a huge fan of the genre, playing and beating all of Fromsoftware's classics and I've enjoyed all of them (Yes, even Dark Souls II). Hell, I've even done an SL1 for Dark Souls III, and it was the most bittersweet experience of my life. I keep coming back to these games because I appreciate them as pieces of art and for being plain fun. Dark Souls is the second of the Soulslike genre, only being predated by Demon's Souls for the PS3. While not my favorite of the trilogy, Dark Souls is still a masterpiece and will likely hold up for ages to come. I adore this game, and I could end the review here and give it a 10.

[b]BUT[/b]

I'm reviewing this as a remaster of the original game, and that is where the package as a whole lacks. I'll review the game and then the remaster separately, and give it a single score. 

[h2]Part 1: Dark Souls [/h2]

In this portion, I'll discuss the original game. The game is a masterpiece. I find it incredibly amusing that this was only the second time Fromsoftware was dabbling with the genre. [b]They have managed to craft such an important landmark in gaming history, and their efforts and passion should never be unjustifiably doubted [/b]. I'll start with discussing the world, as that is my personal favorite part. Like other Soulslikes, the game offers extensive creation settings, allowing you to play whatever you want. The game also has a lot of different gameplay styles, including magic, pyromancy, miracles, and basic swords, axes, knives, and shields. You can literally play whatever you want to play, and it really helps with providing a lot of replayability. Out of the entire trilogy, Dark Soul's world remains the most interesting and innovative. All of the areas are so unique, from the soothing melodies of Firelink Shrine to the bloody atmosphere of Blightown and the haunted feels of New Londo Ruins, everything here feels so special and they all fit together perfectly. One of my favorite parts about the world is that it is all interconnected, and you never follow a straight path. As an example, in one playthrough I went straight to Undead Burg, which is most commonly the area where new people go, and in another playthrough, I went to the Catacombs. Sure, some areas are harder than others, but you can tackle the world in whatever direction you want, only being stopped by having to hit certain checkpoints along the story. What helps bring the world to life are the enemies, that are never recycled and are proprietary to a certain area, and they all fit with the tone of the environment. Along your journey, you will meet a few characters, and they all help guide you and give a brief description of your surroundings [Insert "Praise the Sun" joke here]. These characters tend to give you a glimmer of hope in this dark depressing world, which helps alleviate the player and gives tidbits of lore.  

Now, you can't go talking about Dark Souls without mentioning the bosses. While it doesn't have my personal favorite selection, some of the bosses are super iconic. There are roughly 26 bosses, with a few repeated ones. This is honestly a lot, but out of those 26, there are only 10 which are really good, with the rest ranging from decent to annoying. While this is fine, most tend to be super difficult, this is why most people use the phrase "This is the Dark Souls of [genre]', speaking of which... 
Let me rant about the [u]DIFFICULY[/u]. The difficulty in Dark Souls is balanced, mostly dependent on the player's skill and willingness to repeat the action to make the difficulty. I'll set an example; You can literally grind the same enemy for 100 hours to get to level 300 and literally destroy anything in your path with a single hit, or, you could send yourself at level 1 and most certainly get destroyed in a single hit, it's up to you what you want to do. Personally, I would recommend against grinding unless you're feeling like you are under leaves for an area or boss. That's why I don't like the phrase "Dark Souls is the hardest game ever made" because it isn't and everyone that says that has probably never played the game. Hey, if you think it's the hardest game, all power to you, but you cannot deny its difficulty revolves entirely around the player. n

I especially adore the theme of [b]Perseverance[/b] in Dark Souls. [u]You are going to die, that is a fact and there is no way around that,[/u] but that is ok. The game is all about patience and not giving up. You are literally placed into one of the most demoralizing worlds ever and are placed against unsackable odds, yet you surpass them little by little, and adventure to find balance. This is what I love about Dark Souls. This is why I will never get tired of Dark Souls. [b]This makes it a masterpiece. [/b]

Dark Souls also received 1 piece of DLC, [u]Artorias of the Abyss[/u] and while you might groan, let me tell you that this is one of, if not the best, pieces of DLC I've ever played. It lets you explore new areas, battle new enemies, gather new weapons and spells, and fight new bosses. Bit of a spoiler, but Artorias and Manus are up there in my top 5 bosses of the entire series (My number one is Slave Knight Gael from DSIII if you're curious). It is an amazing appetizer for people that wanted more, and at the time of release, it was retailing for around $15 dollars at the time of release, which was a steal and puts into perspective how gamers are being mistreated nowadays, with DLCs of the same price only adding minimal content, a real shame. This is more Dark Souls, and if you loved the original experience you're going to love this. 

This is my review of Dark Souls and like I said before, it is excellent, I genuinely don't have a single complaint. I would give it a 10/10, but...

[h2] Part 2: Remastered Edition[/h2]'
[u]I don't like Dark Souls: Remastered.[/u] Let me put it into perspective. The original game came out in 2010 everywhere, where it was released for 60 dollars, like most other AAA games, and like other games, it became heavily discontinued after a few years, usually retailing between $15-$30 dollars. That's all and fine, but then in 2019 Bandai Namco alongside Fromsoftware announced a "Remaster" of the game. I put this in quotation marks because considering this a Remaster is a disservice to all Remaster. They literally slapped the game on Steam again, updated some textures, gave you the DLC, and called it a day. Now I'm going to list all the new features, ready?

1. ...

What's that? Do you think I made a spelling mistake? [u]No, the Remaster literally adds nothing new.[/u]. I wouldn't be complaining so much if they didn't delist the original version from Steam, furthermore, they didn't even give this as a free upgrade to the original owners, which is a complete spit in their faces. 

Here is what they should have done:

1. Rebuild the movement system so that it feels more fluid, much like Dark Souls III
2. Add a few more enemies and rework some of the bosses to give them a few more moves and make the fights more dynamic and make them feel less clunky.
3. Fix some of the glitches that the original game had.
4. Fix (or remove) Capra Demon. 

Not hard guys.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
 
I adore Dark Souls, it is one of my favorite games ever. It will forever remain in my heart. It has created a community of hardcore fans that respect and love it. Its world and bosses are some of the most interesting in the area, and at the time it was released it put Fromsoftware on the map. It created the best trilogy in gaming and its monumental achievements cannot be understated. However, this Remaster is terrible. Thanks for reading this review.

It's the original Dark souls, but with some touch ups and improvements. Far many before me can tell you about this game better than I, and I'm sure there's plenty after me who could also do the same, but I think that's almost fitting to the themeing of this game. or even, the entire series.
Quite simply put; it's a good game. One of THE best, of all time. I'm not joking it's very literally been voted as such.
 
It's still a 2011 game at it's core, so there is some old school clunk and jank, but it's not intrusive with it usually. movement speed is a little low, sure. but you can look past that most of the time. If you have some buddies to play alongside with, or even want to go completely solo, it's still really fun and enjoyable for both crowds.

The lore of course is super well thought out, even for simple things as to why your healing item works or why you respawn after you die. It however will not be giving you the answers to everything; but it does provide just enough for you to be able to draw your own conclusions, thus, YOU are actually included into how things went how things are. how things will be. 

Dark Souls is a game to test you in how strong your will is. 

There is no difficulty slider. there never will be one. and there never should be one.
which is poetically beautiful in its own right.
EVERYONE is on the same difficulty, thus, no one is treated unfairly. No matter what disadvantages you have in how you play, how you react, how you conduct yourself. You are challenged on the same equal level as everyone else. THAT, is the truest inclusivity imaginable. You are treated as an equal to every other player before or after you.  

Will you give up because you lost to a particular challenge 13 times in a row, or are you going to get back up, dust yourself off and go at it again until you win? the choice is purely yours. only you can make that choice, and thus, it's up to you on whether you can get through the game or not. 

Also, a super neat detail, it could be considered small to some; is the Two Bells of Awakening. If you're around two specific areas and you're hearing bells going off. that's quite literally other players in the game right this very second, who are beating those bosses and claiming victory by ringing the bells for it. It's just one of those synchronous moments that tell you that other people are making their way through their journeys as well along side you, and how they are doing in a way.  

Dark souls is a rich game, one steeped in lore, in how hard the Developers thought about every smallest detail, and it's always up to the player how much they want to take it in. If they want to ponder, just why a particular enemy is even in this particular area, or simply who's the next thing you gotta bonk to get out of your way. It is a game that deserves it's reputation, a game that earned the right to bear forth a new genre of gaming entirely, and change the landscape of gaming in its own unique way.

I do recommend you play it, whether as something you want to just smash and bonk your way through it, something to cherish as you play with friends, something you cleared on your own under a rather tough challenge/Speedrun, even under something super silly as "Can you Beat Dark Souls while blindfolded on a banana" or as something you keep with you, and ponder on for the rest of your life.

Although not my introduction to the franchise, that being DS3, this game is one I have an unmatched emotional connection to. The game twists a narrative into its level design that is INSANELY intriguing and fun to figure out (or to let VaatiVidya explain), and genuinely feels like an adventure, I'd say more so than most action/adventure games I've played. That sense of adventure and exploration is thick throughout the entire game, be it the awe-inspiring initial view of Anor Londo or the dungeon-crawling atmosphere of the Catacombs. I have nothing but love for this game, but it should be noted that yes, as many have said before, the second half of this journey is not quite as engaging as this first. I still enjoyed it plenty, likely more than most, so it didn't bother me much, but that may throw some off.

Conclusion: Buy the fucking game (preferably on sale)

Still one of the better games even today, it sets the standards for challenging third person action RPGs, so much so that it turned that specific type of game into its own genre. The gameplay is amazing, from traversing the amazing, well thought out world, to actually engaging in challenging encounters that complement the game mechanics. The lore is incredible too as many will tell you. The attention to detail, careful game balancing around very solid mechanics, the overall atmosphere supplemented by the few but extremely memorable side characters you encounter, this is easily one of the greatest games ever made and it's a testament to how well this game has aged, especially considering how so many new Souls-likes have yet to surpass this game in so many aspects. For very experienced players, those who know the whole world like the back of their hand, please give the Daughters of Ash mod a try, it helps the game feel so fresh and makes the game harder without ever going into bullshit territory, while also adding some cut content (including a boss), and some new original questlines (more obscure than ever too, just use a guide trust me on this).

This wasn't the game that started it all, however it was the game that put it on the spot light, the game may be clunky and somewhat outdated, however you can't argue that it's a masterpiece of a game that deserve all the respect it needs, the story and game play was something never really seen before and it literally birth a genre of games that many people love and it also paved the way for the sequels that are beloved too, this game might be the Remaster, but that doesn't mean anything really as the only difference is that it has better lighting to make the monsters look more fresh, but the story and game play is still all there and it may be difficult and punishing especially with the stiff controls, but its still a fun game to have

Dark Souls 1: 2

This game is the Dark Souls of souls-like games. Literally, it's Dark Souls, the spiritual successor to Demon's Souls and the OG of the souls-like genre. You are the Chosen Undead, a Hollow shell of a person now destined to either take over as the herald of fire and rule over this chaotic realm or to plunge everything into an age of darkness forever. Master Dark Souls' unforgiving combat and challenging bosses as you traverse an expansive RPG full of some of the most impressive world-building I've seen in a videogame.

Going into this I had a decent amount of souls-like experience already. I had played Mortal Shell once, Jedi Fallen Order on the hardest difficulty, and Sekiro to 100% completion over about a dozen playthroughs. I expected to feel at least a little bit prepared but not a tremendous amount, considering Dark Souls plays a bit differently from these other titles and is also around a decade older than them. For the most part, I was right. Some outdated mechanics and awkward controls took me a very long while to get used to (don't even get me started on sprint, dodge, and jump all being bound and linked to the same button). Playstyle was significantly different as well; I was so used to the blocking/parrying-centric combat of Fallen Order and Sekiro that I was confused for a while on why blocking things with my medium shield in Dark Souls wasn't as effective. I hit a point of severe frustration early on in my playthrough navigating through the Undead Parish, and more specifically at the Bell Gargoyles boss fight. I felt that I was less often fighting my opponents in Dark Souls and more often fighting the game itself, trying to get it to work the way I wanted it to, the way I had set expectations for.

So I learned. I used the crafting system to keep my equipment upgraded to a point that felt more usable, I optimized my equip load so that I had a more medium-paced dodge roll as opposed to the heavier one, I focused my combat playstyle less on blocking and more on dodging and rotations. And I got better. I went from taking basically an entire evening to beat Bell Gargoyles to beating most boss fights in under ten tries, and quite a handful of those bosses on the first try. And as I learned how the game wanted me to play, how the game wanted me to explore, how the game wanted me to breathe, I could focus more on how incredible of an experience Dark Souls was. Despite being a decade old and one of the first games in its genre, I could feel the passion that went into its story, its environments, its combat, its character design. Once I got past that hurdle, I could name on one hand the number of times I was genuinely frustrated with Dark Souls, something that caught me by surprise considering the game's and series' reputation. 

I am still stunned with how much I genuinely enjoyed Dark Souls. Not that I was going in expecting to hate it but again, Dark Souls' reputation masquerades it as something that very few people come out of without losing a few patches of hair. And don't get me wrong, I still think run-backs and dual-boss fights are some of the dumbest things to grace the light of day, but my overall experience with Dark Souls was so incredibly positive. I am very excited to try the rest of the Souls series and Elden Ring next (I am aware of Dark Souls 2's problems please just let me dream).

Dark Souls 1 is a masterpiece. I went into this expecting an outdated jankfest but instead got a well-crafted and sadistically challenging experience that tested me and my sanity in ways most modern Soulslikes havenâ€™tâ€”even those made by FromSoft.

My first few sessions all ended in rage quits, and I don't recall having said this many gamer words ever since I quit League of Legends almost a decade ago.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
Dark Souls 1 has been referred to by many as â€œeasyâ€â€”especially compared to something like Sekiroâ€”with the implication that with difficulty comes quality. After having experienced this masterpiece, I can confidently say that this notion of Dark Souls 1 being easy comes from a fundamental misunderstanding of difficulty.

What is difficulty? What decides whether something is a challenge or a cakewalk? Iâ€™d suggest it to be the amount of effort and thinking a player has to put in to overcome the challenges set forth by the developers. Part of the draw of games with high difficulty is that, the greater the challenge faced, the greater the satisfaction received when we finally overcome it.

And when we talk about â€œdifficultyâ€ in Soulslikes, the conversation seems to be focused solely on how hard the bosses are. Itâ€™s always Malenia this, Malenia that, Waterfowl this, Waterfowl that.

However, a large part of the difficulty in Dark Souls 1 is focused on the maps themselves: the valleys, forests, caves, catacombs, and dungeons youâ€™d have to work through to finally arrive at the boss at the end.

You are presented with numerous challenges that you canâ€™t solve with a simple well-timed dodge rollâ€”challenges that are less about trying to figure out how to dodge Waterfowl Dance and more about keeping your wits about you as you explore this vast and beautiful world.

[h1]Exploration[/h1]
The map design in Dark Souls 1 is a work of art. Unlike in more modern Soulslikes, the way forward isnâ€™t always clearâ€”you are forced to trawl through the unknown until you finally happen upon your destination.

You have classic ganks, ambushes behind corners, and archers shooting at you from seemingly unreachable places. However, accompanying them is a deluge of sadistic map design choices seemingly intended to engender a rage-filled, â€œARE YOU FUCKING SERIOUS?!â€ every time you encounter one.

Later game areas also often feature certain cancerous mechanics that would probably have driven me insane had I not acclimated to and embraced the BS with a simple, â€œOh, so weâ€™re doing this now? Ahaha, okay, letâ€™s go.â€

Whatâ€™s more, hidden paths flanked by perilous drops that would lead to secret areas in other games are, in fact, often the intended path in Dark Souls 1. As someone who always takes the time to clear the entire area of enemies before exploring every inch of the map, I [u]adore[/u] this map design.

It is often unclear whether the path Iâ€™m taking would lead to yet another secret area or the boss, and this sense of uncertainty is so much more mysterious and fun than when the Site of Grace is literally pointing to the next one. Itâ€™s also really nice how the fog gates here donâ€™t always lead to bosses, which makes the surprise when you finally find a boss even greater.

[b][u]NPCs[/u][/b]
Some NPCs give you major hints about how to proceed or how your actions would influence the world, which is really cool. I had to retrain myself to actually pay attention to NPCs again due to how often modern gamesâ€™ NPCs just spew pointless nonsense.

However, certain NPCs should really, REALLY repeat their vitally important hints, because they are the ONLY indicators for how to proceed. If any hint was needed for this game, it would be to [b][u]listen very carefully to what the first NPC you meet at the hub tells you[/u][/b]. Write it down or screenshot it if you have to.

[b][u]Rewards[/u][/b]
What about your reward for finally overcoming these challenges? In other games, your reward for clearing some dumb puzzle is usually a useless ring the devs placed there for the sole sake of being a â€œrewardâ€.

In Dark Souls 1, you get anything from the emotional release of finally clearing the area, to secret paths leading to Bonfires and NPCs, to even one where youâ€™re able to (moderate early-game spoilers) [spoiler]kill some bastard who would otherwise shoot at you with magic for 80% of the entire boss arena[/spoiler]. This is the most fun Iâ€™ve had with exploration in a very long time.

Now, this is not always perfectâ€”I personally hate illusory walls because the ways to discover them are either a) unreasonably long periods of rolling into and hitting walls or b) using guides, both of which are extremely anti-fun. While this game hints at some of them, many are insanely hidden and often lead to extremely important NPCs and areas.

[b][u]Do Not Use Guides[/u][/b]
The last thing I will say about this topic is to never look up anything unless youâ€™re absolutely, definitely, 100% stuck. And unless you want this game to become a boring cakewalk, do not look up an area or progression guide. A lot of the difficulty in this game is about exploring the unknown and figuring out how best to proceed. You can face that challenge head onâ€”or you can Fextralife the fun out of the game.

You are ultimately free to do whatever you want, but I will tell you that using a guide for this masterpiece of a game is like flipping on a switch for Elden Ring that will summon a Mimic Tear +10 at the start of every major fightâ€”a switch you can never turn off.

Embrace the unknown. Get lost, get mad, and git gud.

[h1]Boss Fights[/h1]
Compared to more modern Soulslikes, the difficulty in many boss fights comes less from the bossesâ€™ movesets themselves and more from the arenas in which said fights take place.

I wonâ€™t spoil anything, but I will stress that instead of solely testing your reaction speed and the dexterity of your fingers to dodge through attacks, the test of skill here is often about forcing the player to figure out ways to mitigate the sadistic and annoying cancer present in many of the boss fights.

The collection of bosses in Dark Souls 1 is such a perfect blend of testing your brain along with your skill. While I definitely enjoy my Waterfowl Dancing amputees and old men armed with katana, spear, and Glock, this style of difficulty is so much more varied and enjoyable, even if the fights themselves are indeed easier from a skill-based perspective.

[b][u]Runbacks[/u][/b]
While the runbacks here are definitely longer than those in modern Soulslikes, I didnâ€™t feel as annoyed for some reason.

Since the difficulty in modern Soulslikes is concentrated almost solely in the bosses, runbacks in those games feel like a nuisance. In contrast, since the difficulty in Dark Souls 1 seems more puzzle-focused, doing the runbacks quickly, safely, and efficiently felt like simply yet another puzzle to be solved.

Or maybe Iâ€™m just glazing because I still canâ€™t believe how good this game is.

[h1]Final Words[/h1]
If you love Soulslikes, you owe it to yourself to try this game. Take a couple of hours to get used to the jank, turn off the Google Search, and give yourself over to the cancerous, sadistic masterpiece awaiting you.
