This game has the unique ability to teach one many important values that are useful in real life. Firstly, it will teach you that the problems you face and the frustration that comes with those problems can often be overcome with patience and persistence. It will teach you that to overcome problems sometimes you must change the way that you think of the problem. It will teach you many philosophical values that you might not even realize it is teaching you, but those values will have a positive effect on the way you approach your own life. I recommend this game because I believe that learning the lessons that this game has to teach is beneficial in many ways to the way you approach problems in your real life. This game is like a very intelligently written novel. I've come back to play this game many times over the years since it has released and I still love it.

[h1]...it requires a lot of patience and resolve. In the end though, itâ€™s not only worth braving the darkness for the sense of satisfaction, but also for the incredible world building.[/h1]

According to many players Dark Souls is one of the hardest game series out there. Itâ€™s rare that solely beating a video game is considered an achievement itself. To do just that you need to go through a purgatory of constant failures, pain and frustration. Itâ€™s a production that many people take on mainly just to challenge themselves. Still, there is more to this game than just being â€œa bit more difficult than an average video gameâ€.

Your character wakes up in a prison cell and you find out about the curse of the undead. The curse causes you to lose all power and come back to life after each death, until you start to lose your mind and become one of the empty husks, ghouls mindlessly roaming the many castles and dungeons you explore. 
Once you leave the walls of the asylum you were locked in and learn about the prophecy of the Chosen Undead, you travel to Lordran to rekindle the fire, lift the curse and save the world. 
Well, did you grasp the main concept? Was it too general of a story, not specific enough? That is Dark Souls. If you pay attention to the prologue and the actual things you do in the game, you might get [i]some[/i] idea of what is even happening. But this game is a big jigsaw puzzle. Many things you do in it are for you to just progress further. You donâ€™t get the context of the fight with this big spider monster and what defeating it means for this location. You just want to get past it. This context you find in environmental storytelling, item descriptions and enigmatic dialogues with NPCs.
You can only understand Dark Souls when you actively seek out its secrets. Its actual story is not only not handed to you on a silver platter, but is also full of lies, falsehoods and manipulations. The characters have their own goals, things they say are not always the truth and it doesnâ€™t matter if they are purposefully spreading lies or are just as oblivious as we are.
Iâ€™m not saying that to correctly appreciate this game you must become the absolute lore master, itâ€™s not the point. Iâ€™m saying that by just playing the game to beat it, you will miss a lot of its artistic value. Itâ€™s full of interesting side plots (my absolute favorite is Artorias and Sif) and metaphors. Damn, people are writing research papers about this game, I considered it too.

The gameplay itself is like this: you go from a bonfire (which is your checkpoint) as far as you can, ideally to the next one, defeating or evading enemies as you go and acquiring their souls. Souls are the currency that lets you level up, upgrade your gear or buy items from merchants. You explore many different locations, fighting various enemies, finding items and uncovering secret illusory walls. You face formidable bosses each testing your skills.
So what is so difficult then? My take is that Dark Souls difficulty consists of several main points. One of them is losing all your power after death. When you die you lose all your current carried souls and humanities (humanity is a whole different mechanic I wonâ€™t be explaining here) and leave a blood stain close to the place you perished. If in your next attempt, you manage to reach the stain youâ€™ll recover all your lost power. If you die before that though, the stain gets replaced with a new one, making you lose all previous progress. It can be equally addicting as demotivating.
Another unpleasant thing is running back after each death.
Thirdly, this dark fantasy adventure is oddly realistic. Your character has a stamina bar that depletes with almost every action. Sprinting, dodging & rolling, attacking, blocking hits all use stamina and once you run out of it, not only you cannot attack further, but also you canâ€™t dodge away. Itâ€™s important to keep track of your stamina bar, because besides knowing a few spells, you are just an ant with a toothpick to that Gaping Dragon â€“ one wrong move can mean the end for you. Combat itself is also pretty tactical, if you can call it that. You must position yourself in a way so that if the enemy swings at you, you donâ€™t roll off a cliff or into the lava. Even just healing yourself is a tricky decision â€“ you must make sure that you have time to do that mid-combat. The animation takes time and foes wonâ€™t let you take a break. 
In conclusion one of the most frustrating situations can be that you die to a boss, try to run back fast for your souls while being mad, start making mistakes along the way, get beat up by some funny skeletons because you swinged at a wall instead of them, miraculously survive only to roll off a cliff and die again. Then rage quit.
Sounds bad right? Do I think this game is hard?
Itâ€™s certainly above average. But I think the key here is to keep the right mindset. You will die a lot, itâ€™s not only part of the experience, but also the best way to learn. The game teaches you to live with failures and that itâ€™s never truly over unless you donâ€™t get back up. Also, there is no shame in screwing up â€“ the beauty of this game is you can have 300h in it and still die in a stupid way. 
You are given many tools to aid you. You can always farm some souls and level up yourself or your gear before moving on. You can experiment with your playstyle and build. There is pretty much no best armor or best weapon here (except for some cheesy magic builds I heard of), just play around and find whatâ€™s best for you.
And your biggest help might be the multiplayer feature. You can summon other players (or AI characters) to help you fight a boss you have trouble with. The MP also works in more subtle ways: players can leave messages to each other on the floor, helping you find treasure or warning you of some danger. This can also troll you and make you roll into the wall repeatedly, but hey, itâ€™s part of the charm. 
DS has some mechanics that arenâ€™t really explained to the player, you have to google them on your own. Many people will probably say â€œitâ€™s part of the difficulty and mystery of the game, itâ€™s good!â€. But man, I think things such as Equip Load couldâ€™ve been explained a little better.

The remaster is my first encounter with the game, so I wonâ€™t be comparing anything here. The game looks good and has a great aesthetic. Environments are amazing, so are the enemy and boss designs. Really, solely how the bosses look like can tell you a little about their story (Artorias having a broken arm). The world is dying in this game, itâ€™s basically medieval fantasy apocalypse. Many foes once great and powerful, now are sick, wounded or lost their former power. They still will give you a hard time though. Anor Londo might be the greatest visual achievement here â€“ not many game locations will leave that kind of impression. It only grows on you when you uncover its secrets.

The music is an interesting thing in Dark Souls. Overall, many times itâ€™s not there. You just hear your tired footsteps, undead yelling, sounds of combat struggle. That makes the moments when music appears all the more powerful. There are only a few locations with background music. The boss themes not only are intimidating and adequately convey the fact that youâ€™re going to get your ass handed to you in a moment, but often they give off more specific feelings. â€œKnight Artoriasâ€ is menacing, but then it tries to tell you the tragedy of the character. Gwynâ€™s theme should be the biggest and most bombastic track of all â€“ itâ€™s the final boss battle. Instead, itâ€™s just this melodic, melancholic piano.

Itâ€™s not easy. You have to fail; you must learn the game and it requires a lot of patience and resolve. In the end though, itâ€™s not only worth braving the darkness for the sense of satisfaction, but also for the incredible world building.
 
(additional thoughts in the comments, because itâ€™s hard to do DS justice in a short review and Steam has character limit apparently)

Decided to get this after really enjoying my time with Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring.  Regret it.  While I'm sure people have their nostalgia for it, playing it now it's just frustrating.  Bonfires miles and miles apart, sluggish and unreliable rolling, bad UI, tiny ladders hanging off of ledges the width of your foot that you're lucky if you see, enemies absolutely able to stunlock you on that 2 minute run back to the boss.  

As far as remasters goes, it's really not that remastered and not worth the inflated price.  We've seen how good remasters can be, this just has some "HD" paint slathered on top and 60fps.

But what about the fights?  If you're like me and have seen tons of fanart of the bosses and the communities love for them....they also aren't worth it.  Most bosses just use 3 or 4 different attacks and the strategy is to just hug them and swing because the rolling just sucks, they're really anti-climactic.

I'm glad this game lead to other amazing games but it's just not worth going back to it unless you really like FromSoft games and you're idea of difficulty is artificial and needlessly annoying.

While an important game in FromSoftware's history, the game itself is not worth the money or time of the player. It is riddled with bad design decisions and while it can be fun, most of the time it's just frustrating and tedious. Examples include:

- Sparse respawn points; dying makes you go over the same spot again and again. This makes the game "grindy" without the actual benefit of the grind.
- No explanation of game mechanics and poor UI, which artificially raises the difficulty and prompts players to lose time or make bad decisions. I think this is one of the biggest problems of this game; once you learn the mechanics and few other gimmicks, the game becomes much easier (which further proves this point).
- Slow movement which feels unresponsive and frustrating at times.
- Artificial difficulty introduced through poor mechanics, such as "darkness" (which also makes the level feel longer then it really is), invisible pathways, sparse spawn points again or enemies waiting all day in that small nook behind a corner for an off chance that player comes by.
- Jumping mechanics are just atrocious, but sometimes required to reach certain places.
- "quests" which depend on player doing random stuff with no indications of what to do (people with stockholm syndrome might call it storytelling).
- Blighttown, 'nuff said.
- Price (worth 10$ tops).

If you are a big fan of FromSoftware's games, I still would not recommend to buy it. Watch youtube playthroughs, it's going to be way cheaper and more fun. If you still want to play it after going through a playthrough you might enjoy it more now that you know the gimmicks that artificially inflate the difficulty.

I finished the game only to be able to say I finished it. It wasn't very enjoyable experience and a lot of my struggles came from the game not explaining itself (which can be mitigated a bit by reading wiki/guides). I only enjoyed about a quarter of my time there; most of the game is dying in stupid ways due to some of the flaws listed above. And after all that time final boss fight was anticlimactic, easy and the ending disappointing. I recommend their later games; the more the improved on their formula, the better it gets.  

I definitely do not recommend this game and regret wasting my time on it.

My opinion on Dark Souls is not important. You don't need me to say "this game is good." Saying "Dark Souls is a good game" is like saying "the first world war was very important" or "the ocean is very wet." Even if I hated Dark Souls, it would still go on being a good game, entirely independent of my opinion.

But, fine. If you need to see the words: Dark Souls is a good game. Still! It's still good, even though there are other games that are like it that are also good. You should play it. Even if you looked at it and was like "nah, not my deal" or "I hear that's hard, I don't like stressful games"... no. Unfortunately, your opinion on Dark Souls matters as little as mine does. It's still a good game. You should still play it. Because for all the things you and I might believe ABOUT Dark Souls, the only way to find out if you like the game is to play the game. There are reasons everyone says it is a good game. If you need to, wait for a sale. But try it.

You owe it to yourself to try.

And if you hate it anyway, play Elden Ring, it's prettier.

I tried this game in preparation for Elden Ring over a year ago and stopped at Blighttown. It being my first soulsborne, it was truly an experience filled with wonder and rage. One example of wonder would be me taking the lift under the first bell tower. One example of rage would be the walk back to the Taurus Demon. That is probably the most mad I had been at a video game in a very long time, but being more well versed in these types of games now, I look back on it and laugh.

Coming back over a year later, and after beating Elden Ring, I must say this game has so much to offer. The only stipulation being that you are willing to put in the time to learn the game, and to get better. Coming into the game I had so much drive. I wanted to beat every Dark Souls before Elden Ring came out, just to have that experience. just to not even get halfway through the first game before calling it quits. After giving it a second go and completing it, I will say that you shouldn't throw in the towel, or you're going to miss out on one of the greatest gaming journeys I've been on. 

This game, for newcomers, will beat you down over and over again. The game, for players who have played before, will beat you down over and over again (but more fun this time).

As of right now, I'm early on my Dark Souls 2 playthrough and I can only hope that it, and Dark Souls 3, can hold a candle to the greatness that is Dark Souls 1.

Every soul has its dark, remastered

"Dark Souls Remastered" is a true masterpiece that delivers an unparalleled gaming experience. The updated visuals breathe new life into this iconic title, making the bleak and atmospheric world even more immersive. The intricate level design and challenging combat system are as captivating as ever, ensuring that every victory feels incredibly rewarding. From the hauntingly beautiful soundtrack to the unforgettable boss battles, "Dark Souls Remastered" oozes ambiance and excellence. The game's intricate lore and cryptic storytelling invite players to delve deep into its dark and mysterious universe. For both veterans and newcomers, this remastered edition is the definitive way to explore the unforgettable world of Lordran, making it a must-play for any avid gamer.

My introduction to anything soulsbourne or souls-like was Elden Ring, followed by Sekiro.  Feeling inspired, I decided to take on the classic trilogy, starting with Dark Souls I.  Being a much earlier game, you can tell the graphics and gameplay were still in their "working out the kinks" process, but that doesn't stop this game from being a masterpiece.  It may not have the open-world aspect that Elden Ring or match it's beauty in world design, but it is truly a work of art.  The way the world is all linked together and the main storyline are what drive this game and I'm all for it.  I definitely need a guide for a few parts to see where to go next, but other than that, the game is fairly linear without forcing the player to make one decision or another.  I, personally, found this game  lot easier than I was expecting (thank you, Sekiro), but that allowed me to focus less on grinding to prepare for a boss fight and more on the story that I'm experiencing.  Overall, this is a 10/10 game.  Takes a little bit of getting used to with a fairly steep learning curve, but I highly recommend it to anyone wanting to enjoy a classic.

I really enjoyed this game. I played hollow knight, and my first run of that took 300+ hours. I think if you want more bang for your buck, that is a better dollar-per-game-time ratio, at least for me.

Despite only taking me 1/10th of the time to complete, I think I enjoyed this game just as much. It is rough around the edges, very cryptic, and I found myself looking up guides a lot, but I still loved every second of it. I would personally recommend finding a friend who has unreasonable amounts of playtime, and asking them for cryptic hints, probably a more comedic and immersive experience.

TLDR: This game is an unfun, dated piece of trash. I am genuinely surprised that Fromsoft decided to continue the Dark Souls trilogy after making this offense to gaming.

Dark Souls Remastered was some of the least fun I have ever had in gaming. A mixture of terrible combat, horrendous level design, awful bosses, and ugly graphics come together to create an overall garbage experience.

Let's begin with the combat. Wow, it's bad. Like really bad. When I played I tried almost every build. While the weapons were different, they all had one thing in common. They felt like shit to use. I tried straight swords, greatswords, curved greatswords, katanas, rapiers, axes, spears. I even fucking tried bows if you can believe it. EVERYTHING FELT LIKE SHIT TO USE! I ended up settling on a pure magic build. While magic still felt overall bad to use, it was the best option because it got rid of a lot of the bad mechanics that plagued melee weapons. One of the main issues that I had with the melee combat was the fact that if a pixel of your weapon made slight contact with a wall, it would stagger you. Enemies did not suffer from this which lead to bullshit situations where you were not able to hit enemies if they happened to be in a tight hallway or something similar to that. This is just one of the many things that really stood out to me. Combat was generally unsatisfying and clunky.

Next, letâ€™s go over the level design. I donâ€™t even know where to begin with this. With the exception of maybe Undead Burg and Undead Parish (the first couple of areas of the game), the levels of this game are laughably bad. Itâ€™s honestly kind of impressive that they managed to make a world this terrible to traverse. I wouldnâ€™t be surprised if they held some sort of contest when making this game to see who could make the worst level. I know I keep going on and on about the level design, but itâ€™s actually that bad. Blighttown, Senâ€™s Fortress, Anor Londo, New Londo Ruins, The Dukeâ€™s Archives, The Catacombs, GODDAMN NEARLY EVERY FUCKING AREA IS DOGSHIT! I kept telling myself that there was no way that the next area could be worse than the last and I was wrong every time. The only redeeming quality about the world/level design is how they link a few areas back to Firelink Shrine. They only do this about three or so times that I can remember though.

Finally, letâ€™s end this negative review by talking about maybe the most important part of a Dark Souls game, the bosses. If you were hoping for me to say something positive about this, sorry they are bad too. I guess you can say they fit the vibe of the level they are in. Sadly the vibe of each level in this game is ass. The best bosses in this game are mediocre and the worst ones are downright offensive. Capra Demon and The Bed of Chaos are genuinely some of the worst bosses Iâ€™ve seen in gaming. Bosses that generally get praised in the Dark Souls community such as Ornstein + Smough and Great Wolf Sif are barely any better.  

Dark Souls Remastered consists of bad combat, garbage level design, and unfun bosses. I am absolutely flabbergasted, fucking astounded, that some people consider this the best game in the trilogy. I feel like Fromsoft should come to my house and apologize that they made this mess that I played through. I would not recommend this game unless you dislike fun, or if you just want bragging rights saying that you beat the game.

I'm sure once I play DS3 and Elden Ring again I'll remember how much better they are then this LOL but I had a really good time with this game. The first hour or so I hated it but after that I enjoyed (almost) every second, even though there's a LOT of jank that is absolutely awful lol. Like I love how the whole world is connected, but not being able to teleport between bonfires for the first half of the game sucks. There is also a lot of areas that I absolutely dread thinking about, but there's also so many memorable parts and places and so many things I really enjoyed seeing in DS3 as well. Also the co-op system is so awful, like you need a humanity (equivalent to an ember in DS3/furlcalling finger remedy in Elden Ring) but you need to scroll through the awful menu to find it, and once you use it, you need to sit down at the bonfire just to be able to actually activate it..and it's quite limited at the start but eventually you get a reliable source of it.. But even though this version of dark souls 1 is "Remastered" it still has its issues and jank and you can just tell its old lol. I definitely recommend playing this game solo, and I'm sure this game might be better if we had a lot more QOL changes from DS3 and Elden Ring, but regardless I really think Dark Souls 1 is one of the best!

The Dark Souls of Dark Souls games. 

What I would consider the last seminal release of the AAA video game industry, a one-of-a-kind title even the original developer can't seem to fully re-capture the magic of. The cornerstone and main highlight of the game is the world and level design, everything is interconnected with multiple paths to reach different places with numerous shortcuts to help progression and ease backtracking. With no fast travel in the game until the last 20% or so this gives the game an incredible sense of immersion. 

Further helping with the game's immersion is its sparse use of music, reserving its sparse tracks for the games boss fights and only 4 in game areas; the only thing you will hear throughout most of this game is your own footsteps and the sounds of your environment. While there isn't much music each track is memorable, Gywn's theme, Firelink Shrine's theme and Sif's theme being highlights. 

Combat in this game is weighty where every action you make needs to be deliberate to succeed. Dark Souls difficulty is a bit of a meme, especially in the case of DS1 where the original PC release had the "Prepare to Die" subtitle. The game isn't really difficult, it just punishes bad behaviors and not thinking through what you're doing both in exploration and combat. Being too aggressive in combat and not watching your stamina will get you killed in enemy encounters. At the same time spamming dodges without paying attention to enemy patterns will also get you killed. While dodging has generous invincibility enemies will mix up their attack timing, delaying swings and changing patterns. You need to pay attention to both your opponent(s) and your surroundings and adjust each of your actions accordingly. 

For PVE the game is very balanced and offers numerous ways to build and outfit your character. Certain builds will struggle more with certain boss fights and situations but excel at others offering a lot of ways to play and replayability. Between the original release and the remaster I've played 4 very different builds and had a fun and interesting time with each. And despite not being able to re-spec a character on an individual playthrough the game has a ton of replay value with its varied quests, ambitious NG+ features and actually challenging (and farming heavy) achievements. 

While the story is pretty simple, the world's lore and overall tone of the game is incredibly engrossing. At the start of the game, you are given a good baseline of why your character is doing what they're doing and a broad foundation of the world you find yourself. However, by observing your environment for context clues and reading item descriptions you'll find a rich, in-depth lore that lets you have fun filling in the blanks yourself. This is complimented by countless memorable NPC, enemy, environment and weapon designs that still hold up all these years later. 

The remaster is generally an improvement, which with how poor the original PC port was isn't really a great accomplishment. The only major negative is that by changing the lighting system to a more "realistic" one the high contrast art style of the original is partially lost making some select areas and enemies look pretty bland compared to the original version of the game. The game still does look good overall however and you wouldn't really notice it unless you were very familiar with the original release. 

As for flaws with the game itself, I feel there are only 2 major ones. The first is that the games netcode is abysmal, PVP in all forms it takes is more funny than something that's really engaging because of how bad the rubberbanding and stuttering can be. Considering this a remastered re-release itâ€™s disappointing nothing was done to address this issue that plagued the original (and all its sequels). Co-op is more forgiving in this regard, however if you are not the host there is still a good chance you can get a bad connection and just end up in a laggy, rubberbanding hell where none of your inputs will be read and acknowledge by the game until 10 seconds after you've pressed them. That being said there is no real reason you need to engage with the online functions of the game outside of trying to get certain covenant rewards. While the idea of invading or protecting other players' games sounds neat in concept the netcode makes it more of a headache in practice. That being said, all of this is entirely optional, you opt-in to the games online function by using an in-game consumable that basically gives you a status effect that enables the online functionality for you. So, by simply not using this item you never have to interact with these parts of the game. The less online intrusive elements like soap-stone messages and player ghosts are still as novel and enjoyable as they were at the time of release, however. 

The second flaw is the covenant system itself. Covenants are in game allegiances that offer certain rewards by ranking them up, normally through collecting certain items and engaging with some form of PVP or co-op. While the concept itself is fine none of these covenants explain how they work or what they reward when you find them in game. While a lot of stuff in Dark Souls is intentionally vague for lore or immersion reasons there is no reason for a player character to blindly join a covenant without being told what their about or what they offer to the player and is immersion breaking in itself. Outside of that this lack of explanation just leaves the player confused and forced to look up information online. This is something that could easily be fixed with in game dialogue from covenant heads or even info in the game menu when interacting with a covenant head. 

Now while I see these as flaws, they are both essentially optional systems (game is fully playable offline and you are never forced to interact with covenants), so they don't hamper the overall experience of the game. If you've not played it before I strongly recommend experiencing it, this is a classic title I grow to appreciate even more as time passes.

Started with Elden Ring, going back and playing through all the Souls games minus Demon's Souls/Bloodborne because I don't have a Playstation, surely it'll come to PC soon right? My only frame of reference so far for Soulslikes is Elden Ring so if you don't like me comparing the two then stop reading.

I find it rather interesting that a lot of the DNA in Elden Ring can be found here in the original (sans Demon's Souls) in that there are a lot of diverging paths and exploration is on some level free-form. I was expecting a mostly linear experience but found it was actually pretty open-ended which was really neat, and stumbling randomly across new areas when I was just expecting a dead-end with some item was fantastic. The whole "if you're stuck somewhere go some place else" idea is present here as well, although the lack of fast travel until O&S ended up being really annoying for backtracking.

I was expecting to be more annoyed by the massive walks of shame but I got pretty used to them quickly. There are some that are more egregious than others, but the game teaches you to be patient and slow when exploring, so taking time to go back to the boss room wasn't as frustrating (unless I had to go through annoying enemies to get there.) The walks in this game make the run back to Placidusax look like child's play, since while it's pretty long with that fight, you can at least run past a lot of the enemies whereas in this game you often are pretty much forced to fight them unless you want to get stabbed in the back.

PvP is just as bad as Elden Ring, tried it out for a bit, and got teleport backstabbed by a gravekeeper UGS that one-shot me three times in a row before I gave up on trying to guess where he was on his screen due to latency. Speaking of, it's really neat and interesting to me that there are so many different PvP factions that often have unique mechanics. Makes me wonder what it was like in the hayday at peak activity. Kinda rare to get invaded in my playthroughs.

Damage scaling was a nice surprise but it took me one bricked build to realize that vigor is a stat you basically don't have to invest in for half the game. I got stuck on Moonlight on my first playthrough because my ZDPS dex build was failing to 6-round him and it was getting annoying. Read a thread that said you should be 3-rounding him and that re-speccing isn't in the game and got the hint. On my second I basically didn't even level Vigor at all for like half the game.

This game does Dual Bosses right which is a shame since Elden Ring seems to have deeply forgotten this methodology of design. O&S might be one of my favorite bosses now and it's comical to compare it to the foreskin duo in ER. That being said, while boss design in some respects is better, some are just kind of... bad? Capra Demon stands out to me since he's really aggressive and in a tiny room with two dogs that also rush you down, so there's basically nowhere to run and heal. Sure, you can just adapt by playing aggressive and using shield instead of trying to heal off all damage, but I can't help but feel like this fight would be more fun if you had A LITTLE more space between the enemies before they were on you and the arena were maybe... twice as large. with another arena that size placed horizontally? I don't know.

idk how to finish this off, I'll just say Claymore is my baby (love the rolling two-handed R1) and it's insane how they only have one ring slot in the game since one of them is permanently taken up by Ring of Favor and Protection. Moving on to Dark Souls 2 next, surely it can't be that bad right?

Have played through this game 2 times and the OG edition almost to completion a while ago. I quit my first time as I was not enjoying the whole feel of the game at all (I started out with DS2 back in the day and played that and DS3 before 1 which was a big reason for this) as it feels a bit slow and stiff nowadays. But I forced myself through eventually with DS1 R. I did not have alot of fun that time either, and especially in the second half as I did not even enjoy the gameplay, which is basically what carries that part of the game.

But this most recent time I actually had alot of fun which kind of surprised me. I do think it is due to me finally finding a weapon and playstyle that I actually enjoyed with the slower more deliberate gameplay. Earlier I went with dex/quality builds but this time I went full Zweihander and had so much more fun. Also inspired me to do a full playthrough of the series with Zweihander which I am currently very much enjoying.

The game itself is basically split into two parts. Everything up until Anor Londo is basically why this game is regarded as a masterpiece. More so in gameplay and the progression, as I do think the bosses are a bit of a mixed bag, even throughout the whole game in fact with not alot of truly great ones. But dang if the level design is not just incredible, and also the atmosphere. But the second half is actually kind of terrible. Bosses go from pretty good to the absolute worst I have met in a game and the levels are super uninspired in their design. The saving grace in the late game is the DLC which I think have the best bosses in the game by far (Artorias is really fantastic). I do not blame people for not getting through the second half (like myself lol), but I do think it is worth it in the end to get through it all.

Luckily I enjoyed the gameplay way more this time which made that second half much more enjoyable for me. Has very much opened up my eyes more why people still insist the first one is the best, even though it is such a flawed game. I still do not agree as DS3 is still my favorite due to it being great throughout, but at least I now like both DS1 and 2 the same (OG, not SotFS) as they both even out to a similar enjoyment level to me in the end (I liked DS2 way more than 1 back in the day, but I know that can be due to alot of nostalgia) I also think I would rather replay this than DS2 due this game being quite short in comparison. Pretty sweet game and series ofc.

This was my first Souls game. I had a really hard time getting into it. So much so that it took me three rage-uninstalls and four brand-new characters to finally commit to a full playthrough. But boy, when it clicked, it CLICKED. This is, in my opinion, one of the greatest games ever made. 

Pros:
-The level design is probably the greatest ever in gaming history. Every single area is a memorable experience. The game also rewards exploring these unique areas by giving you items, NPCs to talk to, and shortcuts that make your way to the boss easier and faster. 
-The enemy design, of both the common enemies and the bosses, is masterfully done. All of the bosses are unique. They look badass and creepy. 
-The soundtrack is amazing. I sometimes visit Firelink Shrine just to chill and listen to music.
-This is a FromSoft game. So, naturally, the combat is the strongest point of the game. It's rewarding and extremely fun. Getting better after every try against a boss and finally defeating them after hours of trial and error is the most satisfying thing I have ever experienced in any game I have ever played.

Cons:
-Some areas have just a little bit too much bullsh*t. Sometimes it can be helpful to just put the game down, clear your mind, and come back the next day when you feel frustrated about some of that bullsh*t. 
-The game can be too vague at times. [spoiler] Accessing the DLC is an entire quest for no reason at all. I also remember needing to check a guide to find the door that went to the Lower Undead Burg after running around like a mad man trying to find a big door. [/spoiler] But 95% of the time, the game will reward your exploration, and you will eventually find a way to progress.

Dark souls a game that puts you into tough challenges, tip always spend your souls after you win large chunks of fights or bosses, DO NOT HORDE them, unless your level is higher. It can bite you back if you get to confident.

Also be warned new coming players.
Players with larger hours on the game will invade you with 99 humanity, fully upgraded armor and weapons, at a low level. 

They are called twinks, Run back to the closest bonfire and jump off the cliff, you can block them through the steam player recent play list, to never be invaded by them again, They completely ruin anything PVP wise, you will get one shotted no matter what. You can also deny them by entering boss rooms.

If those are looking for a solo experince to ignore it, set your game offline, but this removes message and bloodsplats, same for co-op summons.

It's... Dark Souls. Amazing level design for the first half of the game, shame the second half was rushed. 
Don't pick thief or master key on your first playthrough, those two things will ruin the sense of exploration and unlocking paths through the world.
Don't level resistance. Every stat you level increases your resistance to almost every damage type.

Dark Souls.

The worst great videogame I have ever played.

Do you want to to fight your way through poison swamps, treacherous cliffs, and lava lakes, all whilst only being able to dodge in 4 directions. Do you want to get lost, wonder what the hell you are supposed to do to progress, only to figure out you need to spend 20,000 souls, kill a giant wolf, and loot some dead guys grave just to get a ring that lets you fall through a very dark pit? Do you want to fight two bosses at once, or one incredibly frustrating flaming tree? Do you want to fall off of cliff after cliff after cliff, or get stuck in a corner and beat to death. Do you hate dogs? Do you like big booby women? Do you hate yourself? Do you love torture.

If you answered all of these questions with "Yes, I DO!", rethink your life. If that doesn't fix you, play dark souls.

I've played hundreds of hours on several platforms. Even after all these years, I still find it to be one of the best games of all time. The level design, the lore, the in-game ambience and mood; few games compare to it. It's punishing to the reckless and rewarding to the ones who persevere. Dark Souls is a tightrope-walk between dread and blissful elation.

As a kid, I had a very dark soul, and the shadows of loneliness enveloped me. My solitary existence was my constant companion, leaving me feeling like an outsider in a world that I perceived as unrelentingly harsh. My solace came from Limp Bizkit's music, whose angsty tunes resonated deeply with my troubled soul. Fred Durst's raw and emotional lyrics were the soundtrack to my life, speaking to the darkness that consumed me.

But then, I discovered Dark Souls Remastered on Steam, a game that would alter the course of my journey. Just like Limp Bizkit's intense music, the game plunged me into a world of shadows, challenging me at every turn. It felt like I was confronting the abyss within me, just as Limp Bizkit's lyrics had done for years.

The brutal difficulty and relentless enemies in Dark Souls Remastered taught me lessons that Limp Bizkit's music couldn't. It was a reflection of my own life â€“ failures, setbacks, and relentless struggles. And much like Limp Bizkit's music, the game showed me that even in the darkest moments, there are glimpses of light.

The game's intricate level design and hauntingly beautiful landscapes hinted at the hope that I'd never allowed myself to see before. It was as if Fred Durst's lyrics had come to life in the game, reminding me that even the darkest souls have pockets of brightness.

Just like Limp Bizkit's music served as my therapy, Dark Souls Remastered became my escape and a source of inspiration. It helped me confront the abyss within my soul and provided the strength to overcome it. I realized that, much like Limp Bizkit's music, there's redemption even in the darkest corners of life.

As I write this review, I can't help but draw parallels between my life, Limp Bizkit's music, and Dark Souls Remastered. They've all been essential in guiding me from darkness to light, proving that even the darkest souls can be remastered and can have spaces where it's bright and light sometimes.

TLDR: Limp Bizkit's music, like Dark Souls Remastered, shines a light on the darkest corners of the soul. Both have shown me that even the darkest souls can find redemption, just like Limp Bizkit's lyrics resonate in the darkest moments of life.

So the hours posted here are wrong. I've been playing this game way longer, but I originally was on Xbox. I actually have around 900 hours in this game, but regardless I'm not here to brag about playtime. I'm here to review one of my favorite games of all time, while also shitting on how this is a horrible remaster. This game, as a lot of people know, is absolutely amazing. From its interconnected world, to its methodical and intricate combat, this game is a joy. I don't want to go way too in depth over the game itself, as this is the REMASTERED version, not the original. All you really need to know is if you're considering Dark Souls, then buy it and give it a shot. Worst case scenario you can refund it if it's not for you! If this is up your alley, however, then prepare yourself for a magical experience until you kill O&S and it goes down to being just a pretty good experience (then it becomes a masterpiece then with Artorias of the Abyss). One other thing, though, this is a wiki game. Just like games like Terraria and Barotrauma, this game wants you to look at the wiki and learn about it, as it's super convoluted. Don't feel ashamed for checking out the wiki!
Anyways, onto the remastered part: it sucks. I wasn't lucky enough to get PtDE before it got delisted, but looking at comparisons they are next to the same thing given you install a performance mod for PtDE that is widely available and easy to use. If you own PtDE, this game is just as dead so don't bother getting it for the multiplayer. This was how I got started as a sunbro, but it's dead now just like the original. As with the Vampire Survivors review, I won't be putting a number score here because number scores are BS in my opinion, but my overall verdict is that it's still Dark Souls I, but if you already own another version of DS1 then don't bother.

Hard at first. But with each boss you kill, each enemy you slaughter, and with each time you yourself are ended. you will begin to learn the tells of a swing and the spacing of your sword. you will scrape at bosses until you grovel out a victory, you will make death runs until you can do it with your eyes closed, you will kill the same enemies over and over again. But for what you ask? It certainly is not fun to die and run back just to do it again. Well my friend, its when you first learn to parry the black knights, when you finally kill that one boss, when you find the coolest looking Armour, when you forge a great weapon out of souls and sweat, when after you have fought tooth and nail you come out on top. This game is great because its hard and unforgiving, This game is great because even though it was hard and unforgiving you didn't give up. Its great because it challenges you and respects the efforts you put into it. --- In short, I recommend this game to any who have not dared to play something so challenging, because it will show you what you can do if you really try. ---

What if you built an entire game around the respawn? What if THE RESPAWN were a game mechanic? I donâ€™t know if this game is for me. Iâ€™m trying, but I feel as if the game punishes me for exploration. Combat is so rigid and tanklike, but not impossible. Still, every enemy does enormous damage and takes so many hit points to defeat. Took me a few tries to beat the first boss, but I did it. Everything after that has been so awkward. I meet skeletons, but fighting them is not worth it. What Iâ€™m reading about the game says itâ€™s damn near impossible to conquer it without taking tips from the community, which tells me to avoid combat as much as possible and collect items instead. But what are these items? Why am I collecting them?

Why are minor enemies such a MAJOR EVENT to fight? Challenge stems from the clunky combat controls instead of anything deliberate. When I die, often itâ€™s because the game didnâ€™t respond when I wanted to roll, or didnâ€™t block when I pushed the button. So far Iâ€™m not enjoying this, all of these stats and items. Why canâ€™t I assign a throwing item to a quick slot for easy use? I canâ€™t explore without facing enemies I canâ€™t defeat. I canâ€™t fight. I canâ€™t outrun most of the enemies. What am I doing?

The whole game seems to be built around the idea of respawning: the game will kill you over and over, but thatâ€™s ok because you can just go back and figure out how to proceed from there. [b]When I progress, I donâ€™t feel as if Iâ€™m getting better at the gameâ€™s internal logic, rather that Iâ€™m bypassing the game.[/b] What is the point of combat if youâ€™re not supposed to fight most of the enemies? So far, I am not a fan of Dark Souls.

100% completed. Excellent game for people wanting a challenge; reminds me quite a bit of Hollow Knight. It's very fun and worthy of spending many days on to fully complete its storyline and maybe even go above and beyond with the achievements. I will admit, however, I feel like there's a lot of functions in this game that's left unexplained and likely will leave the player to have to research things. There are a few places you need to go that can't be unlocked until you get certain things (which aren't specified), in order to cast pyromancies/miracles/sorceries you need to have the appropriate conduit wielded (which wasn't explained), the stats at the start aren't elaborated on nor is there really an option to see what they affect, and I had no idea until about halfway into my first playthrough that there are different paths you can ascend your weapons to (i.e. lightning, magic, fire, etc.). So unless you know a lot about Dark Souls in advance before playing, you may have some trouble figuring some things out throughout the game. However, these downsides are not enough to get me to dislike the game. It was incredibly fun even with these quirks. I highly would recommend purchasing this game, and maybe the others in the series too :)

I remember having first played this a few years ago back on the Xbox 360. I wasn't able to make it past the bell gargoyles, and actually was sorta hardly able to make it past the Taurus demon.

Well, that's changed this time around, I've finally beaten the game! It only took, what, 55 hours? I'm sure if I ever play it again, that it'll take maybe half the time. 

My thoughts on the game are vastly different than they were when I was playing this on my old 360; I had thought the game was wayyyy too difficult. Now I think that it's an experience of a game that most of everyone should play, or at least try to. The first half at least, the second half is certainly... Something. The whole game takes a noticeable drop of quality after Anor Londo, a criticism I'm sure that everyone under the sun remotely interested in DS1 has heard. If the entire game was built like the second half was, I'm sure that this game wouldn't have made as big of a ripple across the entire gaming scene as it did, in fact I'm positive it would have killed this entire series, and with it the souls-like genre.

But yeah, almost perfect game.

Honestly, I fucking hate this game. It's my least favorite Fromsoft game that I've played. It's not necessarily a bad game but a large part of the difficulty meme for this specific game is based off of how janky everything is. Hitboxes and collision are insanely inconsistent, my character would randomly fall off of rounded surfaces during platforming segments and then there's wild things like enemies backstabbing you from the side while you're in mid-air. A lot of the maps in this game are horribly designed (fuck whoever designed Tomb of Giants) and some enemies are extremely unbalanced. I've played through DS1 multiple times and every playthrough feels the same, the game is hard and frustrating because of it's legitimate difficulty but a larger part of it is the poor design. It would  be nice to see this get a proper remake like Demon Souls received.

While I don't particularly like playing this specific entry in the Dark Souls series I have to admit that it's my favorite in terms of its plot and its significance in the overall DS continuity. I don't hate this game I just think it needs a lot of polishing before I would call it an amazing game. I'm glad future titles were more refined than the previous iterations.

Overall, play it for the memes but DS2 is better.

Dark souls is my first fromsoft game and boy has it completely changed my view on gaming.
This game would break your soul, your controller and maybe even your monitor, and its worth each one of those things. its a once in a lifetime experience. To think that a game released 13 years ago, would not only stand up to modern gaming standards, but far surpass it, tells you all there is to know about this one.

the good - 

The NPCs of this game are some of the best ones i have encountered in any game. You almost start to connect with them and root for them to achieve their targets.

the combat is by far the best combat mechanics i have ever experienced. I was playing lies of P and dark souls side by side, and it is mind blowing how this 13 year old games combat matched, if not surpassed, the latest edition of soulslike on the market.

the bosses - some of the best. you need to strategise and analyse each one of them and plan your attacks accordingly. gives one a weird feeling of achievement for defeating a virtual enemy.



the bad -
that being said, the game is EXTREMELY frustrating. there are very few checkpoints and for some bosses you need to fight a dozen soldiers before you get a shot at them again. but its all about getting it.. once you get it - believe me this game would still beat your ass and humble you : D.

looking forward to the second and third iterations of this game!

One of the best games ever, and nearly a masterpiece.

Ever played Zelda? Do you remember that feeling of adventure and discovery you experienced in those games? Well, dial that feeling up a notch and add in a lot of brutality. In short, that's Dark Souls.

With tons of interesting weapons and cool armour to choose from, you can come up with so many new builds to always keep the game fresh.

Even to this day the PVP scene is alive and well and I regularly get into tons of thrilling, often nail-biting matches with other players.

And unfortunately on rare occasion you do find cheaters, but overall, it's rare.

I cannot recommend this game enough, it is so much fun and extremely rewarding with its progression and challenges.
the original version was better ngl. but other than that, yes this game is good. Yes, play it!

was recommended after enjoying dark souls 3 a lot! sadly this game is barely a prototype to what became of the series by DS3, so much wrong with it. most bosses were simple and cheese-able and went down on the first try with little to no effort. most areas were uninspired and awfully designed which made exploring awful; poor pacing on bonfires and obscure spots for important entrances and exits helped keep meaningful progress to a minimum; and the ridiculously tedious runbacks to bosses that didn't immediately melt first try kept me from enjoying the experience entirely. hoping DS2 solves a lot of these issues - if it had properly placed bonfires and lets me warp between them right away, it will already be a better game. Overall I would give DSR a 4/10 - worst game fromsoft has made to date for sure.

edit: went back to finish all achievements, played nearly 50 extra hours across 3 NG cycles. i can safely say two things: 1) its a great game, and 2) ds2 and ds3 are far better experiences

I just can't recommend this. The developers did not finish the second half of the game and even in this remastered version the second half remains just as broken and unfinished as it was in 2011. 

.Certain bosses are very gimmicky and unfun to fight. (Ceasless discharge and Bed of Chaos)

.The lighting is considerably worse than on the PS3. (How did you manage that?!?)

.Some armour sets just don't look right and the colours are all messed up.

.Has very serious balancing issues where it can jump from being impossibly hard to way too easy.

.There are areas of the game that actually made me uninstall because of how unfinished they are. (Just put some enemies in a circle in the level editor and call it a day? Really?)

.Absolutely awful jumping mechanics that WILL get you killed.

I started my From Journey with Bloodborne, then played Elden Ring multiple times. I decided to take a journey back and play the original Dark Souls and it was rough. I straight up quit several times, uninstalling the game and yet each time I found myself a couple of days later reinstalling it. It took me well over a month to get through this game but the rewarding feeling I had when I finally completed it was well worth the frustration. Great game!

Man i really tried to like this game holy hell, but honestly everything about the game feels clunky, frustrating and tedious. Your attacks never hit how you want them too, controls are god awful with many things bound to the same few buttons (though i hear its much nicer on controller). constant backtracking for seemingly no reason, awful collision with enemies constantly blocking your path in tight spaces and your weapons bounce off walls so you can barely do anything about it.

Now i dont usually do reviews but im writing this mainly because i genuinely want someone to tell me why people like this game, none of the steam reviews say anything more specific than very general statements or just praising the difficulty, none of my friends who like the game can explain anything specific either. I think this game originally came out at a time when games were getting easier and all the reactionaries loved this game because it felt like a 90s game (probably the only game series for which saying it feels like its from the 90s is praise somehow), so it feels like people are more praising the game for some philosophical reasons rather than the actual gameplay itself. 

The only thing i hear people say is fun is "getting better" at the game but honestly when the gameplay is so clunky and tedious i feel like its more a case of needing to get better in order to even be able to progress in a game that is at it's core just a mediocre action game. And ok this may be the most problematic part of this review but honestly the game isn't even really difficult despite that being what everyone praises, as almost every death feels much more like you dying for some stupid reason and every time i'd die i wouldn't think something like "i need to read the enemies attack better" or "i need to be more precise in my movements", but instead something like "damn i was stuck in a corner and couldnt do anything against 3 enemies when i couldnt even swing my weapon without hitting a wall and got stunlocked to death".

I might be missing or not getting something in which case i'd happily let someone change my mind because it seems like all the aspects people praise is much more them coping than anything, with common praises being things like "it doesnt hold your hand", "it feels like a game from the 90s", "the game is challenging", but when you look at those statements none of the is praise its just a statement like the game has open exploration, feels dated and is tedious. Most people who praise the game just say something like "oh yeah youre just bad if you dont like it" or something of the sort but honestly ive played way harder games that were way more fun but the reason why those games were fun is because the core gameplay was always interesting, and it always felt fair and deserved, while dark souls 1 combat isn't particularly interesting and deaths feel more undeserved than anything, and the controls as well as not getting bored and impatient pose a bigger threat to you than the actual enemies in this game.

Honestly maybe its a sunk-cost thing, where you spend countless hours battling the controls and running through the same areas, and by the time you learn how to actually play the game, you make yourself believe youre having fun so as to not admit you wasted all that time on a mediocre game, and nobody wants to admit it so instead everyone just collectively decided to pretend to enjoy it or something and that all the bad game design is somehow actually incredible game design if you have 3 shots, squint your eyes really hard, and repeat the phrase "its hardcore" 99 times in front of a mirror.

I must admit however the one thing i can't comment on is the story and soundtrack since i definetly havent played enough to really get to see a lot of it so even though i don't find them anything special, ive definetly not progressed far enough to either hear the "good tracks" or witness the story or something. This is a pretty important point as i have many times played through games with awful controls and many tedious elements because the story and music were really good so i could see that changing my mind.

Once again, I ask someone to change my mind because i've genuinely tried really hard to get into these games and see anything positive but I just cannot, no matter how hard I try.

fixed issues: 
- jump is on L3 instead of Circle, which is also the key to run
- multiplayer: you can actually get summoned and summon this time; gravelording seems to be easier/working as well

not fixed issues: 
- fps issues: what would be small stutters in any 2018 game, like droping ~5fps brings the remaster down to 30fps, that feel like 10fps
**- jumping: the game originally was in 30 fps and if u play the PC version u get 60 fps, but the jump distance is halfed **(seems fixed, had no problem with the longer jumps on 2nd playthrough)
- lagging multiplayer (lagstab)
- multiple ledges/clipping environment still exist (ie great hollow, lost izalith, ...)
- alt tabbing still doesnt work: game will either refuse to switch tabs or go in windowed mode to do so, which you need to change in the options every time it happens

I've played all the other souls like games that From Software has made and I gotta say, Dark Souls 1 is one of the best experiences I've had. Its genius level design, chilling atmosphere and tragic story all play an insane role immersing and making you invested in the game. While its bosses (except O&S) aren't a big, difficult, spectacle like other From Soft games, they are still enjoyable and enable you to express your skill in different ways. 

It now makes sense as to why DS1 was always highly regarded by fans - it's the beginning of the souls trilogy and it's a banger.

If you get the game on sale then its worth a play if you're looking for a dose of fun. 

I will say, I don't understand the hype around this game. In all the other souls games I've played, I've rarely felt cheated or cheesed. I lost count of how many times I got hit my attacks I felt I dodged, got combo-ed by a boss or stun locked by normal enemies. With that being said, I did find myself laughing at some of these deaths and I did enjoy my time in Lordran.

Gonna try and do some pros and cons I had with the game I guess:

[h2]PROS[/h2]

- The bosses felt fair for the most part and all were fun to fight
- Enemies are relatively easy to dodge and backstab looping is always a blast
- Upgrade materials are readily available until late game, costing an appropriate amount of souls to buy and are dropped somewhat regularly from normal enemies
- The setting is great

[h2]CONS[/h2]

- The lack of early game fast travel leads to some fun instances where you spend 30 minutes running between areas of the map just to unlock the ability to upgrade your weapons more or to allow you to upgrade your flasks (since you can only carry one fire keeper soul at a time...)
- Boss run-backs are atrocious. I hope you enjoy running for 5-10 mins to get back to the boss and then spend 3 seconds fighting it before getting true combo-ed.
- Many areas felt barren or pointless, they were only there to add needless complexity or to add difficulty getting back to the bosses
- You need a consumable to kill certain enemies that costs 4000 souls (stupid ghosts in new londo)


Honestly, 7/10

Masterpiece ahead.

It took about 10 hours for the game to really click for me and that's when I started enjoying it. I really didn't like it at the start and didn't get the appeal. By now, I finally understand why people like the souls games. I still really dislike the PvP though. Having someone with 1k hours in the game just destroy you randomly sucks. At least you can entirely avoid this by just being hollow most of the time and only being human when you need it and don't care about dying.

Surprisingly, I haven't gotten super frustrated with this game. With the exception of PvP, when you die, it's at least 95% of the time your fault and it feels fair. Failure doesn't feel as bad when it was the result of your own actions. I get much angrier at multiplayer FPS games.

As for this being a "remaster," it's pretty much the same as the original game. Just a different lighting system that changes the game's feel in an overall negative way, but the game runs at a stable 60fps even at 4K resolution for me so it doesn't really matter as much. If it ran poorly AND looked dated, then I would have an issue with it.



For anyone who is reluctant to play the game or isn't enjoying it yet, all while likely being told to "git gud" by the gatekeepers of the community, just keep going. It'll take a while for it to click, but you'll steadily improve and your experience will get better alongside your skills. The game never lets up in terms of difficulty, but you'll get better at handling all of the doodoo feces it likes to throw at players until you can just clown on all the enemies. Don't be afraid to look at guides when needed if it makes the game better for you.

Best game ever

As you know by now, this is a great game with really good storytelling and world-building that is just waiting to be discovered.

After the tutorial stage, you are just left on your own to discover everything that the world has to offer. Everything in the world will try to get you, and you need to push back hard so that you won't get swept up and go hollow. The storytelling is cryptic, and you won't really get it unless you really start piecing together the story that comes from the item descriptions and the environment. But unlike some modern games, the story is worth the effort, and it is like a puzzle mini-game inside the game itself, so I enjoy it.

Combat feels much more basic, heavier, and strategic compared to its succeeding genre offshoots like Nioh and other games in the Dark Souls trilogy. I was literally thrown off at some point by how heavy the combat felt, and when I went back and played a session of Nioh, which revolves around fast-paced combat, I couldn't play the same fast-paced combat again. But this does not detract from the godly first experience that you will have in this game. The feeling of exploring some area where you feel that you can't escape and then finally finding a shortcut or a bonfire is exhilarating and fun. The environment will kill you most of the time, and that's fine with me because it adds to the experience [spoiler](except for Anor Londo Archers and Sen's Funhouse; those two will always be a nightmare for the first playthrough)[/spoiler].

This game encompasses all of my favorite things about video games. Good combat, an amazing story, the feel of discovery in an open world (technically, it is a semi-linear open world), and finally, an experience to remember. Overall, I really can't recommend this game enough; it is worth its full price, and you can get an even better deal if you buy it whenever it is on sale.

I started this game not expecting much since I had heard that some of it was really annoying to go through, but honestly I was pretty blown away. The interconnected world is genuinely amazing, and the fact that you can't warp to bonfires from the very beginning of the game like in Dark Souls III is very fun to me as the exploration aspect is awesome. Obviously there were some things I didn't like in the slightest (like Bed of Chaos but that's a given), however the majority of the game was really fun to go through. Especially the DLC's, since Artorias and Manus are great bosses. Overall I really recommend this game, it's pretty good.

Dark Souls is the best RPG I have ever played. Spent thousands of hours on PS3 and other platforms, making me a forever FROMSOFTWARE fan. Everything about the game is borderline perfect besides the dreaded ''walk of shame'' with certain bonfires. Some areas like Tomb of the Giants and Anor Londo for example, will have you restart the entire area and fight or run past hard hitting enemies if you die to the boss. Either wasting precious healing items or possibly dying and losing your blood stain in the boss arena. Making some areas incredibly frustrating and tedious. Besides that, this game is just amazing and I'll be playing it along with the other Souls-born games for years to come. Best RPGs ever.

Title: An Epic Return to Darkness - "DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED"

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…

"DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED" by FromSoftware, Inc. is a masterpiece that needs no introduction for fans of the souls-like genre. As a seasoned undead adventurer, I've delved into the abyss of Lordran once again, and this remastered edition is a testament to the timeless brilliance of the original game.

Graphically, "DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED" breathes new life into the dark and atmospheric world of Lordran. While it doesn't overhaul the visuals entirely, the improvements are significant. The enhanced lighting and textures make every corner of this grim, interconnected world more captivating than ever before. The character models and environments are more detailed, creating a more immersive experience while still preserving the iconic aesthetics that define the series.

Gameplay-wise, "DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED" remains the benchmark for challenging and rewarding gameplay. The combat mechanics are as tight and precise as ever, demanding mastery of weapon types, timing, and strategy. The sense of accomplishment when conquering formidable foes or navigating treacherous terrain is unmatched. The game's notorious difficulty is not arbitrary; it's a beautifully crafted challenge that forces you to learn and adapt, making each victory all the more satisfying.

The level design is, once again, a standout feature. Lordran is a sprawling, interconnected world filled with secrets, shortcuts, and hidden lore. The non-linear progression allows for diverse playstyles and encourages exploration, making it impossible to resist the urge to revisit areas and uncover every hidden gem. The world feels alive, brimming with mysteries waiting to be uncovered.

The online multiplayer aspect remains a unique and integral part of the experience. Jolly cooperation, tense invasions, and cryptic messages from other players continue to add an extra layer of depth and unpredictability to the game world. Whether you're seeking aid or plotting the downfall of other adventurers, the multiplayer interactions are a testament to the game's enduring appeal.

"DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED" is more than just a nostalgia trip; it's an essential upgrade for both newcomers and veterans alike. The technical enhancements, while not groundbreaking, improve the overall experience without compromising the game's original vision. It's a testament to FromSoftware's dedication to their fanbase and the legacy of this iconic series.

In conclusion, "DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED" is an unforgettable journey into a dark and challenging world that continues to stand the test of time. It's a must-play for anyone seeking an immersive, punishing, and ultimately rewarding gaming experience. Whether you're reliving the past or embarking on your first adventure, this remastered edition is a definitive way to experience the masterpiece that started it all. Praise the sun!

Genuinely think Manus is the most poorly designed boss except Bed of Cancer.

Overall he's a cool boss. Aggressive as he is, you could surely beat him after some trials and errors. There's even a huge opening on his left.
What gets my nerves is that "Manus quintuple combo". Unlike Soul of Cinder who has enough windup for you to escape, this thing is impossible to dodge at close range without blocking/light rolling. You can make the boss unfair, no recovery time, panic chug punishes, delayed attack or whatsoever, but if that one attack punishes melee players doing medium rolls, it's not a good design.

THIS GAME DESERVES A REMAKE, NOT THIS.

Did you ever played the original Silent Hill 2 for the PS2 and then years later bought the HD Collection and were like: "Wow!, this looks worse" well, I've got bad news for you, this "Remaster" makes SH2:HD look decent.

The special effects are better overall and the game runs at 60 fps so, there was a try, BUT, it feels like they improved that and at the middle of the way said: "that's it, we're done, the Remaster is complete". They implemented a new and better lighting system to the game so, the game must look better, right? Well, it  kills the original atmosphere in a lot of areas and also it makes almost everything look worse. For whatever reason a lot of armor sets and armor that the enemies are wearing look worse as if they directly tried to downgrade them. Some NPC's faces look better and less polygonal but most of them look worse. Then we've got the textures of the environment, a lot of them got improved but others look as if they tried to make them worse.

Only about 20% of the new stuff looks better than the original and for that I don't recommend it. If you have the original version just mod it so it runs at those magnificent 60 fps; if you don't, well, time for some heavy modding so this doesn't look like the downgraded version of the original.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
Gwynevere.
It's Dark Souls.
Musics are aight.
No performance issues.
Pretty good for the first game in the series
Open levels design which lead to surprise shortcuts.
Graphic is alright for a remaster of a really old game.
Really hard, probably the hardest one in the series, but* -> Cons.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
Inventory management is a nightmare, the UI is cursed, could have got a rework to be more like DS3.
No fast travel until half of the game, even then you can't fast travel to all bonfire, collecting items and running to vendors are very tedious.
Some of the worst boss designs in the entire series, some of them aren't even worth being called a boss.
Dated, slow combat, you can only dodge one time, chaining dodges isn't possible, you have to take a break after every dodge.
*Quite boring, bosses have like 5 attacks at best, combat play out like a turn-based game, boss attack -> you dodged -> you attack, rinse & repeat.
Your experiences may vary depends on which area you choose to go first, pick the wrong area and you'll want to uninstall the game, playing this game blind is the worst thing you could do which is the opposite of other games in the series and Elden Ring.

To sum up, it's a souls game with minimal enjoyment, much more boring and annoying to play unlike other games in the series but it's not a bad game that deserve a negative review, give us a Neutral option STEAM. Play this if you want to appreciate how far souls games have come otherwise ignore this game, you won't be missing out much.

The classic first installment that would kick start the entire Dark Souls trilogy.

Gameplay ages like fine wine, and while the graphics aren't obviously cutting edge now, the art direction carries it and still manages to be beautiful. The open level design is obviously what this game does better than the other souls games. But it is an inconsistent experience with a couple of questionable gameplay elements that is more inconvenient than challenging. If Dark Souls 3 is everything FromSoftware had learned fit into one condensed finely tuned package, then Dark Souls is the raw experience that crawled to let Dark Souls 3 run.

I would prefer rating this as "Neutral", but since I spent a lot of time with it, positive is fine.

So, let's start with the bad stuff:

[list]
   [*] Controls are clanky at times. I know the game is supposed to be slow and thoughtful while also reactive, but sometimes it just feels weird.

   [*] Bonfires. They're awesome in general, but 2 things I hate about them: 1. They're never (except one single time) right in front of a boss. Every god damn time, you after you die to a boss, which will happen, before fighting him again, you need to walk for 5 minutes. The way isn't a challenge anymore after you've done it 3 times. 2. Their warping ability. It's a great mechanic and I like that you get midgame and not from the beginning. But god damn you can only warp to a couple of them, so more walking... 

   [*] Stamina Bar. It's always annoying. Sure it is intended to make you think etc and be careful with your resources but there are better ways to solve this.

   [*] The skill system. Overall it's okay, but some details about it are strange. Resistance for example seems completely useless. Also, the higher your numbers get, the less they will increase. I already started NG+ and I had to do a lot of farming to actually feel a difference in my damage numbers. You also can't upgrade weapons further in NG+, so I guess you just have to hit more.

   [*] After a certain point, the game becomes less enjoyable IMO. To be precise: [spoiler] The new areas after you get the Lordvessel are not as exciting as the game is up to that point, Especially Lost Izalith/Demon Ruins and the Duke's Archive [/spoiler]

   [*] It is quite a task to compare items/equipment, expecially when you don't know what some of the stats are actually meaning. I mean these unusual stats are very nice and should be added to more RPGs, but overall it's not too easy to decide what to use or to even realize what's your best option. And not even to start with how you want to upgrade your stuff, especially weapons.
[/list]

But, that aside, there's also a lot of good stuff that kept me going:

[list]
   [*] Obviously the difficulty. It teaches you to be considerable about your actions. Not only in battle but also with the quests the game offers. It makes you learn what your enemies are doing so you can react accordingly. Every hit you take or deliver can be crucial.

   [*] Combat, even besides the difficulty, is awesome. You have a lot more weapon types than in typical RPGs, you can chose between wielding all of them one or two handed. You can choose to block, parry or dodge attacks. Although bows aren't really meant as a main weapon you can still use them occasionally. Magic is also a little weird, as your spells have limited uses and you don't have something like Mana. If you're out of spells, you have to have an alternative.

   [*] The world is great. You can visit basically like 90% of what you're seeing (except very far background), it's interconnected, not repetitive, atmospheric and interesting. I would like to see some more NPCs just to fill some places, but it's fine as it is. But the NPCs that are there already are very nice already.

   [*] Basically right from the beginning, you get awesome looking gear. At least for some classes/build, most weapons and armor look fantastic! You can actually start the game with fully fleshed out knight armor.

   [*] And one of the aspects which FromSoftware is know for: Bosses. They are incredible. Menacing, awesome looking and with great variety!
[/list]

Why?

Elden Ring (ER), that's why.

Granted, I believe they made Elden Ring more of my style because this s**t was hard.  Not that ER was easy, but I did not have to run down a chasm to repeat a boss fight in Elden Ring.  I'm happily satisfied that the devs made that change for ER, but DS is the OG so... yes you have to run down a chasm, hoping not to take too many hits, to repeat a boss fight.  

Anyways, I hold the record for most refunds for Dark Souls Remastered.  TBH, it's going to take 10-20 hours to really feel the "feels" if you know what i'm saying. . . And once you do, you'll agree that Dark Souls is easily one of the best games ever.

I also killed all the NPCs in the starting shrine out of frustration which I would NOT recommend doing because, come to find out, they sell you useful items later in the game (Doh!) and you can't respec. . . So, me losing my 49,000 souls (repeatedly) from non-boss fights, sent me into a black-out rage.  Once I came to, they were gone; do not do what I did.

Don't roll knight, roll pyro.

I came to this title after playing and finishing Sekiro and Elden Ring. I was so enthralled by this genre, so hooked  to the world building and gameplay; and the satisfaction of finally killing a boss after trying and dying so many times, that I couldn't help myself be eagerly waiting for the Dark souls franchise sale. The sense of victory and achievement of overcoming insurmountable odds really drew me to this game.

If i want to keep it brief, I would just say The Dark souls Remastered is a masterpieces, thru and thru. From the beginning on the undead asylum to end of the kiln of the first flame, this game was captivating and mesmerising. I could only wonder how much a vast and detailed world of Lordran was created for us, the chosen undead, to be a part of; to be the one saving or dooming it as we see fit. The game, the lore, the combat, the equipment and stat system, the inter-connectivity of different areas was really a joy to explore and experience. 
Its evident why this was amongst the titles that gave birth to the sub-genre called 'souls-like'.

I don't know why i have not played the dark souls trilogy before, but now when i am, i just couldn't get enough of it. Playing and finishing this game made me realise why these series by Fromsoftwares are so popular and I myself am in love with it.

Thus began the age of men, the Age of Dark.
