Dark Souls is great game and you should play it.  The reason why I gave it a thumbs down is because this "remaster" was minimal effort.  Textures are higher resolution but some look oddly "bumpy" (see the ladders or the cogs in the Duke's Archives).  The shaders are more advanced but ruin the original moody lighting.  The bonfire fire looks more realistic but lost its original mystical look (just look at the bonefires at the bottom left of the loading screens).  If it wasn't for the fact that they stopped selling the original release and ended its online service, I would be recommending it instead.

So many flaws but is considered the best dark souls game? 

-Terrible claustrophobic and narrow areas where the developers find it necessary to have either a hard as hell enemy waiting, or hordes of easier enemies who spam all at once, getting multiple hits in on you. This doesn't help when you are halfway through an attack animation but is canceled if they hit you (they will hit you).

-Random trap floors that can screw you over and cause you to lose souls and humanity, landing you in the nest of enemies but not only that, but for some reason you get fall damage for falling through these unsuspecting collapsing floors. One example is when returning to Undead Asylum and you fall through the floor to fight a boss, but the game unfairly causes you to lose health upon hitting the floor, leaving you vulnerable to be hit a single time from the boss that will send you back to the bonfire.

-Backstabbing (by far the most broken mechanic) is complete sh**, so many occasions where a random will invade and somehow get back-stab after back-stab. This wouldn't be as much of a problem if it was fair, but I encountered countless enemies and invaders who somehow managed to activate these back-stabs even when looking directly at me or when I have rolled out of the way of their attack but the game registers it as a back-stab.

This game has its moments where I find enjoyment from playing and exploring, but this is heavily watered down by the ridiculous design choices and bugs that commonly occur throughout your playthrough. This being said, it is not the worse game but also not the best of the series, it has spirit and love put into it, and I do recommend others to try it and judge it for themselves, this is only my opinion based on my experience with the product

Dark Souls is the worst game I've played in the souls-like genre.

I've enjoyed Elden Ring, Sekiro and Nioh massively but never played the DS series, so had high hopes for the widely acclaimed first game. Have to say it is a huge disappointment.

- I was prepared for clunky controls, but not something *this clunky*. Walking/running around is annoying slow. Input lags are even more severe than in Elden Ring. Rolling with the lightest armor felt like fat roll in ER. The combat was mediocre to start with and the controls just made it straight up painful.

- The game difficulty feels way too artificial and ultimately unfair. Git gud is only fun when you feel like you're moving toward achieving something. When you need to git gud just to avoid Crepe Demon's jump attack first thing you enter the door, you're just dealing with the game dev's malice and decide it's not worth it.

- Exploring the map was probably the only fun part but it is undermined by the lack of fast travel/means to avoid combat when moving between bonfires. I was trapped in the bonfire in upper blighttown for hours which basically ruined any excitement I had when I lit that bonfire. (ER/Sekiro have fast travel, for good reasons. Nioh doesn't have fast travel within a level but there's nijutsu that makes you invisible. Hollow knight has neither but running past enemies is way easier than in DS were you can barely run at all.)

Never joined the hype train on this game over the years, but recently got curious and gave it a try. 48 hours in, I gave up and requested a refund. 
Simply put, this game is incredibly frustrating. You have to walk around vast areas without any saving spots just to be one-hit killed by some random low level enemy and walk all that way again.. Its just such a huge waste of your time, it's ridiculous. Not to mention boss fights, they're just boring.
Yes, it's supposed to be difficult and extremely challenging, and it delivers in that regard.
That being said, it's not what I personally consider a pleasurable gaming experience.
Maybe I'm a "filthy casual"? Perhaps. But if you play games to have a good time and relax, enjoy the visuals and dive into a immersive universe without having to deal with all the unnecessary stress this game brings, you'll do good to avoid it.

Well, isn't that a shame. If Elden Ring was a recommendation with an asterisk, then this has to be a recommendation with three asterisks at least. Really, it barely eeks out a positive review on the strength of its level design (the structures are a joy to explore in principle) and the fun I had performing the rather consistent parries.

Apart from that, I finally get that age-old "artificial difficulty" argument. Of course, that's always going to be an extremely silly term to call it and thus easy to dismiss, but it does address a mixture of jank and tedium which frequently mars enjoyment of Dark Souls. A lot of the bosses aren't hard per se - being slow, predictable and having a limited moveset, though the DLC is much better in that regard - but they do often take a stupid amount of hits, all the while you have to ensure you don't perish to jank: Questionable hit boxes on certain attacks, stage hazards, getting stuck on random bits on the ground, the camera...

Combine that with boss runs (again, never hard, just tedious) and you're looking at a lot of wasted time, plain and simple. It doesn't help that you're controlling a character that moves like a wet sponge and seems incapable of scaling anything higher than a stair. Your character arguably performs better when keeping what you might foolishly assume are the key tools of locking on (the one useful thing about the O&S fight is that it teaches you to stop doing that) and rolling (since you take additional damage during it) to a minimum. Hence why I say that exploring is fun [i]in principle[/i]. Which is stupid, because you have to, since you're also dealing with general FromSoft obscurity. The bottom line is that Dark Souls isn't hard because it's such a challenging test of skill, it's hard because it's a psychological test of how much repeated BS you're willing to tolerate.

So, feel free to make ample use of guides, because this is a very cool game to experience in many instances. Not that I think you have to experience it yourself; I'd say it's perfectly fine to just watch someone else play it and spare yourself the firsthand frustration. I think between the parries, some fun fights in non-boss sections, most bosses thankfully being easy enough to only take a few tries and the fantastic level structure, I had barely enough fun to make this thumb point upwards, but a glowing recommendation this is not.

This was the first time I played a Souls game. They have been hyped up quite a lot, so I decided to delve into the worlds created by Miyazaki. Many have named the first game of the series as a masterpiece, and one of the greatest games ever made. Personally, I do not think that it actually is. But, it is a great game nonetheless, that reminded me of my early gaming days in the 90s.
The atmosphere is amazing, and the bleakness of the dying world slowly seeps into your soul. It is a difficult game but fair, despite some clunkiness. The majority of times that I died was either due to poor reaction times, or getting to greedy with my attacks and mismanaging my stamina. The only exception would be the Anor Londo Archers (yes, they deserve the capital letters). Lost almost 93000 souls to them and 12 humanity. 
Overall, I did not have much difficulty with the bosses. I beat Quelaag, Nito, Sif on my first try. Artorias, Manus, Kalameet and Ornstein and Smough on my third. And then we have the Capra Demon for 8 and the Bed of Chaos for 11... These two were a case of poor design. Especially in the case of the latter. In general, that part of the game seemed unfinished and it was a real slog. 
I certainly liked the challenge that the game presented me with. It was a long time since I had palpitations during a boss battle, and the exhilaration after I triumphed. This is the essence of Dark Souls. You get good. As simple as that. However, the quality of the game fluctuates especially in the second half. But, I would highly recommend this game simply because the feeling of overcoming the challenges it throws at you is simply the best. Can't wait to move on to the rest of the series, then Sekiro and finally Elden RIng.

[h3]Dark Souls: Remastered can be easily compared to drinking a six-pack of beer.[/h3]
[b]In the first part,[/b] you feel great and chug another beer after another.
[b]In the second half,[/b] you start feeling bad, but at this point, you just push so it doesn't go to waste.
The same can be said for the so-called "remastered" title. 
It's like one of your favorite beers suddenly got a new formula, but after buying it you don't even feel the difference. 
Maybe it's just slightly worse, but you feel like it's just the same beer but in a new can.

Just like with alcohol, you will either like it or not. 
It may be strong, even too strong for you, but with time it can change to be one of your favorite drinks to-go.

This game reminded me of what it means to love games again. The never-ending desire to play more, the repeated question of what could possibly next and an immersion in a fake world that I have not felt in a long time.

The game is Brutal, but it's worth every minute of anger and grinding your teeth cause that dopamine hit is better than drugs.

The Story-telling although mostly through item descriptions and dialogue you have to do special requirements for, is truly a tale worth unpacking as their is a lot to be found within. And is a testament to how thought out the world your playing in is, which just adds to the experience.

The game is also janky in some regards, but in my opinion it adds to the charm. I love old games.

Aside from that, highly recommended!

This is my first ever Souls game experience.

My first character was of course a Knight, because who doesn't like the looks of heavy armor, a massive long range Halberd mixed with a cool shield. It has been pretty obvious that I'm not Chad enough for melee so I decided to start over and go easy mode, in other words, made a Sourcer. This decision allowed me to go though most of the side and the main content within 25 hours. I lit that flame because I wasn't there to put an end to everything but to succeed the weakling that took 5 shots to die.

Looking forward to moving to the next game in the series :)

I realize I'm very late to this party and obviously got my money's worth on this game (judging by my play time), but I still came away from it with a bad taste in my mouth. I feel that, despite this game's good qualities, it still has a bunch of indisputably bad design decisions that I never hear anybody talk about, so I want to complain about them here.

I wrote an even longer review than this, but it ended up being too long for Steam. So instead of my usual list of pros and cons, I'll just list the bad design decisions that I feel people tend to overlook when extolling this game.

--- Bad design decisions featured in this game:

- As someone who mostly plays single-player games, this first point is one I am emphatically passionate about: if a game is presented as single-player, it should be playable without needing help or advice from other players (specifically, without needing to refer to a wiki). If the game doesn't give me the necessary tools to figure out everything for myself, if I need to read a wiki or find hints left by other players to learn basic information about a game, then that game is badly designed. Arbitrarily hiding information from players isn't making a game "full of secrets" or "mysterious", it's just making it obtuse and inaccessible. Without checking the wiki, there is no way for you to know:
        - How many souls a soul in your inventory is worth before using it (or until Frampt is available). This is especially true for boss souls (since the amount Frampt gives is not always the same as how much it's actually worth).
        - Which upgrade path for a weapon is best (you can only see how the weapon's stats change when upgrading to the next level, not the maximum number of levels nor the stats for each level). Additionally, once a weapon is upgraded, it's impossible to know whether a newly acquired weapon can be upgraded higher than the already-upgraded one or not. There is NO REASON this information couldn't have been made available in the game, and the game is not better or more fun for having this information withheld.
        - The necessary ingredients for boss weapons. The game won't even show which boss weapons can be crafted if you don't have the correct kinds of ingredient weapons in your inventory.
        - That equipment load affects run speed and roll speed. Also, there is no in-game way to know equipment load levels, which determine whether you do a fast/medium/slow roll. Considering how central combat and rolling are to this game, this is a major, inexcusable oversight.
        - What staggering is, and when/why some enemies stagger.
        - What being "hollowed" is, why this is relevant to the story, why the player character being hollowed is different from enemies being hollowed, or why enemies only attack you but not each other.
        - That being un-hollowed allows summoning help in boss fights. There is no other benefit to being un-hollowed (as it allows invasions), so it's easy to go through the entire game without realizing this.
        - That there are illusory walls (if you haven't discovered any by accident).
        - What invasions are, or when they are NPCs (which can be reasonably defeated by a sufficiently skilled player) or other human players (who have no visual indication of power level and may easily one-shot an unprepared player out of nowhere).
        - Which items are dropped by which enemies and how often. This is particularly important if certain weapon upgrades require rare materials, but there are not enough of them in chests around the world to fully upgrade a weapon (without going through the hassle of new game plus), so you need to grind certain enemies to get enough of them. There's no reason the game couldn't have had a codex that gets filled out with enemy information as you defeat them.
	
Besides hiding useful information from players for no reason, this game has plenty of other bad, stupid, and unjustifiable design choices:

- The game's entire move set is dumped on you in the very first level. If you don't master jumping and parrying, you may never be able to get back to this area to see the instructions.

- This game has no story, just unrelated events that happen in sequence. The "story" - if it can be called that - merely consists of the player character traveling to a series of different regions and killing boss monsters, usually without any information on who these monsters are, why they were important, nor whether the player character has any idea why they're doing this in the first place (aside from, "Well, I'm playing a video game and I guess this is the way forward."). This is where defenders of the game will give the weak counterargument that the story is in the flavor text of in-game items. To this I reply: reading item descriptions is a mediocre excuse for storytelling. Compare this to the storytelling in Subnautica or Skyrim: all information necessary to those stories is presented through dialogue and cut scenes, and most text is just for additional flavor and worldbuilding. And - most crucially - this information is presented in places where you'd actually think to look, like in-world books or highlighted entries in a codex, not fricken' item descriptions which are so often unhelpful, boring, or obtuse that you just learn to ignore them. Integrating storytelling with gameplay is the superior approach, and if Dark Souls had been well-made enough to do things this way, its fans wouldn't need to defend it. Extra points are deducted for weapons that have special effects which are only documented in flavor text.

- The fantasy elements in this game don't feel like they're from the same world. Sure, each different monster looks unique, but the bosses in particular feel like a grab-bag of fantasy elements, not parts of a consistent style or system.

- The world doesn't feel alive. All characters and enemies are just standing in place waiting for the player to come along and interact with them. Compare this to Skyrim, where NPCs have set routes and will walk from their house to work and back, or will even join you on quests to other locations. Additionally, the various towns you walk through in Dark Souls do not look like they were designed for actual people to live in (no beds, no bathrooms, no markets, unnatural layouts). This makes them feel very artificial and video-gamey.

- If you don't understand how "builds" work (that is, upgrading your stats to focus on damage vs. speed vs. magic), you can get yourself into a situation where you have to grind a lot to be reasonably leveled. Magic is particularly clunky to use in this game: you have to stand still in place for a second or two to cast any spell. Considering this leaves you wide open to backstabs and that enemy attacks can interrupt the spell, it doesn't seem balanced compared to combat. So in the early game if you spend several upgrade points on magic in the hopes it will get more powerful later, all that time and grinding will prove to be a waste, and will increase the cost of future upgrades for the stats that actually matter.

- There are places where you have to sit and wait for 30 seconds to be transported somewhere. In all other situations in this game, if something doesn't immediately happen when you take an action, this means you're missing a necessary item or have to complete some task elsewhere first. Having places in the game where you actually need to wait 30 boring seconds doing nothing is inconsistent and infuriating.

- The process for accessing the DLC (Oolacile and the Abyss) is unjustifiably obscure. It requires revisiting the least fun area in the whole game and killing a specific but otherwise nondescript enemy for no discernible reason. This isn't fun or challenging, it's just obtuse and inaccessible. (Plus, the process for downing Kalameet is similarly obscure and arbitrary.)

I had a really good review for this game, but for some dumb reason I decided to change it to a dumb Dark Souls quote.

After playing through to the end of Dark Souls: Remastered, facing the 4 lords and learning the attack patterns of enemies I must say this is an excellent title. I like the lore, even though is can be very vague and the universe itself is shrouded in mystery, decay and hopelessness, but in the same vain there is still "hope" in the kindling of the first flame, there is beauty in the broken landscapes and dilapidated structures, Anor Londo was a big focal point of the game, at least when establishing the "ruling hand" of Lordran. When understanding the dynamic between the ruling class, what happened during the ancient Dragon wars involving the everlasting Dragons and the 4 Lords, as well as Gwyn, it makes you really feel just how bad things had become when you come in.

Gameplay in my opinion is SLOW, compared to even Dark Souls II SoTFs, and a snails pace compared to the likes of DSIII and Elden Ring. I won't say it's a bad thing, as it was much more challenging than Elden ring, the 4 Lords were easy enough even without help. The bed of chaos was, something? I feel that could've been done better. Gravelord Nito was difficult at first, but slow, and like much of the rest of the bosses, once you learn his attacks, and when to dodge, he becomes trivial. The four kings were more difficult, as at the time I'd say I was under-prepared in terms of DMG output, and as you continue to fight them off more "clones" appear. This was annoying to say the least, but he went down after a couple attempts. Lastly, Seath the scaleless was an okay fight, the curse infliction was a difficult obstacle, but once again, a couple attempts and a few thousand souls to level, he too went down.

The only negative things I can say about the game, is the collision of weapons in small corridors, on posts, objects etc. This has killed me many a times, but it is avoidable with proper kiting. 
I've mentioned it before, in my previous review. Invasions suck. It wouldn't need to be that way, If the latency wasn't such an issue. This seems to be an issue in DS 1-3 and I can't really see it any other way. Getting struck through blocks, getting struck when obviously out of range of an attack, it's not fun. Thankfully, you don't NEED to be human for any apparent buffs or bonuses, unlike in later titles. 

I think if you enjoy the fantasy genre, and want to challenge yourself as a gamer, give Dark souls a try. If you get mad take a break and come back later, I can certainly see why this game is held with such high regard.

I have played Dark Souls more than any other Fromsoft game and while I don't think it is objectively their best work I can't help but feel the same charm I did back in 2011 when I first launched the game on our PS3 with my dad. This game has had a huge influence on my taste in games and is one of my favorite games of all time. It also introduced me to one of my favorite developers of all time. I can not recompensed this game enough.

'A magnificent action-RPG that redefined and re-contextualized the importance of difficulty in videogames', THIS is the basic gist/summary I have heard from countless sources, now that I am finally playing it, I can see the appeal, It's difficult but fair, It likes to troll with you but also gives you a meaningful sense of accomplishment, there will be times where you will be genuinely stuck in an area or a boss for hours, this is where the community aspect as well as online aspect of the game comes into play, this makes the game a social experience yet no one ever talks with you, with the exception of gestures, interactions are limited yet sense of connection with people who are going through the same ordeal as you, feels tangible.

> Level design is excellent many areas in the game are built like a maze - essentially... a single area, say, shrine for example can lead to a dozen different places all interconnected in their own intricate ways.
> Graphics and lighting are excellent for a seventh gen console title, and still looks great. thanks to the games moody and interesting art direction,
> There is a looot of content in this game to dabble into....
> Sound and music is great though not amazing, it works and compliments the world.
> It is a story light game, there is a ton of lore here for the curious ones...
> Bosses are the real highlight of this game
>There is a slight bit of jank to movement...it is certainly not a platformer, but you can get used to it as you play...

....Haven't completed the game yet, but i highly recommend this to anyone that likes a good challenge, a good rpg and an amazing world to explore...

As a player starting the Souls genre with Elden Ring, this feels similar and still different. I do appreciate the consistency with which FromSoft tackles game mechanics and you clearly see the evolutionary path up to the point of Elden Ring.

That being said, a lot of the quality of life improvements are still missing here, which is a good thing. The world feels much more condensed, raw and deadly. The atmosphere is phenomenal and clearly sets this game apart from ER.

I got it on a deal for roughly 20 bucks, but if I wasn't on a tighter budget right now would have bought it at it's regular 40 bucks as well at some point.

I think there's no need to argue the quality of this game anymore. Graphically it works just fine setting a very distinctive tone. Sound design and music is top notch.

All in all I highly recommend Dark Souls to anyone seeking a good challenge and to players familiar with newer FromSoft titles who can live without some of the quality of life things like fast travel and an in-game map system.

The game often feels more like a puzzle to solve instead of a difficult challenge to overcome.  Solutions are not always obvious but figuring them out feels very rewarding.  The combat is usually slowly paced and methodical, it feels more like a turn-based game than an action RPG at most times.  The boss encounters are usually one-note and the exuberant feeling after defeating one is mostly due to not having to do the boss's run-back again.  Overall, a very impressive game with a reputation the precedes it, and a new player experiencing the game for the first time over a decade later can still have a memorable experience playing it.

I fucking hate this game. Aside from that, it was a incredible experience some of the areas unbelievably stupid hard but other than that it's an awesome game. Recommended to all those who deem themselves worthy.

The game's PvP is completely neutered by the removal of dead angles and ghost strikes, so the backstab meta is much stronger (hard to imagine I know) than in the original and you have less ways to defend against it. 
Another thing that fucks everyting up is introduction of the dogshit DS3 style matchmaking, which no longer allows you to invade infinitely up and also locks you in a specific weapon upgrade bracket, so the pool of available players to play with is by default much smaller than in the original no matter the online activity.

The PvE is pretty much the same, hitboxes of certain attacks from certain bosses are a little more forgiving (Smough's ass slam, Ceaseless Discharge tenticle slams and swipes, Stray Demon AOE blast, etc.) due to the game now running natively at 60fps, so that is nice. The lighting is worse than in the original, a lot of the metallic armors look like they're made out of plastic now. The game graphically took a small step back it feels, the upscaled textures look like complete shit sometimes, the original was a bit more grainy looking but it worked in its favour imo. 

If you're only interested in PvE and don't want to bother pirating PTDE and patching the shit out of it to make it playable, then go ahead I guess. 

If your intent is PvP, then please don't bother.

Elden Ring's my first Soulsborne game and  I am still really enjoying it. If you're looking for something easier than grab yourself a copy of Dark Souls Remastered. The combat is the same except bosses are much slower. Backstabs are relatively easy to do to enemies. There are some dungeons that can be found annoying and frustrating but there are always ways to come back to them later in the game. The game is not currently being updated so there are tons of cheese methods that aren't patched yet. [b] Dark Souls Remastered also comes with the DLC (Artorias of the Abyss) so there is no need worrying about buying DLCS for the game. [/b]

I'd definitely recommend this game for anyone who's not played a single Souls game or has played one.

Dark Souls. 

An iconic name, rhyming with difficulty and despair. 
It is true to an extent. 
I wanted to try it for myself, even if I'm not a hardcore gamer. And what a journey ! 

I finished it in Normal Game and in New Game +. 


The art is one of the points that surprised me the most. The remastered version is beautiful and smooth, the dark fantasy, bleak but nonetheless medieval fantastic atmosphere is something that I missed in games. Just look at landscapes from Sen's Fortress and Anor Londo, and you will feel a real medieval Lord of the Ring's Weathertop, Osgiliath and Minas Tirith or Berserk castles vibes. I also really loved the forest/ruins environment from Undead parish. 

The music is non existent while exploring, it gives a real feeling of vulnerability since you are startled by the smallest environmental noise. It is also epic and terrifying while fighting bosses. My favourites ones are those from Ornstein & Smough and Kalameet. 

The scenario and lore are quite difficult to find, you have to look up the item's descriptions to gather informations. Even if it is rewarding to understand the puzzle bit by bit, I was often lost with the lore and I don't think I could understand it without videos and wikis. Also the NPCs dying or going hollow if you didn't talked to them at a specific point or didn't do something to keep them alive (even if you didn't know) is a tad frustrating. 

As Sartre said "Hell is other people". Well, in Dark Souls you'll start to think it's true. Especially when you try to return to the bonfire with enough souls to level up and a bloke invade you while you have no more estus, let you get rammed by monsters and emote on your face after backstabbing you... Unforgettable experience.

The difficulty is one of the most iconic part. The fact that you can't choose the difficulty is THE BEST. It is something that you never experienced before. At first I took three weeks to reach O&S because I was scared to die. But after beating NG, I got like "f*ck it we ball" and played normally. Dark Souls is one of the best gaming experience I had with Nier: Automata. The feeling when you triumph from an area that gave you nightmares is unique (I'm looking at you Tomb of Giants, you were the first area to make me ragequit in 20 years of gaming). Or after beating monstrous boss (Ornstein and Smough of course, but also Artorias, Manus, or Four Kings in NG+... They nearly crushed my spirit). You'll have to keep your mental resilience in check and never yield. My advice is to take small breaks (5 minutes to a few hours) when you begin to get tilted, and come back with a renewed spirit. 
 

Dark Souls is an experience, a proof that you can do it. 
Forge ahead, and don't go hollow.

It's the exact same game under the hood, but with an improved engine and higher-quality assets built from the same source material. Newer optional mechanics such as optional room passwords (to get around level limits) are also available for those co-op sessions. This release is objectively the best way to play the game, and seemingly does not change or remove anything else unnecessarily.

On top of that not being able to warp between bonfires initially made the game really fun to to play, and made the experience unique and fresh compared to other FromSoftware titles. I highly reccommend playing the series chronologically, because this is definitely one of the most unique and "fun" Dark Souls games. However, if you prefer a more polished and straightforward game you can start with Dark Souls 3, and then play the other titles afterwards.

I think what makes this game special is the map design. The interconnectedness of the world creates a sense of exploring through an abandoned land, not just areas put together in a linear form. For example, you can see Lost Izalith from Tomb of the Giants or you can see Firelink Shrine from Blighttown. These little nuances increases the immersiveness of the game. After 12 years it still holds up. A must play for any FromSoftware fan.

Coming from Elden Ring, I figured id try the what popularized the souls genre. The one thing id say is don't expect this to play like Elden Ring, the combat is slower and significantly clunky'er then what you might even expect. Attacks are way slower, and you have to commit to every attack you through out. The game really sensitizes on waiting for your turn to attack ( outside of the 4 kings, where you throw all that out the window and smash face ). However even though its slower, the fun of combat is far from boring. Instead spamming lions claw, and dodging Melania's waterfall dance youre pacing around the enemy trying to get that sweet backstab. Outside of combat i wont lie, i had my fair share of WTF moments. I thought walking into Blighttown was horrific, then i discovered Sen's Fortress, and the Tomb of the giants. Definitely felt like however designed the areas just wanted to make a area where we would just actually suffer true emotional damage. Overall though id say its a MUST if you're a fan of the genre.

2023 edit:
Looking back on this review clearly didn't age well and while I maintain some of my opinions from back then people might misunderstand it as pure hate for the game. Dark Souls Remastered is the best version of DS1 at least from a smooth gameplay and frame stability perspective. The few quality of life changes made from the original are very welcome (multiple item turn-ins with covenants, the new bonfire at the catacombs blacksmith, control/key bind config, etc). One of the most known issues with this remaster is the change on the lighting effects that completely change the atmosphere of the areas and as a result can take out of your immersion. It's still pretty annoying to this date that FromSoft removed both DS and DS:PTDE so you HAVE to buy this version and the 50% discount it had on release (which isn't available anymore unless there's a steam sale going or something).

[i]Dark Souls Remastered[/i] is the best version ever released of the best game ever made. Oh, sure, you can quibble about minor changes (the lighting is different!) and complain that nothing has changed since the [i]Prepare to Die Edition[/i], but at the end of the day this game makes the original obsolete in every way. Yes, I wouldâ€™ve loved to see [i]Dark Souls 2[/i]â€™s superior menus implemented and yes, I do think there are certain levels that seem downright lazy when compared to the stellar bulk of the game, but at the end of the day this is not a remake, and to change things drastically from the way they were when it came out would do a disservice to the game itself. Worse would be to arbitrarily shift characters and items around and fill the game with goons by the bucketload, as the already disappointing [i]Dark Souls 2[/i] was subject to with its 2015 â€˜remasterâ€™ [i]Scholar of the First Sin[/i]. [i]That[/i] was a bad remaster, because not only was the technical improvement negligible, but the actual design of the world and its lore was compromised by some fabricated need to change things around to make people purchase the same game twice.

This game, on the other hand, is the same game it was when it came out in 2011. There is a new bonfire in the Catacombs to make it easier to access an NPC in that area, but thatâ€™s it. As far as I can tell that is literally the only change to level design from beginning to end, and yet it is a vastly superior experience than [i]Prepare to Die[/i] because the multiplayer is alive and well. Iâ€™ve played [i]Dark Souls[/i] a lot, but it wasnâ€™t until the first time I played this edition that I encountered members of covenants outside of a handful of the most popular ones. In the very first area where multiplayer is possible I fought a Gravelord Servant, then an acolyte of the Path of the Dragon, all within ten minutes. I got my shit ruined because I was wielding a weapon I barely had the stats to even [i]hold[/i], but it was a [i]fantastic[/i] experience regardless because I felt like I was experiencing the game for the first time in the way it was intended - as a fusion of single- and multiplayer experiences into one.

Itâ€™s awesome, is what Iâ€™m getting at. If you have money that you are going to spend on a computer game I literally do not think there is a better way to spend it than on a copy of [i]Dark Souls Remastered[/i]. Itâ€™s the best game Iâ€™ve ever played, and failing a return from the heavens by Jesus Christ himself and the subsequent release of a game heâ€™s been developing for the last two millennia, I donâ€™t see how that will change. I really do think everybody owes it to themselves to give this game a try, and I think that this version is the best way to do it.

[b]Background:[/b]
Dark Souls is the first souls-like game I've got around to play, finally in 2023. :D Though there's many similarities in the gameplay to Witcher 2/3, Prince of Persia and some other action/RPG games I'm familiar with.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
After everything that I've been hearing about Dark Souls for over a decade, it truly did deliver on the promised experience! The start was quite harsh, and it took a while to adjust to the combat mechanics and learn all the finesses. I didn't entirely like the fact that the controls were made for controllers and were sometimes VERY unintuitive â€“ I even had look up an external resource to learn how to jump, because it was explained so poorly in-game! I took me around 60 hours before I realized you can kick, do jump attacks and whatnot. 

After getting hang of the mechanics the experience became much more fun. One of the big (positive) surprises for me was just how much RPG elements there were, as I had thought of Dark Souls as more of a hack'n'slash type of game. As I often tend to be somewhat of a completionist, the game was at times surprisingly grindy as well, since some items have really low drop-rates and later on leveling takes a lot of souls (the main currency of the game) â€“ although to be fair, you don't [i]have[/i] to grind if you're not so inclined. The gameplay and combat was overall very satisfactory and I enjoyed it a lot. The difficulty was very steep at the start, but towards the end it became sometimes even too easy, with all the fully upgraded gear and higher level. One of my only gripes is with all the invisible walls and not being able to walk over a 5 centimeters high branch, which had me feeling like I was playing the first Witcher game all over again.

[b]Story/Lore/Environment:[/b]
I really loved the aesthetics of the world and the environment. All of the areas were ingeniously connected to each other and made exploring fun. There were also a HUGE amount of secrets to be found â€“ even some entire large areas! There was a fair amount of detective work to even get access to the DLC area!

To be completely honest, I often have a hard time understanding how Japanese games can be so bizarre, but maybe that's just a Western perspective. xD The world and the story is kept a bit of a secret from start to finish, and you're only fed tidbits of lore as you go through it. The state of the world is also not really put into perspective and you don't really understand what humanity, undeath, hollows, gods etc etc REALLY are, and how they relate to each other.

The weirdness and quirkiness is especially accentuated by all the characters you meet throughout your adventuring. It feels like more than half of them speak in Shakespearean monologues and have a weird laugh they do every time you talk with them. Also, after a lengthy monologue that's going all over the place, you're only answer is either 'Yes' or 'No' â€“ the answer sometimes completely defining in unexpected ways the future of your well-being, their life (or death) and whether you'll ever get access to their goods/services. Next time you'll also have to find them in some remote area of the world that you (maybe) got a hint about. You do also always get the option of just stabbing them in the face whenever you feel like it, which I guess is some nice freedom of choice.

[b]But wait â€“ there's more![/b]
In addition to the grinding, the Co-op and PvP features made Dark Souls feel surprisingly much like an MMORPG. The online features and the New Game+ feature really give the game a lot of replayability. There's also a huge amount of weapons and combat styles that you're not going to experience in a single playthrough. Anyway, now I'm going back to my next one-and-a-half playthroughs to get the final five missing achievements! :P

Having platinumed all three Dark Souls games (four if you count DS1 Remastered), here is my "hot take" on the iconic series:
1. DS1 is still my number one, and not just among the souls games -- it's my favoritest game of all. A must play.
2. DS2 took a bit of an odd turn (new mechanics, new lands), but it's still near and dear to my heart. Not a must play, but a nice addition to the main course.
3. DS3 got the series back on track, perfecting the original formula in almost every way and wrapping up the story cycle beautifully in the Ringed City DLC. A must play.
Thank you, Miyazaki, thank you, From Software!

Dark Souls I released in 2011 is the first game in the Dark Souls series being the predecessor of Demon Souls, the game which set out the ground foundations for the souls-borne series. Dark Souls I is a breathtakingly beautiful game for
its time where each area in the game feels alive. Dark Souls I takes the blueprints that Demon Souls left and builds upon it greatly. Dark Souls I is a perfectly merged dark fantasy game known to build an entire genre of games, souls like, 
with the games sheer difficulty and fear factor. Dark Souls I in 2018 would get a remaster with a fresh coat of paint, bringing the game closer to life with a great graphics overhaul making the game even prettier. Dark Souls I is well known
among hard core gamers due to the games incredible difficulty compared to anything on the market at the time. The game always for you to choose how to play it and this is one of the great strong points of the soul-borne franchise. If you
choose one route and struggle, for example you choose a dex weapon and can't seem to overcome a boss, the game will throw optional bosses at you for a chance to level up and come back when you are stronger or with the games great
build variety you can swap how you fight the enemy you have discovered in a new way for a chance at success. This is the main and real driving point of the Dark Souls games, the reward curiosity and exploration and give you a real sense
of completion and worth when you finally manage to overcome a challenge, these games are all about overcoming a challenge. I first played Dark Souls III and then returned to Dark souls I once I had gathered all the achievements for Dark Souls III.
This made my journey with Dark Souls I much easier than the average player as I came to get the game with previous experience with the souls way of doing things. However, this does not mean my journey was without rocky roads or challenges as
Dark Souls I is a very different game from Dark Souls III with unique boss fights and a less fluid movement system, learning to play with these was a challenge in itself that I would have to overcome. Once I did I fell in love with Dark Souls I. It is
unapologetic and fierce, the game will kick you down and keep you there if you let it. Many of the boss fights within Dark Souls I are some of the greatest and most enjoyable boss fights I have ever experienced with a video game. For example, the legendary
duo fight with Oystein and Smough, I can safely say this up there for one of the scariest, mightiest and and most breath taking boss fights I have ever fought. However, this is the peak of Dark Souls I, as much as I love many of the boss fights in this game, 
the games second half (any point after this fight) is where the game has a serious dip in quality. This part of the game is not bad in any way it just lacks in comparison to how great the start and middle of the game is. As areas such as tomb of giants or the catacombs
are very difficult but not in the usual sense, the are challenging not to teach the player but almost seem to be a pain on purpose. The bosses of these areas are also fairly tame in comparison feeling as if they didn't get the same love or care that other bosses did. However,
this doesn't mean every boss in this half is bad as the four kings is one of my favourite fights in the game. Although, fights like nino or pinwheel are very underwhelming and often a pain to get to and fight. Overall, with a few bugs and fairly tedious areas such as the tomb
of giants, Dark Souls I is still an absolutely legendary game and possibly one of my favourite games of all time, it is a must play. Dark Souls I set out the foundation that so many games attempt to be. Imitated yet never duplicated.

what no one ever tells you about dark souls is not the little tortures the game inflicts on you (the level design is near-purposefully malicious in mechanics come the latter half of the game and the game knows this) it's the little tortures [i] you [/i] inflict on yourself in the lulls of the game, perhaps while not even playing. it's not the mere act of dying to some boss' bullshit attack that goes through your shield that phases the player, it's the time in between. when you're painstakingly fighting through the same enemies to get back to where you were, when you're swapping your equipment back to the stuff most effective in dealing with the mobs as opposed to the boss...when you're riding the train to campus, when you're working into your third hour. it hits you. that horrible, stupid, unhelpful question: "what if I did that another way?" if i had to distill the game's genius into one aspect, it'd probably be this one. 

so yeah, TL;DR, hard game, took breaks. too many? maybe, but don't think those breaks were dark souls-less, quite the opposite.

Dark Souls isn't merely a game; it's a transformative experience that immerses players in a world of unparalleled challenge, depth, and accomplishment. FromSoftware's masterpiece has given birth to a genre of its own, shaping the very landscape of gaming with its unique blend of difficulty, atmosphere, and profound storytelling. Dark Souls isn't just a game you play; it's an epic journey you live.

The world of Dark Souls is a dark and mysterious tapestry, woven with layers of interconnected areas that invite exploration and discovery. Each location exudes a unique ambiance, from the eerie grandeur of Anor Londo to the gloomy catacombs and beyond. The sense of place and atmosphere is palpable, making each corner of the world feel like a living, breathing entity.

Combat in Dark Souls is a symphony of strategy and precision. Every swing of your weapon, every dodge, every parry is a calculated move that demands the utmost attention. The deliberate pacing of battles forces players to learn, adapt, and truly understand their foes. The feeling of triumph that accompanies overcoming a seemingly insurmountable enemy is unlike anything else in gaming, a testament to the game's unforgiving yet fair design.

Where Dark Souls truly shines is its masterful storytelling. The lore is enigmatic, delivered in fragments through item descriptions, cryptic dialogue, and the intricate design of the world itself. Unraveling the mysteries and piecing together the history of Lordran is an intellectual pursuit that rewards those who seek understanding. It's a testament to the game's respect for its players, treating them as intelligent participants in a living narrative.

The difficulty of Dark Souls is legendary, and rightfully so. Yet, it's not just about being hard for the sake of it; every challenge is a lesson, an opportunity to hone your skills and refine your approach. The game teaches patience, observation, and critical thinking, attributes that extend beyond gaming and into the real world. The feeling of accomplishment that accompanies overcoming seemingly insurmountable odds is a high that lingers long after the final boss falls.

Visually, Dark Souls is a masterpiece of gloomy beauty. The art design, combined with the intricately crafted environments, creates a world that feels both grim and captivating. The interplay of light and shadow, the intricate details of armor and architecture, all contribute to an experience that is visually mesmerizing.

In conclusion, Dark Souls is a triumph that has forever changed the landscape of gaming. It's a journey that tests your limits and rewards your determination. FromSoftware's opus is an artistic endeavor that melds storytelling, challenge, and atmosphere into a gaming experience that transcends the screen. If you're seeking an adventure that will reshape your perception of games, Dark Souls is an essential pilgrimage that will leave an indelible mark on your gaming soul.

[h1] Dark Slough [/h1]

I [b]LOVE[/b] Dark Souls! I [b]ADORE[/b] it!
It's so much fun reading about this game's lore, enjoying its soundtrack, and simply experiencing this game's absolutely gorgeous art-style & world...
...yet I [i]hate[/i] actually playing it.



[h1] Sack of Gore [/h1]

I heftily dislike how this game controls.
Controls are both stiff & slippery. It feels like everything you do has a second-long delay or something, and yet you also just fly all-over the place.
[b]JUST SWING YOUR DAMN SWORD![/b]
It feels like it wants to ground itself in clunky realism by giving weight to everything due to your armory, and yet your character just flies everywhere like you're skating on butter.
It's partially due to this inconsistent flow of movement that really gives me this "[i]yucky[/i]" feeling while playing.
Half of the time my character never does what I want them to. I try to do something as simple as climb a latter or swing my sword, but instead they just wobble around.

Also, no matter your loadout, even if you remove everything & look like Mary's Mother, you're still so slow in so many aspects!
Many action takes like a whole seconds to perform. But when it's set in action it cannot be stopped.
I'm simply not a fan of that. I want to be able to cancel my attacks by switching weapons or blocking. That's how I enjoy my games, not by punishing me with enemies that attack faster than I do -- thus already having hit me after I swung my sword before them, giving me no opportunity to react, leaving me in this dishonest state of unfairness.
No joke, this game gives my controller bite-marks.

The controls are honestly so awkward & stiff & slippery that I thought my controller was broken! (It's not)
It is totally inexcusable to make a game wherein the challenge isn't the difficulty of the game itself, but from handicapping the player in the most bullshit ways possible. Where doing anything will have you stand on your toes in anticipation to see what any of your slightest movements will end up doing.

And dying to a boss & having to run through like 17 rooms of enemies to get back where you were, now at half the health since you had to run through like 80 enemies; just ain't fun.
Luckily, this is something Elden Ring would [i]finally[/i] fix by having bonfires near the bosses, and not on the opposite of the whole area. i.e. like a 7 minute run to the boss-fight again.



[h1] UI/UX [/h1]

Navigating these menus are harder than the actual game itself.
The thing about bad UIs are that they're near-impossible to describe.
But trying to navigate these menus. I just can't. It's impossible. You think it'd be simple? But [i]nooo![/i]
And when you open up your menu, the game is still running! So you can still get attacked while switching gear.

And pausing this game at all is an ass! Oh wait- you can't pause it... [b]AT ALL![/b]
I mean, if you gotta go answer the phone or take a shit... it's like tough shit if you gotta take a shit !!!
You gotta take a quick shit; you gotta turbo turds!
I'm trying to play the game! I got shit-stains in my pants & an answering message on my phone that says "Sorry! I'm playing DARK SOULSâ„¢: REMASTERED!"
[I]What a selfish game.[/I]
[b]BOTTOM LINE: HAVE A FUCKING PAUSE BUTTON![/b]



[h1] Non-gameplay [/h1]

Everything that isn't connected to the gameplay I like.
I like the lore, I like the story, I like the music, I like the visuals, I like the sound-effects. I like practically anything not related to the gameplay itself... so what good is that when I don't already enjoy the game?



[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

I kinda hate this game.
Which is really sad. As I [b]LOVE[/b] everything about this game, except the game itself.
I listen to the soundtrack constantly, I follow many Dark Souls fan-artists & content creators online, I've bought merch, I watch people play it on YouTube, I have a screenshot of this game as my Windows background even...
The game is [u]fantastic[/u] in those regards.
Ultimately, it's a game I'd love to love, and yet hate to hate.

Very dated and clunky combat by today's standards, and not being able to warp to bonfires until beating O&S 30% into the game can be brutal if you dont know the layout and what to prepare for when journeying.

My advice is look up Wiki things VERY frequently so you dont make an irreversible mistake (Like on my first play through, where I had to start over on a new save). Strength builds are incredibly viable in this game, and is the only Souls game that I use strength builds religiously for, where I use Dex builds in all other games (Zweihander and Greatsword FTW). Also, I highly recommend beating every boss in your play through. You get 100% of the experience and the souls you get rewarded with will make you big and strong to beat the game harder.

After that, once you beat the game for the first time, coming back to it is a unique experience when comparing to the other Souls games. It has a charm, and its the same experience all of us go through.

This game is phenomenal.

When i was younger when i thought of really difficult games i thought of games just set on the highest possible difficulty and i wondered why anyone would play those games like that because it wasn't even challenging most of the time it was just blatantly unfair. Then i heard of the "Souls like games" it was in 2018 and i decided to give Dark Souls 3 a try for the very first time, it was my first souls game and to be honest i just didn't understand why people actually enjoyed playing these games. You have no map, no quest marker and there was practically no safe area. I was fairly early into the game so i understandably didn't like it, but i continued on a little bit further until i encountered the Abyss Watchers. It was so difficult to me that i took a months break before playing again, but when i finally returned i managed to defeat them and my lord. The amount of hype i had and excitement i had gained after defeating this boss made me finally realize why people enjoy these games, to overcome the challenge and the reward of doing so makes it all the more sweeter when you spend time and effort into learning a bosses move set and prevailing. That was on Xbox One, When i first decided to get a PC i made sure to pick up Dark Souls Remastered so i could experience every souls game and i have come to the conclusion that the money this game cost is well worth the price. From the beautiful areas that have been carefully woven and crafted to connect to each one another around the map to the amazing boss designs and music, this game has grown to be one of my favorite games in recent years. Again i just want to talk about the map design and how everything connects together and i just absolutely love what they did with this game when it comes to level design, it is by far my favorite part of this game. Another extremely strong point in this game is the bosses, an example of an amazing boss fight in this game HAS to be the final boss Gwyn. As your walking into his domain after offering all the other boss souls to that alter thingy you get yourself prepared for an amazing boss fight that is super intense and at the same time extremely challenging, Is what i imagine people who are first experiencing the game would feel but after my 3 playthroughs throughout this game i always love to walk over to Gwyn and just reminisce on the adventure that i have had to go through to get to this point. And the music of that fight only solidifies that feeling. As apposed to all the other extremely intense music that is loud and gets you in the mood for a great fight Gwyn's music is just graceful for a lack of words. It makes you feel more like "This game is about to end.." instead of "This game is about to end!". Overall this game gives me a sense of nostalgia for some reason even though this was my first proper time playing the game. and it is phenomenal. 7.7/10

Well this was certainly an interesting game.
The game which started the infamous trilogy of ball crushingly hard games. (And no demon souls doesnâ€™t count ffs that game isnâ€™t even on pc)

And for the most part, I really enjoyed my experience with it.
The early to mid game was especially good with its bosses and overall level design. (Iâ€™d say from start to O and S)

For someone whose first souls experience was with elden ring, this game really forced me to adjust my play style.
Whilst in elden ring I would tend to run past most enemy camps, only picking up collectibles or killing the strongest foes to get their drops, in DS that same strategy usually would lead to me getting pushed up against a corner and getting Stun-locked back to my last bonfire.

The game doesnâ€™t ask you to take things slow, it kicks your ass If you donâ€™t, requiring you to take out enemies one by one to avoid enraging too many folks. 
And thatâ€™s really where a lot of the difficulty In this game comes from, its levels and regular enemies, not its bosses.

Not to say the bosses are bad though, far from itâ€¦for the most part. As I already said, i really do not have any issues with any bosses up until O and S besides one in the lower undead burg who is made artificially more difficult by putting regular, VERY ANNOYING ENEMIES, in his tiny arena.
But after O and Sâ€¦the game turns into a bit of a mixed bag.
While the environments still look amazing, the level, enemy and boss designs take severe hits in quality, usually just falling back into gimmicks or lazy reskins of old ones if weâ€™re talking about bosses specifically.
But I still was happy with the overall package of the base game.

The DLC was where the game picked up in pace for me again. (Figuratively and literally)
The 4 bosses in the dlc basically feel like they have watered down movesets from bosses youâ€™d see in later installments, to not be overwhelming in your clunky and overall slower movement, but I personally really enjoyed this.
This was the first time in the entire game where the bosses posed a real challenge in my eyes.

As a conclusion, I wouldnâ€™t recommend this game to someone If theyâ€™ve never played souls, but if you have played any of the other games and are willing to look past some of the jank of this one Iâ€™m sure youâ€™ll find some joy in it.

Praise the sun \[T]/

One of the best games I've ever played.

The game is undoubtedly very difficult, but fair. Usually when you die it feels like it was your fault, not the game forcing a cheap death. The game focuses on slow and meaningful combat. When you make a combat decision, such as attacking, dodging, or healing, you are committed to that action. There is no canceling an action once you start it. In a way, this game's combat is the antithesis of button mashing. Battles between enemies are like duels where you and your opponent are trading blows with each other and your opponents will punish you for making a bad decision.

It's the kind of game that rewards players for playing through it multiple times. The first time I played through this game it was a huge challenge. I was very excited every time I made progress and was constantly scared that I would die at any second and ruin said progress. It feels like everything in this game can kill you instantly and you never know what is lurking around the corner. If you stick with it, killing bosses and finishing the game is one of the most rewarding things you can do in all of gaming. 

Upon repeat playthroughs, the game definitely gets easier as you know where everything is and exactly what to expect, but it never stops being fun. There's enough weapon and armor variability that you can play through multiple times and have a completely different experience for each of them. 

The lore is extremely in-depth, but it's not directly told to the player. In order to figure out this game's story you either have to read every item description and take notes or you have to look up lore videos online. There's really no way you could figure out all of the lore from a single standard play through. On the other hand, the lore is not required. Since the main focus of this game is the combat, you can play through the entire game without knowing any of the lore and it would be just as fun. Taking the time to figure out the lore simply adds another layers of intrigue to those that wish to seek it out.

I really don't have anything bad to say about this game. Many consider it to be the best in the Dark Souls series and I've never encountered any game-breaking bugs/glitches. Everything is difficult but in a fair way that makes you feel rewarded for progressing. If you like the slower punishing combat that rewards good decision making, then you need to give Dark Souls a try.

[h1]DARK SOULSâ„¢ REMASTERED[/h1]
In this game you're nothing, less than nothing. And each time you fall, you need to stand up and go further. It's not a game about getting over enemies, it's a game about getting over yourself... and enemies.
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Dark Souls is an Action RPG game, where you free to choose what to do next. There are a lot of activities: from exploring new locations to farming souls or gear. The charm of the Dark Souls is the enemies and bosses, that won't spare you. But you'll get used to it... You will.
[b]World[/b]
The beauty of the world in DS1 is indescribable. I was astonished when I first saw the Ash Lake. The primordial beauty of the world right before your eyes. Also, there are a dozen of shortcuts from one location to another, and when you open them you'll be like: "Wait, what? How did I get here?".
[b]Soundtrack[/b]
Gwyn's OST goes plink plonk.
[b]Conclusion[/b]
It's not just a "hard game", it's a whole journey that you need to experience. I'd 100% recommend you to try it, but be aware of the [strike]amazing chest ahead[/strike] consequences...

[b]10 Dark Souls out of 10[/b]

Any group of mooks is more dangerous that half the bosses as multiplicity throws positioning and timing out the window so you get stun-locked by a basic hollow's leaps and flails. Bosses are either crushed first try by simple wailing or take many infuriating attempts to build up a vague intuition of what the borderline opaque windups and arena-filling hit-boxes are. Get hit once and you're probably going to be finished off before you can even try to defend or evade again most of the time. Critical paths are straight up concealed, especially ladders that are barely visible most of the time. The tutorial is vestigial and you are thrown in the deep end full of sharks.

But then there is the sense of conquest when you defeat this malicious game even with the mildly treasonous controls and camera, badly stacked interrupting, enemy-favouring hitbox shenanigans, and all else.

It's like Dark Souls

The masterpiece that made Hidetaka Miyazaki famous is back in a wonderfully remastered edition. As it, there is no change to the original structure, just a revamped lighting engine and a solid sixty fps through to whole game. The budget price is very good for the few who still never played this classic, and a good chance for the rest who loved it to play the definitive edition.
I'm Dark Souls five.

Damn these games are long, huh? 80 hours for DS2 and almost 50 for this. Most of the games I play are 4-12 hours long and I think Dark Souls is a good example of why that might be the ideal length, because people don't do a great job describing exactly how rough that second half is. I mean aside from the spectacle of it from a distance, and one of the best bosses in the series, even Anor Londo didn't impress me. 

Now believe me, I get why this game is held so high over the others for veteran fans. Back in 1974 there was nothing else like this game. When it came out it was indisputably the best at what it did and that probably had a major influence on the people who played it back then and discovered what they want from games. It definitely helps that the game makes a powerful first impression with Firelink and all of the zones directly connected to it. Those are all of the best areas in the game minus a couple.

There are a couple systems I wanna talk about, like humanity. Humanity is a consumable item that raises hp and item discovery, as well as damage with certain weapons. You can also spend it at any bonfire to increase the amount of healing items that checkpoint gives you by 5. This whole thing feels unnecessary. The game is rarely ever hard enough to warrant spending them and humanity isn't rare enough to warrant saving them so I gotta say I like the estus upgrades in future games more, and I don't want kindling to return nearly as much as I'd want to see bonfire ascetics from DS2 make a return.

The combat in this game is quick and responsive unlike the sequel, which has it's own charm. Your moveset is determined by the tools you choose to use. Not just attack moves but how effective your dodge roll is. This leads to really stupid situations where you choose a class that starts with cool armor and end up stripping all of it off for the entire first half of the game so you can get a faster roll. Honestly if you're not opposed to using a shield, I say start off with all your armor on and trying to rely mainly on blocking with the occasional roll, just so what's happening on the screen isn't so stupid and immersion breaking. Obviously if the roll is more fun to you, that's what matters most.  

The bosses in this game are mostly just alright. The great ones you've already seen online and they're pretty much the standard for DS3 and Elden Ring. 

I definitely recommend Dark Souls if not for the fantastic first half, for the rest of the amazing series that comes after the credits roll (just don't expect DS2 to immediately wow you)

Y'know how in the mid 90s, 3D became a thing, and lots of developers had no real idea how to adapt established IPs to the new hotness? Think Crash Bandicoot and the first Metal Gear Solid game. Both of those took what was proven to work in 2D and played the established formula straight in a 3D environment. Dark Souls, to me, feels like Miyazaki looked at Castlevania 1-Rondo of Blood and said "What if these hadn't become utter garbage?" Everything from the aesthetic, to the bosses, to the fact that attacking has weight to it and you can't afford to swing wildly feels like classic Castlevania given the 3D transition it deserved a few decades ago. That probably wasn't what Miyazaki was going for, but it's what I feel when I play any Soulsborne game, and it's why I appreciate them.

One of the best games what I have played on any of the platforms. I own version for PC, xbox, ps3 (and remastered for Nintendo switch) and have played on all platforms. Witth combined 4000 hours I can say for certain that this game hooked me on all similar games what came next. 
The way you understand the story of this world by slowly going deeper and deeper in unknown territory where you're not welcome at all was really special on my 1st play, and remnants of this feeling still are there after few thousand hours of making challenge runs, co-oping with friends or with random, invading for PvP or taking part in organized by content creators or myself PvP tournaments. Second part of the game feels rushed, but it is still very solid.

In my original review for DSptde I wrote that "I'm waiting remastered only because of new players who will give new life to this game, make PvP in creative locations possible again. No other fixes are needed. Why? Because DS1 does't have any problems to fix, but awful net-code." Did it give me everything I ever wanted? A Lott of people and many-many memories, recorded PvP duels? Yes, it did. It also did some disappointing changes, as healing with Estes during pvp or weapon matchmaking what killed some mechanics of original game, as chaos weapon. Was low lvl pvp toxic without this changes? Yes it was. Did it become less toxic? No it didn't. You still can use end game magic without any stats to 1 shot people.
Every time I see someone new playing this game, I wish it was me, experiencing this world without knowing anything and getting frustrated and feeling like some of the mechanics are unfair and not so user-friendly. This game offers the greatest interconnected world. Each NPC having little dialogue yet has great personality and can tell his story with little to no words, leaving a lot of space for your imagination, as if you're reading a book on a language what you don't fully understand and your mind is filling this gaps, making you part of this world.
Even after these years, this game is still a well-made one compare to other fascinating games that are well acknowledged by gamers worldwide.

A brilliant map and top notch gameplay.

Still highly worth it.

As someone who never quite understood the appeal of Dark Souls and always considered them unfair designed, I finally understand the appeal of it. "It's not about the destination but the journey" is a quote that could not be more true when it comes to this game. Every bit of annoyance the game throws at you is needed for you to experience the best pay off you will probably ever have in any game.

That means if you consider yourself to have the mental strength to go through a journey of pain/suffering/hardships/joy, then this game will give you something very special and change the way you look at game-design as a whole.

[h1] Too clunky and janky to be enjoyed [/h1]

Multiple aspects of the game are quite poorly made. Sadly this makes it very unfun to play.
A few examples of what I mean:
[list]
 [*] The controls only allow you to move in 4 directions. Front, left, right or back. This is quite annoying when you want to roll as your character can't roll at a 45Â° angle. When fighting in narrow spaces or on small elevated walkways this can get you killed very quickly.
 [*] The hitboxes are incredibly unprecise. I rolled away from a monsters swing attack, saw his claw going 2 to 3 meters past me and I still got hit. The other way around I had situations where I attacked with a Greatsword and saw half the texture of the blade going INTO the body of the enemy, but he didn't take damage. It just didn't count the hit. When shooting a bow or crossbow past a wall or object this is also very obvious. The arrows and bolts are often stopped despite clearly flying past and then get stuck in mid air.
 [*] Sometimes you will just die to random bugs. I rolled into a pot to destroy it and was insta killed by it. This is not supposed to happen. It's bugged. I also died when traversing a fog gate because the game placed my character too far to the side and I immediately fell down a cliff. In a hardcore game which punishes you for every death this is [i] VERY [/i] frustrating and must not be a thing.
 [*] Multiple places in the game have death traps which you will die to unless you already know about them. Something like an enemy jumping at you from behind a corner and stabbing you in the back. This isn't fun. Neither is it challening or difficult. It's just annoying.
 [*] You sprint by holding down B on a controller. This can not be set to toggle. You move your camera with the right stick. As a result you can not move your camera while sprinting. This is annoying when you want to run around large bosses because you can not see them as you will always look to the front while sprinting.
 [*] There is no pause button. You can open any menu but the game keeps going. Fanboys will go on about how this is immersive but it's just annoying. Someone rang the door or something else in real life needs your attention? Well screw you because you can't pause. Some might argue that this is due to the Online functionality of invasions, but it's not available in Offline mode either. It's just a bad design decision.
 [*] The UI is a horrific mess. There are multiple menus for equipment and the things you'd want to do with your equipment are scattered across them. Some stats are displayed in multiple menus, some only in one, but not the other.
[/list]

Overall easily half, if not more, of the games 'difficulty' comes from how janky and clunky it is. And that just means it's not fun to play.


The game has some positive aspects too.
[list]
 [*] The atmosphere within the world is great
 [*] The lore and story (while very cryptic) are interesting
 [*] The way the level design loops back in on itself is amazing
 [*] The visual design of the enemies looks really good
[/list]

But the negative side sadly outweighs the positive side by a lot. It's just not fun to play this game.

DARRRRK SOULLLLS-- remastered. For being the game that started it all, it certainly holds up til this day. I know lots of people think its a lazy remaster, but when I first played the og souls, it was in its remastered form. Since I played Dark Souls 3 before this game, it'll be a bit hard for me to say what I like about this game, since everything I like "from" this game is most likely also in Dark Souls 3, and I also reviewed that game, But I'll give it my best.

The world of this game definitely feels big, having everything connected makes the game a much more enjoyable expirence, Ds3 did the same, but Ds1R just feels as if they did it better, but Ds3's world still looks more pretty cause everything in the distance definitely looks blurry in this game. The Covenants are better than Ds3 in my opinion, they feel like actual factions. They're pretty much the same as Ds3 but they were just done better, although people will probably like the switching factions from inventory option better. Having the player have access to the harder parts of the game, (Kinda like how you have access to Caelid from the start of Elden Ring) to than getting their ass kicked, to then coming back later when stronger makes for a good way to feel as if you're actually getting powerful. The bosses aren't as crazy as Ds3 or Elden Ring, but it gets a pass for being old (the best bosses are really just the DLC ones, they just feel more hyper active than the base game bosses). The Boss music isn't as intense as the other games, but its somber parts are something of a beauty. It also has one of the best upgrading paths when it comes to weapons. There are so many different ways to upgrade your weapon its actually insane. Its the same for Ds3, but this game made me learn to appreciate it.

Most people when they play this game will be annoyed that you can't fast travel to the other bonfires at the start, I kinda like how you have to earn this ability, makes me feel like i'm on a adventure more, having to walk back to the places I've passed. What annoys me though is the constant having to run a fucking marathon to get to a boss fight from a bonfire. The closet bonfires that are next to boss fights are 3 football fields long. This makes areas that look cool and beautiful start to annoy me, and I lose that feeling of what I thought of it, cause having to walk through the area 10 times cause I died 10 seconds into the boss fight makes me now annoyed at the environment, seeing how I have to run through the whole thing again just to get back the the boss, even though I love the areas and environments in this game, I think they're better than DS3 (not including Ringed City because that shit slaps) and on par with Elden ring if it wasn't for the blurriness. 

This game is definitely way harder than Dark Souls 3 in my opinion, but i think its more bullshit hard if anything. The Main thing is the stun locking, getting stun locked in this game can happen very easily cause most of the armors have 0 poise, so have fun doing any fashion with armor that offers that (thank god for the poise ring). Bosses can literally 2 shot you, because their first hit will stun you, then their second one will be the killing blow. This was the case for me for the final boss, and I had 40 vigor (it "was" NG+ though) Bosses in this game don't swing as much as in the later installments, so learning their patterns aren't as hard. Oh, and you might as well just throw those Estus Flasks away, every time you're in the middle of healing, the boss is programmed to run or jump to you at the speed of Usain Bolt and knock you out of it or take more of your health than what the flask gave you.

The "PvP", it might be one of the gayest things I have ever seen. Back stab back stab back stab FUCKING BACK STAB, PVP IS JUST BACK STABBING. And the proc for doing a back stab is insane, someone could be behind you, but as long as they are 8 steps close to you, they will get a backstab on you. Using heavy weapons will punish you, cause players will poise through or roll through your swing and walk behind you and backstab you, and you can't roll away cause the swinging animations are so long with large weapons. I don't hear anyone talk about this, but the lock on system is ass. Being locked on to something only allows you to roll in four directions, Up, down, left, right. There is no Up left or Up right, just full on WASD movement with one finger. Fighting bosses was so annoying with Lock on, that I beat the game without it, and it just made things more easier in my opinion, but don't you dare think about NOT locking on during PvP, you'll just be leaving your back open for a backstab.

Now it may just sound like i'm now shitting on the game, but i'm not, I really do love this game, this blows most other games out of the water, Dark souls 1 is in my top ten games of all time to me for gods sake, although this game to me is an acquired taste. Throw your average COD or Battle royale player at this game and they'll probably fucking hate it. But once you actually put the time and effort into this, you'll just love it. For being the first Dark souls, it definitely sends the series in a nice running start, and those who have played Elden ring should definitely play this so they may know just how the Souls games have improved and gotten better since this timeless classic. Praise the Sun

No other game has come close to surpassing this masterpiece. May 12, 2015 was when I purchased Dark Souls: Prepare To Die edition on PC, for over seven years since it has been my favourite game alongside Dragon's Dogma. Today I completed every Steam achievement for the second time in the Remastered edition of the game and I'm only sad that there aren't more challenges for me to track with achievements,  That should give you an indication of how much I adore Dark Souls, I hope you love it too if you decide to give it a try.
