Certainly one of the greatest works of our time, at least in the world of video games as art. A deeply flawed masterpiece that shines above the efforts of so many other developers, for better or worse.

I highly recommend this game to:

* Anyone who wants or needs a potent reminder of what we can become, if and when, we manage to set our minds to something (absolutely NOT to downplay how incredibly challenging that step in itself is).
* Someone looking for personal, emotional resonance in a game, in a world of games that seem to be about min-maxing spreadsheets.
* Anyone who finds themselves inspired by the bleak, the macabre, who can pull positivity out of the depths of despair, or anyone who is searching for what that means.
* Anyone who believes this game isn't for them - I promise you that most of the discourse you see online is either surface level, right for the wrong reasons, or just flat out incorrect. Ignore anyone who seems to boast or wish to speak of comparison of work or achievements. All of our steps and achievements are valid and our own, for ourselves.

This game has fundamentally changed my life in a way that I feel games have not since I was much younger, merely in the process of getting hooked, perhaps even breaking me free from borderline addiction to mere escapist fantasy.

I implore you to give it a shot and give it an earnest try, and to do your best to free ourselves from others' statements of "should" in this game. What you choose to undertake, and in whichever manner you choose is your cross to bear. I beg of you not to let others take that away from you. We don't have to wait for others to allow us to feel accomplishment; we can reach it from within ourselves, when provoked.

Go forth and conquer. Climb digital mountains to peaks you've never even dreamed of, that you would never have believed possible for you to overcome.

Don't you dare go hollow, friend.

[h1]Fooled by that toothy serpent, they upturned the grave of primeval man and incited his ornery wrath.[/h1]

After playing through [b]Dark Souls 3[/b], I was amazed by just how much the game offered in terms of content. After many years of not playing the game due to many distractions, I finally decided to try out the first [b]Dark Souls Remastered (DSR) [/b]game. I have to say, I was not disappointed with my experience of this game, it nails what a game should have in terms of being a good game.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Fun and challenging gameplay, with plenty of builds to do
[*]Dark fantasy world with very interesting places to explore
[*]Fun side content for you to do
[*]A fantastic soundtrack that is nice to listen too
[*]Beautiful dark fantasy-like setting
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[*]The early game has a very steep learning curve
[*]Some of the mechanics in the game are a little rough
[*]The last few bosses were quite easy
[/list]
[h1]Story[/h1]
The story for [b]Dark Souls[/b] is not exactly told to the player but there are some bits and pieces to it that you can make out. You will understand what your objective is at some point but the game wonâ€™t tell you where to go or what to do next. This is completely fine on its own, as you can explore areas of the game to maybe find a hidden item. However, if you must look up a guide thatâ€™s not a bad thing as the game can get difficult on occasion on what to do.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3018867181
I do love the world-building that DS has as it feels like everything is alive but dead at the same time, it really fits a dark fantasy-like setting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay for [b]DSR[/b] is really fun and challenging. Since I played [b]DS3[/b], I was able to get a grasp on the controls and fit into the game just fine. In terms of mechanics, everything is pretty much the same as it was in the original version. At the start of the game, you can choose your character class and what starting item to get. There are a few interesting items for you to have, like the [b]Master Key[/b]. I should mention though that if you pick the [b]Thief[/b] class, getting the [b]Master Key[/b] is pointless as the class comes with one. So, if you get the [b]Master Key[/b] and picked the class, you will get two of those keys.

Every time you defeat an enemy, you will get souls. These souls can be used at bonfires to increase your stats and level up. Although to increase damage, that actually requires you to level up your sword at the blacksmith in the game. There are four blacksmiths that you can find throughout your adventure and they can do various things for you in the game. You do have to visit them on occasion as your weapons can actually break. You will get an icon stating that your weapon is at risk of breaking, it will also do 70% less damage and you must go to a blacksmith to get the weapon repaired. Failure to do so will result in the weapon breaking completely and it does 85% less damage. Shields and armor can also lose their durability and may need repairs as well but I never came across this issue during my playthrough.

I should mention that leveling up your stats in the game will also increase your damage as well, itâ€™s just the blacksmith is the key way of doing it.

There is also a lot of side content for you to do, like doing side quests, fighting hidden bosses, or even doing the DLCs that come with the game. A lot is given to the player when they play the game and with a big world you explore, there is a lot for you to go out and do. The game also rewards you for going out of your way by giving you hidden items, weapons, armor, or even spells.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3018866871
Although I do have a small warning for those that have come from [b]DS3[/b] or are just starting out. When you try to heal, your character comes to a complete stop, they wonâ€™t walk while they are healing. Unlike in [b]DS3[/b], where that is a thing, this is not a con for the game, just a small warning I wanted to give out.

However, I do have a few minor issues that donâ€™t ruin the experience in [b]DSR[/b] but are at least worth mentioning. The first two issues I have with the game do go together and I should at least talk about the steep learning curve that the game has. As well as the mechanics that the game gives you starting out that are a little rough too. I am going to talk about this status element in the game called [b]Curse[/b], which is a completely unique status element to this game only. The only way for you to get [b]Cursed[/b] is by getting inflicted with it by the [b]Basiliskâ€™s[/b] mist attack (one other enemy and a Boss can do it to). If the curse meter is full, you are killed instantly, when you respawn at your bonfire, your health is cut in half and you canâ€™t summon player phantoms or the NPC phantoms in the game. This effect is with you permanently until you get it removed.

The only way to cure the [b]Curse[/b] is by a [b]Purging Stone[/b], although there is an NPC who will do it for a fee of one [b]humanity[/b] but getting to him is a problem. The only way to get these purging stones is by going to the [b]Bell Gargoyle Belltower[/b], you will meet someone named [b]Oswald of Carim[/b], who will sell you these stones for 3000 souls. Although to get to him, you have to travel a little bit, which should take you at least 20 minutes or more because the enemies you have to deal with along the way can be a problem. You also canâ€™t really run past them due to the dogs in that area being very fast and doing bleed damage, plus the other enemies too. Remember, your health is cut in half, meaning a few hits will take you out. The only other way to get a [b]Purging Stone[/b] is by finding the [b]Undead Merchant[/b], who is much closer. However, she will sell them to you for 6000 souls. By that point in the game, you may have to grind for a good 20 or so minutes to get those souls, assuming you did not pick any item that gives you them. Also, you can't fast-travel at that point in the game, so you have to either travel or grind.

Now, let that sink in and try telling all of this to a new player who just got [b]Cursed[/b]. Itâ€™s not a good feeling and this mechanic never returned in any other Souls game for a good reason. [b]Snuggly[/b], who is another NPC can also help with [b]Curse[/b] as well, so I should mention them too.

The last issue I have is that after a certain point in the game, the bosses actually start to become a little easy. There are a few exceptions to this but a large majority of them are pretty much cake walks, getting to them is more of a challenge than anything.

[h1]Graphics, Performance, and Soundtrack[/h1]
The graphics for [b]DSR[/b] are stunning, I loved how the dark fantasy setting was played out in all of the areas. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM. I experienced no issues while I was playing and the game ran smoothly at 60 FPS.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3018866635
The soundtrack is another thing I should give a small mention to, all the songs in the game were phenomenal and I loved listening to them, especially the final boss theme.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
[b]DSR[/b] is a fantastic game that I highly recommended to those starting out with the [b]Soul[/b] series to go out and play, despite the issues I mentioned above. If you are a returning player and have the [b]Prepare To Die Edition[/b], then I recommend you get the [b]Dark Souls Fix[/b] patch instead. Nothing really changes in terms of gameplay, unless you want to play the game in HD which could be a strong enough reason by itself.

Dragon Lord Demon Slayer King here.. Today we are going to reviewing Dark Souls: REMASTERED on steam for PC...

Role-play:
Dark Souls features robust role-play via game play; it has ten starting classes and you can play as a sorcerer, thief, knight, and cleric, etc. which gives the game a lot of replayability. The game features a lot of side characters which add depth to your role-playing ability as they are literally tied to your class progression. Those who may find melee combat tiresome can do the entire game with ranged combat so the accessibility curve is not too high for people who dread close combat. The game is optimally balanced for each class. Your class choice may change your perspective towards the game. I played nearly the whole series without using any magic, miracle, or pyromancy technique and when I switched to ranged combat I found the game a little less tiring and I sense the camera movement in close combat has a lot to add to that tiredness.
Level Design:
Art Design and Direction:
The art direction of Dark Souls is jaw-dropping. It features gigantic forests, castles, catacombs, and lava pits to name a few, and takes inspiration from world heritage monuments like Angkor Wat. I y features a medieval setting which gives vibes c. .. to a synthesis of eastern and western medieval culture.

Enemy Design:
Enemy Design of Dark Souls is incredibly diverse.
The game never stops surprising you. It has Dragons, Dark wraiths, Ghosts, Gargoyles, Knights, Snake people to name a few and the list is very very long. At times you are fighting mushrooms, at others you are engaged with giant rats. The game keeps it afresh till the very end.
Exploration:
Dark Souls does no hand-holding in telling you where exactly to go, what exactly you need, where to get what you need, and how to use the item that you need to use. In that sense, the whole game is a giant labyrinth with enemies lurking at unknown corners. This is where the game becomes truly difficult. It becomes too difficult at times that you have to read stuff on the internet in order to know what you are supposed to do in the game. For those who like this kind of exploration, Dark Souls is a must-play game as the exploration is frustrating, wondrous, and rewarding at the same time.
Navigation:

Dark Souls does not feature a map or a checklist of objectives and there is no mini-map to keep track of where you are coming from. This is intentional but that does not bode very favourably for the game design. The navigation in dark souls is bad. It features many checkpoints in form of bonfires but they can become very hard to find.
The bigger problem is however indistinguishable pathways and pitfalls. You may be staring at a staircase and never know that it's there. This is simply bad design, something which the later games in the series improve upon but here it is very bad and indubitably frustrating. Some may like this frustrating aspect as to them this naturally adds to the exploration aspect, this is where the masochist aspect of the player base comes from, but even they can't deny that the frustration is there, they just simply enjoy it. It is not slavery if you are into it.
Combat:
Combat is Slow, Tactile, and Fair. What do I mean by that?
Slow:
Dark Slow features natural-paced melee combat which is close to that of the real world. For far combat, the game also involves slow realistic V casting animations like an old priest blessing you in real life. It's not a hack and slash game.

Tactile:
Every armour you wear and every weapon you wield changes how your character moves i.e. it affects the expense of your stamina bar. The clashing of weapon have a realistic sense of weight behind it.
Fair:
In Dark Souls, the core game play loop involves one vs one standoff i.e. you and the enemy are on equal footing. You can heal and so do the enemies. You do get to face multiple enemies at times but more or less it has to do with where you move while being engaged in combat. You may trigger a second enemy in that fashion. You can take advantage of your enemy position by stabbing them in the back and enemies can do the same to you. You can make different builds each with its own advantages with certain types of enemies and disadvantages with certain other types of enemies.
The only negative aspects of combat are parrying mechanics which are non-tactile and texture or object clipping of enemy weapons which give them the ability to hit you through walls.

Graphical Fidelity and technical performance:
The original launch of the game was mediocre on Console and absolutely disastrous on PC where it became playable only due to community efforts.
But after the release of remaster all the woes related to technical performance are gone now.
The graphical fidelity of the game is good but it doesn't do art design and direction justice and falls a little short on it. However I have to note that I played it on 4K, as such the experience was a notch higher for me on a personal level and I am not disappointed, however, compared to Dark Souls IlI, the game shows its age speaking purely in terms of graphical fidelity. The game does not feature pause which is a gimmick move to add flair to the hype of this game being one of the hardest to date. Games can be just as hard with a pause button, Sekiro a later game by the same developers proves that. The camera is janky at times and can ruin some moments of playtime.
Sound:
The Soundtrack features melancholic tunes as ambient music and heavy choirs as boss music which gives this game series a distinct sound template. It's beautiful and loud at times but for most of the game, it's minimal and adds to the silence and mysteriousness of your in-game V surroundings.

Story:
The story in Dark Souls is good but storytelling is very inconsistent and mediocre at best. The game has rich lore but you are better off watching it on YouTube. A YouTube named Vaatividya has made a career out of it. Many players are definitely obsessed with the game's lore which may come off as pretentious at times. However, it's certainly not a game you will keep playing due to its story, no definitely not. It's most likely that you may get no sense of a cohesive story (which is there by the way) in your first play through. In short, it's good but nothing special for any seasoned reader or film watcher. I will say for the western audience it brings more freshness to the table in terms of lore to obsess over than to the eastern audience since the developers are Japanese. On a personal level, I do find the lore quite in-depth and intriguing.
Verdict - 9/10

This game is probably one of the most unforgiving games i have ever played, but after you overcome that it gives you such a good feel of satisfaction.

Nearly everything that needs be said about this game has been said already. But imma talk about it anyway. 

So yeah, it's good!! 

And yeah, it's hard. Elden Ring was my first souls game and this was a different type and degree of challenge. But it felt like a more rewarding experience.

The world design as a whole is unlike any other I've experienced. The world feels cohesive, like the product of natural development and evolution. Moving through it, you feel like a part of the world, and you feel how insignificant you are in it. Though you don't have warping for half the game, it doesn't feel tedious to traverse the world because there is always a new discovery or surprise or shortcut to find. The exploration and critical path that players can follow has great pacing and sense of momentum. 

The first half's progression is so good that when you do finally get warping, it takes away some of the sense of magic. But, I think that contributes to a sense of fatalism about the world that you feel as you come to master it. Just as you were once the victim of an indifferent world in the hard early game, as you gain strength and skill in the later game, the bosses and enemies become victims of an indifferent player character.

I think that the game is about power, the helplessness you feel when you lack it, and the terror when you have it and know that it can't last. 

What makes the game fun is how good it feels to gain power and exact it on a world trying to exact it upon you. Despite the game's fatalistic and helpless themes, you feel very much like you are in control. Whether that feeling is illusory, the fact that the game makes you feel it (and question it, when you think about it) is a remarkable use of interactive storytelling.

In short, it's great, in spite and because of its difficulty. Once you get through the difficulty wall, nothing can stop you.

An absolute classic, and arguably the best of the Dark Souls trilogy.

Difficult bosses, a large world to traverse and navigate through, and plenty a rich, dark storyline... should you choose to discover it. The biggest criticisms are that the game is "too hard", as well as how the quality drops off after Anor Londo. Whilst this is true, the first half of the game is still intricately designed, with each area being interconnected/ intertwined with several others.

If you're starting as a new player - you will get lost, you will die, and you will almost definitely get frustrated. Don't expect to be able to blitz through the whole game easily. This game is a test of patience, skill and ingenuity (depending on your playstyle/ skill level), which rewards you with the satisfaction of a hard earned victory.

I had never played a souls-game before but when I started playing this one I knew right from the get-go, I wanted to play it all the way through. I even picked up all achievements along the way.

Skill issue aside this game is truly fantastic.

While the combat, the bosses and enemies and the items are all well designed (Bed of Chaos not included),
what really stands out to me is the world-building.

The environments in Dark Souls are utterly fantastic. The way the entire world links back up so seamlessly is a huge deal in my opinion and makes for a geat time exploring.
The one which started it all.

Estremamente ostico da giocare se venite da un souls like piÃ¹ recente.

[i] Store Clerk [/i]: Sir, you have to reach to 5 more bosses using extremely tedious ways with badly designed levels and kill them to reach the final boss.

[i] Me at 4:99 [/i]: [b] Baby don't hurt me [/b] 

Dark Souls: Remastered starts amazing and shows 10 ways to frustrate you, at first you can't even move 200 meters. But with each death you get better and start to have fun. You really understand what's this game all about, the enemies you cant pass easily, the map that connects beautfiully, items you find, upgrading your weapon and defeating bosses, you get the whole idea and its really fun. 

I started to have fun when I played it as a parkour game where you kick people from cliffs and L + R2 jump on them. 

It was really amazing to get into this world and play in it. But... I thought Anor Londo was last part and after Ornstein Smough I thought I was going to play 1 large area and reach the final boss, turns out there were 5 more areas I have to go, to reach the final boss. And I can say those areas was not fun. FOA running to bosses takes too much time if it's a part of game why not make it twice longer? They fixed this in future games I think. New Londo ghosts, Road to lost izalith, saving sun bro, dukes archieves, scaleless, all of them are tedious stuff where you have to look up a guide, they didnt add merit to game and elongated it. So I really didnt like the second part, but overall its a great game made by a great company, anything game aims to do is amazing, the thing they aimed to do... not so amazing.

But I played this in 2023 where time is an absolutely valuable currency for me, so I was a little hesitant to finish it, if I had played 5-10 years before I would be more patient... Or not! I wouldnt like the second part thats for sure.

I dont recommend this game if you dont wanna play every souls + bloodborne game, if you are starting for the first time dont play this game, if you finished other games i think you should just repeat those games.

If you are just starting to this series just play Bloodborne DS3 Elden Ring or Sekiro.

Amazing trap ahead
Truly a great game, the lore of the world and the design of everything is perfect.

Playing this game, I realised its not bad as I thought. It certainly does have it's charm, but i still think that it is one of the worse Souls games. However, this does not mean its a bad game. I respect it. 

2/10

The overarching problem with this game is [b] the size of the world and how you move in relation to it. [/b]

This leads to these particular problems.

1. Save points:

- The save points act as respawn spots. Pretty standard. What isn't standard is [b] not having any before a boss. [/b]

- This forces you to walk back each and everytime you want to retry a boss. These [b]walks-backs range between 1-5 minutes.[/b]

- Some of these [b]save points are hidden[/b] which is what creates the dynamism between minutes. If you do not find these hidden points you'll be on the higher end of the walk-back range.

- There are also [b]no auto-saves[/b] which means even if you die just exploring an area before you find a save point you'll respawn all the way back to your previous one. Depending on which one you last used ranges between another [b] 5-10min walk to return. [/b]

2. Controls

Rolling is this game's dodge mechanic. It gives you invulnerability frames and allows you to reposition.

But the roll happens when you release the button and not when you press it.

This manifests itself in a noticeable and frustrating delay. You will think there is something wrong with your controller.

Years of playing games where reacting and dodging at the very last second is the correct playstyle will have you crashing into a wall in Dark Souls.

You'll roll early, not get damaged and think "how did that not hit me?". You'll roll on time, get hit and scream "I â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ pressed the button".

This is not a game where you react but where you predict. Trial and error is the core gameplay, you will not avoid damage any first time you fight an enemy.

To run you need to hold down the roll button. The time the game needs to register your button press as long enough enough to distinguish between a roll attempt or starting a run will again result in a frustrating delay before you start running that will certainly lead you to more controls based deaths.

This also creates an unconscious dynamic where while you're holding down the button running you'll think once you release it you will roll. Needless to say this doesn't happen.

There was no point in the game where I felt I needed to walk instead of run.

The run is also a face button. This leaves you unable to move the camera unless you do a gamer 420 MLG claw grip which I'm sure causes severe medical problems.

3. Exploration :

- Game expects you to explore. But in most RPGs exploration is rewarding, This isn't the case here.

- In this game everytime you die you lose your XP. This means [b]you've gained nothing by killing enemies if you then die [/b] in the process before leveling up on a save point.

- Areas are huge and reaching a boss will have you forced to decide between walking all the way back to your save point to level up and returning (with all the normal enemies respawned) or fighting him and pray you're able to beat him in this attempt, lest you want to suffer from the [b]5min walk back. [/b]

- You'll be too busy just not wanting to die to really effectively focusing on fighting the boss.

- Both choices (walking back for a level up or fightning the boss and dying) will lead you to the walk of shame. The standard universal game choice (leveling up before a boss) will have you sit through double the walk.


4. Guidance:

- Game does not tell you where to go.  [b]Game does not hint where to go. [/b]

-  [b]There is also no map[/b]. Areas, besides being huge, are pitch black and have no discernible features/landmarks to navigate around. Darkroot Garden and Tomb of Giants come to mind.

- Many paths/ladders you need to go to are [b]blended entirely to the background[/b] which you'll surely miss. The path going down to the Depths right next to the Capra Demon fog gate is one example.

- This leads to you [b]walking around aimlessly[/b] unable to even progress to a new area because you've missed what should be an obvious path. In theory would be fine because exploration is necessary ( and rewarding? ) but because of the problems I listed above this isn't the case.

5. Conclusion:

- World is too big and you run too slow.

- There are not enough save points and the ones that do exist are placed at locations that force you to walk back for several minutes at a time.

- There isn't a designated story path.

- Game forces you to explore but punishes you for doing so.

what is there to say its dark souls it the dark souls of dark souls- ok that joke is old even by time of typing this.

if you are considering playing dark souls for the first time let this old vet of the game give you some advice (played on console more than pc)

1. get a controller that you can hook up or bluetooth to your pc, keyboard at least for me was HELLISH. controller feels a lot better.

2. dont be afraid to summon, we all need help sometimes, no theres no shame in looking for a golden or white sign to summon a friend or stranger to help us!

3. O&S is not the toughest boss, theyre just a good duo boss, dont fear them but respect the legacy they have. do that and youll figure out how to beat them *COUGHS* CHAOS ZWIEHANDER *COUGHS*

10/10 this game has helped me with anger issues and in a dark time of my life, and i love it to the moon and back.

So how does Dark Souls 1 feel in 2023?
Surprisingly good! 
I find that in From Software games early gameplay feels more interesting then late gameplay. It gives you a survival horror atmosphere: you are weak, your resources are limited, levels have no mapping and enemies of unknown danger lurk around. This feeling stays up until late game and the Giants Tomb level with its pitch black darkness.
It kept me going for the 99 hours of gameplay, and it was good fun despite the amount of struggle.
Oh, and Ornstein&Smough fight is a legend.

I wanted to wait until I had enough hours and playthroughs to give this game a fair review. (75 more hours on switch port). I remember trying to play this many years ago and like several others went the wrong direction from firelink to he catacombs. Of course I had chaulked this up to this being the hard aspect of the game everyone was talking about. After about 3 hours of dying continuously to skeletons i decided the game could promptly fuck off. How naive, how close minded I was, how much I missed out on during the early days of dark souls and its sequels. To be blunt, you can look up any critical dark souls review video and I would agree with it. The game is indeed hard but after your first playthrough you likely won't have much trouble at all navigating this world, especially given how much they force you to travel by foot and use shortcuts rather than warps fo the first half of the game. I think this game is an absolute masterpiece. The bed of chaos being the exception. I've only beaten DS2 once as of last week but I have to admit it doesn't even compare to the masterpiece that the original dark souls is in my opinion. They do have good ideas which i'm excited to see more fleshed out in my DS3 playthough. Although, these ideas just didn't hit the mark for me. DS2 was experimental whereas DS1 plays it safe in most aspects. Given this franchises unique nature of gameplay to story balance, it just works not being so experimental. I think this game is perfect to start on for a new fromsoft enthusiast and you may just end up having your entire life projectory changed by looking into the storylines of some of the npcs and bosses. I give DS1 an 11/10 waaay exceeded expectations.

It's fun but only with high poise.

For context, I played ds3 first, loved it, tried this one, hated it, played elden ring, loved it, then came back to this one and figured out poise. I just finished it the first time today.

If you try to play this game with low poise (light armor) you will get stunned by every single attack and take 10 years to recover. High poise allows you to get hit without being completely stopped in your tracks. If you like wearing heavy armor you'll have a great time but I feel like poise is so necessary in this game that it limits build diversity. The most fun I ever had in Dark souls 3 was playing a themed character called "THE BEAST" who wore no armor and used the dragon stones, claws, and the FUGS, and I was able to replicate parts of this character theme in elden ring but it's essentially unplayable in this game because of how un-fun it is to play without heavy armor.

All that being said, I did have fun running around in full Havel armor swinging around the Dragon Greatsword, but I can't think of much reason to play again if the only thing that's gonna change is my method of attack.

This remaster is a missed opportunity on a broad scale and here's why.
It's predecessor "Dark Souls - Prepare to die Edition" was, when first released on Steam, a nightmare to play due to an unaccurate and washed out keyboard and mouse controll with a fixed frame rate of 30 fps. However, over the years the community released a variety of mods, which fixed these issues and expanded the gameplay beyond these concerns. Thus, there has never been a need for a remaster which only focussed on these difficulties. Of course it's a quality of live improvement but it isn't worth the money if you already own the "Prepare to die Edition". Nevertheless, I do have to admit that the remaster did draw a lot of players in who had never experienced the original Dark Souls. Therefore, it might be worth the buy for the single players experience.
Besides the single player Dark Souls also offers a mulitplayer experience which, if you take Dark Souls 3 for instance, is the driving factor which keeps the game alive. But they didn't change any multiplayer features. And let's be honest the Dark Souls PvP multiplayer experience never has been any fun if you were not willing to invest 100 of hours into learning how to perform and counter backstabs. Additionally, spells and armor have never been adjusted for the multiplayer since the realease of the "Prepare to die Edition".
Furthermore, the access to the "Prepare to die Edition" has been terminated, which made the modding community for the original game die out on the long term.
Last but not least, the "Prepare to die Edition" is an outstanding game but it is far from a perfect product. Countless bugs, Izalith being a rushed and unfinished area, a whole lot of cut content ... "Dark Souls Remastered" never cared to adress these things during its production besides the fact that the game could have been expanded beyond its original scope. Surely, this opinion is influenced by me being a Dark Souls fan from the top to the bottom who wants to reexperience Dark Souls the same way I did when I first layed hands on the game. The past years have shown that it isn't a far fetched dream to wish for a good remaster of a game. With the "Deamon Souls Remastered" an example even comes from the Dark Souls universe.

Elden Ring was my first fromsoft game, which had me worried when I went to play this one. However, despite places where the gameplay feels clunky (I'm looking at you Bed of Chaos) the story, visuals, characters, music, and combat are hugely enjoyable. It is easy to see why DS1 is so beloved.

Getting a couple things out of the way, play with a controller if you can. Using keyboard and mouse wasn't something I found to be good. If you are like me, and don't have a ton of patience for figuring out everything yourself, don't let slamming your head into a wall stop you from progressing. Asking a friend, or even playing through the game with a friend made my first playthrough enjoyable and helped me feel prepared for replaying on my own. 

Overall the only thing that I actually dislike about the game (NOT mentioning bed of chaos) is the camera lock system. It often prevents you from being able to see what larger bosses are doing, while also having weird ranges for locking on to enemies with ranged attacks. There are ways to mitigate this problem by not relying on the camera lock for combat but that wasn't something that I felt like investing time in learning.

Otherwise, the game gets a 8/10 sunlight medallions from me!

It's pretty meh, but it's difficult to pin down why I feel that way.
I have trouble being really compelled by the story, lore, and characters, despite reading item descriptions and exhausting each NPCs dialogue.
Many areas are oversized and/or under-developed, and most don't feel terribly original, so it's overall hard to grow attached to anywhere.
...but... Are all of those things really so bland compared to other games...?
I don't know. For some reason, the game just isn't clicking with me.
I've played other games that were particularly challenging or even similarly unforgiving of failure but still engaged me.
Maybe it's lack of variety in the combat?
I've played other games with relatively simple combat where that didn't bother me.
Maybe it's just all of the above combined that makes it feel so bland.
Uncompelling world, vapid environments, and uninteresting gameplay...
Overall, there just isn't much to keep me interested.

I hesitate to give it a negative review because I don't actively dislike it overall.
If you feel like a long and meaty challenge to sink your teeth into can carry an otherwise largely bland game, give it a shot. Maybe you'll find more appreciation in it than me.

In my case, though, as someone who tends to be mostly ambivalent toward challenge, little in this game really grabbed me... besides a couple of enemies which literally did grab me. Oh, and the massive-****-off crow; that one grabbed me a few times... and those lesser batwing demons after the... --Come to think of it, there was actually a decent 'handful' of things that grabbed me.

It's dark souls. It's annoying, unfair, difficult, and so much fun to overcome and explore. Considering when it came out it's genuinely magic that it's as good as it is. If you're looking for a starting place in the series I recommend Dark Souls 3 first, but Dark Souls 1 is fine too.

Honestly worth it at full price I think and the game runs pretty amazing. Normally I would go through every element of the game to evaluate it but I don't think it's fully necessary for this so let's go rapid fire.

Music: Pretty good, Only weird thing is that your character inevitably moans erotically after getting hit.
Visuals: Overall I think the art style is pretty good, but you can tell it hasn't fully evolved yet. Enemy designs feel good but not great and weapons can sometimes look awesome, and sometimes look boring.
Story: There is definitely a cool story here and while piecing it together yourself can be a great experience, it's also next to impossible to do alone and I recommend watching Vaati.
Gameplay: Here we go. The game is hard but outside of the basics of learning when to roll, hit, and use healing, just make sure your are leveling up your weapon as much as possible and focusing on min maxing your character and you should be able to eventually beat the game. The world is super rewarding to explore and you really can feel an extreme difference in your level of mastery after beating the game. I missed a boss so I ran through the game in new game plus at supersonic speed to reach them, and it really felt great after I struggled so hard the first time.

I believe it's worth your time and money and I hope you pick it up and enjoy it!

The Good is being Got

If I had to describe "Dark Souls" in a succinct way, I would say that it is an old-fashioned game. Granted, this is a game from 2011, but even back then, I would think some of its aspects weren't what you would call "modern". There is no map of any kind, and there is no indicator of missions or where to go. And this can be very annoying: you'll feel kind of lost in that world.

However, when you compare that to the old "Zelda" games, you can see that this game represented some sort of rescue; that Hidetaka Miyazaki wanted to bring back that idea of a world that was supposed to be freely explored, and you would just find new things in your path: eventually, you would bump into a main story element. There are no dead ends: every path leads to somewhere. And some places hide immense secret areas that can go an entire play unexplored.

The world design, however, is not really an open-world like "Ocarina of Time"; it actually reminds me more of "Banjo-Tooie", in that it's not composed of separated levels. Everything is interlinked with shortcuts and passages you wouldn't believe. Still, it is sprawling in its own way, like a series of areas that lead to each other. But again, it's easy to get lost in it, as you'll have to memorise it, which you'll do with enough gameplay.

Then, there's the combat - perhaps the most infamous aspect of the game. I actually concluded "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice" and "The Surge" before I properly started this game, and let me tell you, I don't find it that hard. If anything, it's like a slower-paced version of "Sekiro". It's all about timing: this game is not about swinging swords against your foes, but striking and blocking at the right time.

My biggest issue with the game however is the pause menu, which doesn't actually pause the game. This may be because this is also an online game, and online games can't usually pause. What I find weird is that even when I'm offline, the game still doesn't pause - and sometimes, I have to pick a phone call, or I have to go to the bathroom, or I have to pick my nose! So you just stand in a corner, hoping no enemy will creep on you while you're out.

I find the soundtrack to be beautifully composed but poorly executed, as if FromSoftware didn't have the budget for a proper full orchestra. As for the performance, the game runs beautifully: people talked a lot of crap about this remaster, but it goes without a hitch, and while the graphical adjustments are not in par with, say, the remaster for "Modern Warfare", the game is stunning with what was added to it.
After all this time, it remains a legend, and it will always be.

This game is just perfect. I came from completing Elden Ring and decided to go back and get through the Dark Souls trilogy. Man am I glad I made that choice. This game doesn't have the best combat of the series, nor the best bosses, nor the best weapon variety, nor the best visuals. However, the inter-connectivity of the world building and the atmosphere alone are enough to convince me this is the best Dark Souls game, and there isn't a doubt about it. Turning every corner gives you butterflies in your stomach. You'll be wandering around for an hour and begin to feel like you are 100 miles away from where you started, wondering how in the world you are supposed to navigate your way out of the current area, then all of the sudden come across a path back through the Valley of the Drakes back to Firelink. Setting scale aside, this game has better world-building than Elden Ring(Which I deemed the best game ever upon completion) and I do not say that lightly. Finally getting to the end and beating Gwyn was magical, I jumped up out of my seat and screamed "**** YEAH". Then I poured a cup of coffee and sat in my silent living room for 30 minutes just thinking about my journey in retrospect. If you're looking for modern, over-the-top high octane combat, sure Dark Souls III or Elden Ring will probably suit you better. However if you're looking for an atmospheric challenging title that brings you that warm, fuzzy feeling like back in the day, look no further than Dark Souls 1, you won't regret it.

Getting into Dark Souls, as well as the other games by FromSoftware may seem intimidating due to how difficult they are compared to other games on the market, but if you look past the steep learning curve, then you have yourself a masterpiece of a game. Dark Souls acts as the beginning of not only FromSoftware's flagship franchise, but also birthing the Soulslike genre, which is characterized by an emphasis on environmental storytelling, mastering combat mechanics through each boss, and expected player death that ties into the story. The biggest strength of Dark Souls is the level design, which is easily one of the best ever put in a game. Each area has a unique identity of its own but somehow smoothly connects with one another. There are multiple routes that lead to different areas, most specifically Firelink Shrine, which is basically the main hub of the game. The linearity of the level design also greatly benefits the player as there is a loose, but clear enough path on how the player should progress throughout the game, which removes the need for quest markers and waypoints. Without the quest markers and the clear objectives, it allows you (the player) to fully adventure through the world of Lordran. As for the story and narrative, there's very little exposition and dialogue that is spoonfed to the player. Cutscenes are very sparse and are usually reserved for boss fights and key points of progress. It's up to the player to pick up the pieces throughout their playthrough to further uncover the lore and overarching narrative, much like the real world where you learn by picking up bits and pieces of information from different sources like people or books. If you are up for a challenge, then I 100% recommend picking up this game.

Having heard countless people praise Dark Souls for its difficulty and unforgiving nature, I finally decided to experience it myself. Purchasing it during a Steam Sale, I embarked on a challenging adventure.

At the beginning, I found myself constantly struggling, but gradually, I honed my skills and adapted to the game's demands. However, I must emphasize that the game never became easy; it was my improvement as a player that made the difference.

Completing the game was an unforgettable journey, and I consider it one of the most rewarding experiences I've had as a gamer. The game continually forces you to step out of your comfort zone, discouraging reckless rushing and instead requiring thoughtful and methodical gameplay.

Even the most basic enemies can be formidable opponents if approached carelessly. Overall, Dark Souls Remastered is a masterpiece, challenging players while offering a deeply gratifying sense of achievement.

Throughout my time with Dark Souls, I couldn't help but draw parallels between the game and real life. It struck me that the challenges presented in the game mirror the hurdles we face in our daily lives. Just as in the game, we encounter obstacles everywhere, but it's our ability to assess and strategize that ultimately leads to success.

In many ways, the game taught me valuable life lessons. It reinforced the importance of perseverance and resilience in the face of adversity. Each defeat in the game became a stepping stone, a lesson learned, and a chance to improve. This process mirrored the way we grow and develop as individuals by learning from our mistakes and pushing ourselves beyond our comfort zones.

Believing that overcoming Dark Souls can translate into success in real life may sound like a bold statement, but it's one I strongly stand by. The game's challenges demand patience, determination, and the will to keep going despite repeated setbacks. These are the very qualities that can help us conquer the trials and tribulations we encounter in the real world.

Dark Souls is not just a game; it's a metaphor for life. It shows us that with dedication and the willingness to learn from failure, we can tackle even the most daunting challenges. This powerful message makes Dark Souls Remastered an exceptional and unforgettable experience that extends far beyond the virtual realm.

[b] TLDR: This is the game that turns a boy into a man [/b]

I remember being among those who was turned off from any FromSoft RPG because of their hard-earned notoriety for being difficult. I tried Dark Souls 3 a couple of times and didn't make it terribly far because I would get so mad I'd quit. It took me watching Noah Caldwell-Gervais' video talking about the Dark Souls trilogy to finally get myself this remastered version of the first official entry, not only because it is the first, but because the blocking and parrying are more forgiving. 

Like Noah, I found myself looking for every opportunity to make the game easier for myself, summoning NPC and human help alike, using ranged attacks, upgrading my weapons and stats; along with "getting gud" by learning how to deal with every boss and standard enemy, knowing full well that a single mistake could spell doom. I got so mad multiple times that I'd delete my saves and start over out of rage, whether because of a boss I got stuck on, or a part of the regular level that did my head in, or the wheel skeletons that are, in my opinion, some of the worst enemies put in a video game. This love-hate relationship culminated in me beating my first playthrough the day before my birthday this past January and my first New Game+ playthrough 8 days before writing this.

Now, I have the whole trilogy, Sekiro, and Elden Ring in my library, and I want to play Bloodborne and Lies of P, too. Halberds and greatswords are my weapons of choice because the game allowed me to see which ones I liked. I have a new save where I'm running a pyromancer and I want my next one after that to be a cleric that I level into a paladin. My favorite bosses of the ones I faced across the trilogy are Artorias, Sif, and the Abyss Watchers because they are the most straightforward (i.e. least-gimmicky) and are adjoined in the feeling of doing a dance when fighting them.

Playing Dark Souls and reading Berserk served to remind me that things like these are worth persevering and seeing to the end, no matter how fuck-off difficult they are. I've seen for myself why people think Dark Souls is one of the best games ever made, and I'm fond of it, warts and all. The interconnected world design, melancholic music themes, funny ragdoll physics, and the simple act of grinding for souls on simpler enemies made me stay for the ride. 

If for no other reason than to make your own memories, reader, I suggest touching this game. It's very lenient for one of its kind, I find, in spite of its jank.

Dork Souls Remastered

The original PC version of Dark Souls was the first Souls game I played but that version (without mods) is pretty busted. 

However, this remaster is a solid PC port. Some parts of this game have not aged well -- mainly Lost Izalith still feels unfinished, Bed of Chaos is still the most obnoxious boss in any game ever made, and the New Londo ghost enemies are still extremely obnoxious -- but otherwise I think this game holds up pretty well. 

I think the level design is still the best in any of the Souls games. The way that the levels interconnect feels metroidvania-esque. Compared to recent Souls games like Bloodborne/Dark Souls 3/Sekiro/Elden Ring, most of the bosses in this game feel pretty basic but they are still an exciting spectacle. The combat in this game is slower paced compared the newer Souls games but it feels weighty and satisfying. 

Overall, I had a lot of fun revisiting the original Dark Souls via this remaster.

This is my second experience with a soulsborne game. After 100% Elden Ring some months previously I knew I wanted to play through Dark Souls. I however, waited for a sale before buying it. If you are familiar with Elden Ring there are a lot of similar features such as how leveling works or how a bonfire resets enemies in an area and fills up your healing uses. However, unlike Elden Ring which is open world Dark Souls seems to focus more on the dungeon aspects of the world. When going through an area they are pretty good about setting up shortcuts you can unlock which allow more convenient access to other locations. Like Elden Ring you can access previous locations and in fact there are reasons to go back to previous areas. However, the fast travel system is more limited meaning you will have to remember how to get around and where the convenient shortcuts are. 

The Combat in this game is also similar enough that if you made it through Elden Ring you will be fine with this game. At the time of this review I am mostly through New Game Plus and highly recommend this game.

Considering that Sekiro was the first FromSoftware game I've played (outside of maybe a few minutes of Tenchu back in the day), I thought I'd be reasonably appreciative of Dark Souls, but ultimately underwhelmed because I'd been spoiled by the newer entry's QOL features, graphical improvements, and its vastly expanded movement and melee combat.

I was dead wrong.

Sure, I see the core of what would eventually evolve into a radically different, near-perfect game, but that core itself is STILL an absolutely unmissable experience to this day.

I don't know what I can say about Dark Souls that hasn't already been said by other, more seasoned FromSoftware-sexuals out there about its difficulty and the satisfaction of beating its challenging bosses. It's a great game that absolutely deserves all the praise it's gotten over the years. But I'll try.

Is it perfect? No. Are ALL of its bosses, at least the required ones for story progression, all flawlessly designed? No. I'm looking at you, Bed of Chaos. But what it does get right in terms of boss design, its varied and interconnected environments, and the ways you can tune your playstyle? It absolutely knocks all of that out of the park. Experiencing this classic now, I completely understand why it's compelled so many people and even spawned so many imitators that can't hold a candle to its quality.

The mechanical consistency that I admired in Sekiro has its roots in Dark Souls. For all its (slightly) clunky movement, slower pace, and recovery animations that last an eternity and WILL be punished when you mistime anything you do, none of it is the kind of "jank" that you gotta work around. It's the kind of system that can be learned because it's always consistent. You get a feel for its controls the more you play. Your rolls, depending on how much weight you've got on, always go at a consistent distance. You can hold your shield up to block, but timing it after a roll or an attack is reliable when you get a feel for how long it takes your character to pull up their shield. Attack animations, both yours and your enemies', are readable, so even if you're the type to want to lug around a slow, heavy weapon, knowing that its attack animations are always at a consistent timing will give you a feel for when it's safe to swing it. Parries are more dangerous to screw up than in Sekiro, but given the great readability of most enemies, you'll know which attacks you can parry almost at a first glance. It'll take a few tries. And a few deaths. Maybe a lot of deaths. But it's not something you can't overcome. And when you do, god, you're rewarded with some big damage, and for some smaller weapons, a kick to your opponent's face, just to add insult to injury. It's fantastic.

Everything you can do in Dark Souls is measurable, but in a way that's intuitive. What may seem clunky in your first hour can turn into some particularly elegant gameplay by the end. And this mechanical consistency is what a lot of games, not even just Souls-likes, often get wrong. But it's a quality that's just as evident in this classic as it is in a game as recent and as polished as Sekiro.

And the best part, especially for folks who might be hesitant because of this game's notorious difficulty, is if you're starting to feel like you're stuck, Dark Souls is so insanely open-ended that instead of beating your head against a wall you can't break through, you can always try going elsewhere and come back at another time. Try a different route. Maybe you'll find a secret. Maybe you'll find a whole new area. Maybe you'll encounter an entirely different boss. Maybe you'll find someone willing to trade with you or give you some kind of cryptic hint about the world after a bit of creepy laughter. Maybe you'll find a good place to farm for souls and get stronger. Maybe you'll find an item that, as it turns out, makes the previous boss you were stuck on an absolute joke. This game rewards exploration in the best ways possible.

Which brings me to the world this game is set in. Good lord almighty. The kingdom of Lordran, for all its death and destruction, is absolutely beautiful. God, the SCALE of these places, man. To be honest, I assumed that Dark Souls, despite all I've heard about it taking inspiration from the Berserk manga, was going to be generic western fantasy. It's not. It's very Japanese in how it handles western fantasy. It takes its inspirations and does two things with it that I've seen in other Japanese games: it either mangles it to be something exceptionally horrifying, which is most evident with the boss designs, or in terms of its world design, it upscales everything, and I mean EVERYTHING to be as large and grandiose as possible, while applying the same type of corruption and undeath appropriate to its themes. The transition from Sen's Fortress to Anor Londo is one of the greatest things I've experienced in a game, and it's serviced by how challenging it was to get through the former. THAT is how you introduce a new area with an entirely different feel and scale after making your players think they've seen everything.

Dark Souls is the furthest thing from generic in terms of its presentation, and I am absolutely disappointed with myself that it took me this long to grab this game and play it. It makes me appreciate everything that I found beautiful about Sekiro while the first entry in this iconic franchise still holds up on its own merits. So much that I'm willing to suffer through another run just to see what I missed.

Don't let the game's reputation of being difficult make you miss out on what it does best. I say the same thing about Sekiro, and I'll say it again for Dark Souls. FromSoftware knows how to make the difficulty inherent in their games pay off. And said difficulty rarely ever feels distinctly cheap. Victories are earned in Dark Souls, whether it's entirely through you "git'n gud" with your dodging and rolling, suffering alone with just a sword and a shield, as I did, or doing the 200 IQ move of using ranged attacks, magic, and summons, or if you're the type to be thorough in your exploration and you find other ways to beat its challenges. These are all ways that the game accepts, even if some "hardcore" fans don't. Don't mind them. This game's far more flexible than folks like them would make you think. Either way, there's no replacing the satisfaction of beating this game for the first time. I can't wait to get started on FromSoftware's other games, but at the same time, there's a few optional bosses and some secret areas I missed on my first run, and some more item descriptions for me to read to get a sense of the lore without watching a Vaati video. So once again, just like Sekiro, I'mma be doin' some NG+, baby.

Yes, this game is difficult, punishes errors heavily, and is borderline abusive, but at the same time, all the difficulty gives a unique sense of accomplishment for every step overcome. A lot of people say that it's a masochist's game, but there's a level of patience and stoicism that the game forces you to appreciate. I can't say that any other game I've played really engages the player in that kind of discourse. 

There are definitely some grindy bits, especially if you're going for the collect-all-the-rare-weapons achievement. But in many cases the grind is simply overcoming a new area, getting a little farther each time, until you finally kill the boss at the end and get to the next area. This means that you're not grinding for arbitrary levels or drops (although you still can do that if that's your thing), but instead each attempt pushes the game forward.

The story the game tells is very much told by reading in between the lines. There are occasional lore dumps, like the intro cutscene, but much of the info is learned by speaking to the various NPCs around the map. These NPCs have different dialogues depending on when you speak to them, and sometimes offer vague objectives the player should complete to progress. Essentially, you could play this game as a beat-em-up and miss all the lore and reasoning behind it.

The level design might be my favorite of any game. Everything is tied together in a rat's nest of levels, some open plan, some linear with a few doors scattered around. Each area is connected to every other area, but those paths may only be accessible after beating a particular boss. Everything is situated such that there's no discontinuity; every region has a footprint in the world, and many times if you look around in a level, you'll see areas below or next to you that are part of a completely different part of the game. It gives a really lived-in sense to the world when there aren't areas built just for show, but are instead all accessible. Also cool that there aren't any loading screens between regions, you can just walk between them like walking through a densely packed city.

If you have played Dark Souls, and you liked it, then I can recommend this game to you. 

Otherwise, I just don't get this game's appeal. I recently played Elden Ring and Sekrio and thoroughly enjoyed them, so I decided to see where it all began. A sizeable majority of this game is just not very good. Level design is interesting, but different rooms even within the same zone seem to have been made with a different theme in mind. Enemies don't really have any meaningful reward for killing them, so I ended up just running past most things. Pretty much every boss except for the last on is really big and really slow, more of a spectacle fight. Only at the final boss was any complexity added, and even then it was pretty bland (he just moves faster). The physics, collisions, and many other aspects are just inconsistent (swords/melee hitting invisible geometry and staggering the player, but enemies not having that same collision). The menuing was pretty tedious to navigate (but thats probably because it was designed for controller on consoles). The games seems to confuse tedium with difficulty, with 2-4 minute back tracks to bosses upon death, which really only pads time. Finally, there just wasn't really enough weapon variety and I ended up using the same catalyst+spell for pretty much the whole game. The ability to redistribute skill points at bonfires might improve this since you can adapt to new weapons you find to try them out.

I will say, one innovation that will forever change gaming is the introduction of double sided elevator which ensures the player can always ride up or down without pulling a lever and waiting. Despite this, From only used it once and all the other elevators require a lever pull for some reason.

in 2023 this game still holds its own as a deep, engrossing world full of challenge and mystery. For players coming from Elden Ring, it lacks some of the creature comforts Fromsoft has added along the years, but with hard work and determination, anything is possible.

"My soul has become darker over the years." The man in the right corner once said to me. I was eating lunch at the time I heard him say it. The Kraft mac'n cheese suddenly felt off putting in my stomach. What did he mean by this. "My humanity has decayed and what is left of me is a hollow shell of a man." Every word he says puts me into more of a disarray when trying to decipher what he just said. Could this be an indicator to clue me in on his true identity? Who was the man in the right corner? I sit there, my mac'n cheese getting colder, as his presence fades. I have no words to describe what the man in the right corner is to me but what I do know is that this was not the first or the last time I would hear from the man in the right corner. I may never know who or what he truly is.

A Christian Bible is a set of books divided into the Old and New Testament that a Christian denomination has, at some point in their past or present, regarded as divinely inspired scripture by the holy spirit.[137] The Early Church primarily used the Septuagint, as it was written in Greek, the common tongue of the day, or they used the Targums among Aramaic speakers. Modern English translations of the Old Testament section of the Christian Bible are based on the Masoretic Text.[35] The Pauline epistles and the gospels were soon added, along with other writings, as the New Testament.[138]

Old Testament
Main article: Old Testament
Further information: Development of the Old Testament canon
The Old Testament has been important to the life of the Christian church from its earliest days. Bible scholar N.T. Wright says "Jesus himself was profoundly shaped by the scriptures."[139] Wright adds that the earliest Christians searched those same Hebrew scriptures in their effort to understand the earthly life of Jesus. They regarded the "holy writings" of the Israelites as necessary and instructive for the Christian, as seen from Paul's words to Timothy (2 Timothy 3:15), as pointing to the Messiah, and as having reached a climactic fulfillment in Jesus generating the "new covenant" prophesied by Jeremiah.[140]

The Protestant Old Testament of the 21st century has a 39-book canon. The number of books (although not the content) varies from the Jewish Tanakh only because of a different method of division. The term "Hebrew scriptures" is often used as being synonymous with the Protestant Old Testament, since the surviving scriptures in Hebrew include only those books.

However, the Roman Catholic Church recognizes 46 books as its Old Testament (45 if Jeremiah and Lamentations are counted as one),[141] and the Eastern Orthodox Churches recognize 6 additional books. These additions are also included in the Syriac versions of the Bible called the Peshitta and the Ethiopian Bible.[l][m][n]

Because the canon of Scripture is distinct for Jews, Eastern Orthodox, Roman Catholics, and Western Protestants, the contents of each community's Apocrypha are unique, as is its usage of the term. For Jews, none of the apocryphal books are considered canonical. Catholics refer to this collection as "Deuterocanonical books" (second canon) and the Orthodox Church refers to them as "Anagignoskomena" (that which is read).[142] [o]

Books included in the Roman Catholic, Greek, and Slavonic Bibles are: Tobit, Judith, Greek Additions to Esther, the Wisdom of Solomon, Sirach (or Ecclesiasticus), Baruch, the Letter of Jeremiah (also called the Baruch Chapter 6), the Greek Additions to Daniel, along with 1 Maccabees and 2 Maccabees.[143]

The Greek Orthodox Church, and the Slavonic churches (Belarus, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, North Macedonia, Montenegro, Poland, Ukraine, Russia, Serbia, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia and Croatia) also add:[144]

3 Maccabees
1 Esdras (called 2 Esdras in the Slavonic canon)
Prayer of Manasseh
Psalm 151
2 Esdras (4 Ezra) and the Prayer of Manasseh are not in the Septuagint, and 2 Esdras does not exist in Greek, though it does exist in Latin. There is also 4 Maccabees which is only accepted as canonical in the Georgian Church. It is in an appendix to the Greek Orthodox Bible, and it is therefore sometimes included in collections of the Apocrypha.[145]

The Syriac Orthodox Church also includes:

Psalms 151â€“155
The Apocalypse of Baruch
The Letter of Baruch[146]
The Ethiopian Old Testament Canon uses Enoch and Jubilees (that only survived in Ge'ez), 1â€“3 Meqabyan, Greek Ezra and the Apocalypse of Ezra, and Psalm 151.[n][l]

The Revised Common Lectionary of the Lutheran Church, Moravian Church, Reformed Churches, Anglican Church and Methodist Church uses the apocryphal books liturgically, with alternative Old Testament readings available.[p] Therefore, editions of the Bible intended for use in the Lutheran Church and Anglican Church include the fourteen books of the Apocrypha, many of which are the deuterocanonical books accepted by the Catholic Church, plus 1 Esdras, 2 Esdras and the Prayer of Manasseh, which were in the Vulgate appendix.[148]

The Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox Churches use most of the books of the Septuagint, while Protestant churches usually do not. After the Protestant Reformation, many Protestant Bibles began to follow the Jewish canon and exclude the additional texts, which came to be called apocryphal. The Apocrypha are included under a separate heading in the King James Version of the Bible, the basis for the Revised Standard Version.

This is one of the few games that I think have accomplished to build a world of their own. The lore is much deeper than it first meets the eye and almost everything feels connected. The game-play is brilliant for most part and the level design especially in the early-game beautiful (exceptions: Capra Demon boss arena, Great Hollow). Also I like the feeling dark souls' world gave me, the feeling of an age coming to its end, having left its days of glory far behind it, and yet still exhausting every possible means of preserving itself, becoming more and more intolerable to its inhabitants until its eventual inevitable demise in order to give birth to something new and better; and I like it because I really think this applies to our world as well.
   Having said all that, the second half of the game feels a bit sloppy and is not so masterfully developed as the first, with the exception of the DLCs that might be even better than the base game. Furthermore there are several areas, enemies, and bosses in the game that are difficult for all the wrong reasons (examples: Blighttown, Great Hollow, Lost Izalith, Capra Demon, Bed of Chaos, Four Kings). There are also some broken builds that make the game extremely easy and are frustrating to come across in PVP and there are some tedious activities (such as cutting dragon tails) that have to be performed in order to get access to some great weapons.

A classic.  If you haven't played any of the From Software games before, I actually wouldn't recommend starting with this one.  It has a lot of rough edges and can kinda troll you.  Elden Ring is much more approachable and Dark Souls 3 is less obtuse.

But DS1 is still excellent and I had a blast playing through it again ten years later.  This version did have some bugs with full screen dumping out randomly -- it might be VRR, HDR, or high refresh rate related.  But it only happened a handful of times in 20 hours.

What an amazing game. Wayyyyyy easier than the internet claims it is. If you can hold a controller you can beat this game. I found it to be more fun to play the game with "handicaps" such as no summons, magic, or damage buffs like Power Within. The map is brilliantly engineered, and the interconnection of the areas really blew my mind while playing. The only thing i truly hate about this game, gets talked about all the time. It's the fact that it is still unfinished. Definitely worth the play through but Jesus Christ was i disappointed in some of the late game areas with the clearly rushed/empty/repetitive feel.

Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜… (5/5)

Prepare to be drawn into a world where death is a constant companion and triumph is hard-earned. Dark Souls, the critically acclaimed action role-playing game, is a masterpiece that both punishes and rewards players in equal measure. Developed by FromSoftware, this gaming gem has captivated the hearts of countless gamers, immersing them in a hauntingly beautiful and challenging universe.

From the moment you step foot into the desolate and atmospheric kingdom of Lordran, Dark Souls sets an unmatched tone of dread and melancholy. The game's dark fantasy setting is brought to life through stunning visuals, intricate level design, and an ambient soundtrack that heightens the sense of isolation and foreboding. Every location in the game feels like a piece of a bigger puzzle, waiting to be unraveled by those willing to delve deeper into its mysteries.

The gameplay mechanics of Dark Souls are its true signature. Combat is a dance of precise timing, thoughtful strategy, and immense patience. Each enemy encounter is a test of your skills and knowledge, requiring you to learn from your mistakes and adapt your approach. The satisfaction of overcoming seemingly insurmountable challenges, whether it's a massive boss or a group of relentless foes, is unparalleled. Dark Souls respects its players by not holding their hand, making each victory taste all the sweeter.

The character progression system is both deep and customizable, offering a wide range of character classes and weapon types to suit any playstyle. This versatility allows for multiple playthroughs, each offering a unique experience and sense of accomplishment.

One of the game's standout features is its interconnected world design. As you progress, you'll find shortcuts and hidden paths that link previously explored areas, creating a cohesive and interconnected world that feels alive. Exploration is key, and every corner of Lordran is filled with secrets, treasures, and lore waiting to be discovered.

Furthermore, the multiplayer aspect of Dark Souls adds an additional layer of depth and unpredictability. Interaction with other players can be both helpful and treacherous, as you might receive assistance in the form of messages or find yourself invaded by hostile foes seeking your demise.

While Dark Souls offers an unforgettable and rewarding experience, it may not be for everyone. Its high level of difficulty can be daunting, and some players may find themselves frustrated. However, for those willing to embrace the challenge and learn from failure, the sense of accomplishment is unmatched.

In conclusion, Dark Souls stands as a timeless masterpiece in the gaming world. Its rich lore, atmospheric world, challenging gameplay, and sense of achievement combine to create an unparalleled experience. If you seek a game that demands both skill and perseverance while rewarding your determination with moments of triumph, Dark Souls is an absolute must-play. Enter Lordran, brave Undead, and may the bonfires light your path.

Do I need to even say anything about this game? You've heard the rumors about it's legendary difficulty, and decided to come down to the reviews to see if it might be worth getting a game with as famous (and infamous) a reputation as this one. Great game, but with some annoying flaws:
- Sometimes the controller stops working, when I Alt+Tab out of the game, requires PC restart
- I  suggest to do some research what makes a good build, because there is no way to reset the stat points.
- Targeting/Lock on feels bad: Character can only roll in 4 directions when locked on. You need to learn to detarget mid-battle to deal with weird camera angles and the restrictive movement.
- FPS drops significantly at some places

Been looking for an excuse to replay it and recompleting the remaster was one way of doing it ^^". Though oof I can tell that this game hasn't aged so gracefully.

Not that it's suddenly now not worth recommending, no. Simply compared to the newest entries this one will feel very clunky, slow and pointlessly complicated. You truly will not realize how spoiled we are with the granted warping until you see first none and then limited options available here. Overly complicated upgrade system scattered across the game world, much harsher NG+, huge runs to bosses, tight time limits for questlines when looking for spells (most notably Miracles), awful menu deigns and usage, and widely known fact that the game kind of becomes "meh" after finishing Anor Londo as further areas feel unfinished or poorly balanced (or both), Bed of Chaos anyone? Additionally as this is a Remaster this is a rather lazy one not really fixing many bugs that existed in the original (InfernoPlus covered the matter extensively on YT).

But then of course the game doesn't require mods to work properly anymore, can use items in bulk and we got a possible warp to Catacombs. I guess it's something...even if some new things are broken like early PvP balance.
I'm not sure is it the best starting point for new souls players as its age may proof pushing off but it's most certainly the best to get started and hooked on Dark Souls deep lore and mystery of its world. Magic here is extremely powerful compared to any future entry so this can be a nice incentive. The interconnected world is still an impressive feat even if after any future entry having to traverse it multiple times may get on ones patience. Original cast of favorite characters that future games only attempt to clone. By far the BEST dragon-form in the series...

It's an old classic now that for sure still has things to offer but to someone not feeling nostalgic towards I can tell it may prove off-putting for the clunk or lackluster late-game. These simple facts that can't be jumped over so one has to be prepared for them...and to die...a lot ;3

Undoubtedly my favorite entry in the entire Soulsborne series, primarily due to its exceptional ambience, world-building, and level design. The game truly immerses you, allowing you to feel the "weight" of every aspect, be it the combat, the atmosphere, or the rich lore. The deliberate pacing of each discovery and scene adds significantly to their impact, making this entry much more memorable compared to others in the series.

With that being said, each entry in the series has its unique way of crafting a captivating and immersive world, contributing to their greatness in their own distinct ways. But Dark Souls 1 stands out as they managed to capture something truly special for me, and the subsequent entries somehow feel like they lack that charm that I really can't describe.

I had my suspicions about this game when I was considering buying it but when I took that leap of faith I ended up really enjoying this game. the world is so satisfyingly interconnected and has great atmosphere. The combat is obviously amazing, though the magic system leaves much to be desired. The bosses are very satisfying to fight, though personally I found most to be a bit too easy. that may just be me though because this is literally dark souls, notorious for being brutally difficult. What I did find difficult was the exploration. The environments are so hostile and sometimes frustrating to traverse. This would be pretty managable if it weren't for sometimes having to spend several minutes running back to where you died or even the region where you died. all in all, great game, some bad things here and there but overall amazing.

Prepare to die is a title that should go die in a fire because it made way too many people believe this game to be an impossible title, bested only by crazy people, and for a good while I was in that same boat until I finally just gave it a try a number of years ago and I was hooked. Dark Souls is one of the most replayable and enjoyable games you can find with a world designed like a 3d metroidvania letting you go almost anywhere you wish as long as you know where to find the entrance and never stopping you from growing your power to absurd levels. Its build variety is vast and its systems complex, but at its core Dark Souls is more action game than rpg therefore as long as you get a grasp of the movement and mechanics nothing can really stand a chance. If you are still afraid from what you heard or saw from others, please just give it a good, honest go and you will understand why nobody has ever stopped talking about this game after they have played it.

So.... I love Dark Souls, I love the community, I love the whole series- been here since Demon's Souls release. 
Dark Souls 1..... is not good. It suffers a major flaw that FromSoft have since fixed- and that is teleporting between bonfires. While this IS technically possible in DS1, it's not until very late game. I have had 5 consecutive runs completely ended due to this one lacking mechanic. 
Call me crazy, but I don't want to follow a guide for THE WHOLE GAME. I honestly have no idea how I ever beat this game on PS3 pre-internet guides to begin with but JFC this is just dumb at this point. I just can't recommend it anymore after 5 straight up game ending runs all because "you chose the wrong bonfire" and get stuck in a perpetual loop of death and not being able to go anywhere or do anything, messing up NPC quests and the like along the way because you can't do anything. 
This seems to be an issue right after Gargoyles. I can clear first bell in under 2hrs, while leveling, and still somehow end up in a never ending death loop no matter what way I go. Leveling has nothing to do with it, it's merely the lack of being able to escape these death loops via going to a different bonfire and approaching from a new angle. 
It was obviously an issue, or they wouldn't have immediately fixed it in their following games.
